translated_text:
"The
Gostomel airport is already ours", presidential advisor Alex√©i Arest√≥vich wrote on Facebook on Thursday night. Hours earlier, the Russian Armed Forces had announced control of the military airport, also known as Antonov, but the Ukrainian counterattack was reportedly successful.
The seizure of the airport would have given Russian forces a landing point close to the capital, to quickly disembark troops and potentially multiply troops on Ukrainian soil, surrounding the Ukrainian capital.
David Petraeus, former director of the CIA, was surprised by the Ukrainians' ability to resist, faced with one of the best-equipped war machines in the world - and experienced in conflicts in several surrounding countries.
"What was achieved today was less than I expected. We all know that the Russians can overwhelm the Ukrainians, but it appears that the Ukrainians have slowed them down quite impressively," Petraeus told US media.
Despite this success, the first day of the war saw almost incessant advances by Russian forces into Ukrainian territory - by land, air and sea. To the north - an open front from Belarus to Kiev - to the south - Russian bases in Crimea, a port enclave on Ukrainian territory conquered in 2014, advancing in all directions to create corridors - and to the east - where pro-Russian separatist forces in Donetsk and Luhansk head towards Government-controlled areas.
The Ukrainian army said on Thursday night that Russia intends to block Kiev and create a land corridor to the Crimean peninsula and the separatist region of Transnistria in Moldova. "The plan is already clear: the main objective of the operation is to block Kiev and create a land corridor to the Crimean peninsula and the self-proclaimed region of Transnistria", reads a note published on Facebook.
The Army also said that Russia has so far introduced more than 60 groups of tactical battalions on Ukrainian soil.
Mariupol, a city halfway between the separatist-controlled regions and Crimea, was one of the most intense fighting points, according to Ukrainian media reports.
Russian aviation missile fire reached almost all major Ukrainian cities, where sirens were heard throughout the day, urging residents to take refuge in shelters. In Kharkiv, thousands of women and children took refuge in subway tunnels.
Even the city of Lutsk, a few hundred kilometers from Poland ("NATO territory"), was targeted by Russian missiles, according to the BBC.
Western intelligence recognized that Russian air superiority in Ukraine was "total." "Ukraine's air defenses have been destroyed and are unable to protect themselves. In the coming hours, the Russians will attempt to gather an overwhelming force around the capital," said a source from a Western intelligence service cited by international agencies.
"Russian troops are already gathering around Kiev. It's a matter of days, or hours", explained the source, highlighting the speed with which Moscow's forces are moving around the Ukrainian capital.
An adviser to the Ukrainian President said that Ukraine today lost control over the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, after a fierce battle to try to repel Russian military forces.
Mykhailo Podolyak, advisor to President Volodymyr Zelensky, said that it is not known what condition the plant's facilities, where there is a protective shelter and the storage of nuclear waste, are in after the fighting. Wearing military uniform, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky released a video message announcing the general mobilization of the population subject to "military conscription and reservists" to combat the Russian invasion.
Also today, the President of Ukraine had already imposed martial law across the country today after the start of Russia's military operation.
At the end of the first day of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky reported 137 Ukrainians dead and 316 injured.
"Today [Thursday] Russia attacked the entire territory of Ukraine. And today our defenders did a lot. The enemy attacks not only military installations, as they claim, but also civilians. They kill people and turn peaceful cities into military targets. This is vile and will never be forgiven," he stressed.
At least 100,000 people have already abandoned their homes in Ukraine due to the invasion launched today by Russia and several thousand have crossed the borders towards neighboring countries, according to data from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).
In Washington, Brussels and other Western capitals, sanctions were the weapon of choice against Vladimir Putin's Russia.
Meeting in an urgent European Council, the leaders of the 27 have already adopted conclusions, in which they call on the European Commission to move forward with "contingency measures" on Russia's energy supply, and with "rapid preparation of a new package of sanctions" that also cover Belarus, for allowing the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The sanctions agreed today by the leaders will be formally adopted today, at an extraordinary Council of Foreign Ministers, in Brussels.
US President Joe Biden announced that the United States and allies will reinforce sanctions on Russia and that NATO's device in Germany will be reinforced with US troops, following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
"Putin chose this war" in Ukraine, and the Russian President and Russia "will bear the consequences of new sanctions", said Biden, in a statement to the media.
In Moscow, during a meeting with businesspeople, Vladimir Putin said on Thursday afternoon that his country had "no other way" to defend itself other than launching an attack on Ukraine, confirming that the Russian Army is in the process of invading that neighboring country.
"What is happening now is a coercive measure. Because we have no other way to do otherwise," Putin said in Moscow, which was broadcast by television stations.
If Ukrainians are fighting with Russian troops, Russians are fighting in the streets of major Russian cities with their own police.
Around 1,700 people were arrested today in 53 Russian cities, with close to a thousand arrests taking place in Moscow, following protests against the invasion of Ukraine, according to data released by a non-governmental organization (NGO).

translated_text:
Ground invasion points in Ukraine. Infographics: Jaime Figueiredo
War in Ukraine
,
International
Russia advances on Kiev: war in Ukraine is being fought on four fronts
The Russian invasion of Ukraine began in the early hours of Thursday from three fronts: east, north and south. Troops entered from Russia, Belarus and Crimea. Now, Moscow has also advanced on the Ukrainian capital. Kiev has been the target of explosions, shootings and missiles since this morning. Putin's goal is to install a pro-Russian regime in Ukraine
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
13:14 February 25, 2022
15:47 February 25, 2022
|
Jaime Figueiredo (Infography) and Mara Tribuna
Russian troops have already entered Kiev, despite Ukrainian resistance. The information was announced by the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense this morning, in a
post made on Twitter
: ‚Äúthe enemy‚Äù entered the Obolon district, which is about 10 kilometers from the center of the Ukrainian capital. On social media, the guardianship asked civilians to make Molotov cocktails to defend themselves and ‚Äúneutralize the occupier‚Äù, at the same time asking ‚Äúpeaceful residents‚Äù to be careful and ‚Äúnot leave their homes‚Äù.
The Russians arrived in Kiev this morning on two fronts: from the northeast and east, according to the Ukrainian army in a statement. One of the military units' entry was from Belarus, with the aim of carrying out an attack with Grad missiles against military targets. The maneuver took place through the Vilcha checkpoint, around 150 kilometers north of the Ukrainian capital, Ukrainian military authorities detailed.
Russian forces in Kiev, capital of Ukraine. Infographics: Jaime Figueiredo
The Russian Defense Ministry says it now controls Gostomel Airport, about 25 kilometers northwest of the capital, adding that a possible approach from the West has been blocked. The perimeter of Kiev International Airport, further to the southeast, is also being surrounded by Russian paratroopers.
A missile hit the northwest part of the capital in the morning. Several shots were heard near the government headquarters in Kiev, according to the Associated Press news agency. The advance on Kiev was already imminent and expected for several hours. Russian forces began gaining ground last night, with the aim of installing a pro-Russian regime in the country.
Early in the morning, the Ukrainian Government warned of several infiltrated Russian soldiers on the way, and other forces 10 kilometers from the capital. The Ukrainian military even intentionally blew up a bridge, near the village of Ivankov, to delay the Russian entry into Kiev.
Yesterday, an air raid hit residential areas in Kiev, several explosions were heard, and Ukrainian diplomat Olexander Scherba reported that ballistic missiles were hitting the city. Residential buildings on fire, a Russian plane shot down by Ukrainian anti-aircraft defenses, and sirens wailing were other reports heard from the capital on Thursday.
Attacks extend to other parts of the country
The port city of Mariupol, in Ukraine, was also the target of heavy airstrikes, with reports of ‚Äúhundreds of explosions‚Äù, as a diplomatic source told Reuters. Mariupol is one of the country's largest ports and is located near the front line held by Russian-backed separatists in the south of the Donbas region. Controlling Mariupol would help Russia secure a direct land route to Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula annexed by Russia in 2014.
Photo: Reuters / Gleb Garanich / File Photo
Troops also took Sumy, located in northeastern Ukraine and 200 kilometers from the Russian border. The city was invaded by armed cars, artillery fire and Russian soldiers wearing Ukrainian troop uniforms to infiltrate the region, as reported by ‚ÄúThe Guardian‚Äù newspaper.
The forces also took control of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant area, north of Kiev and close to the border with Belarus. Employees are being held hostage, advisor to the commander of the Ukrainian Land Forces, Alyona Shevtsova, reported on Facebook.
Ukraine also warned that radiation at Chernobyl had increased: ‚ÄúThere was an increase in indicators above control levels at 03:20 (01:20 in Lisbon)‚Äù, warned the deputy director of the Ukrainian department for safety issues at nuclear facilities. Grigorach added that ‚Äúit is not possible to verify what is happening‚Äù.
However, Russia guarantees that everything is under control. ‚ÄúRadiation in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe nuclear power plant is within normal levels‚Äù, assured the spokesman for the Russian Ministry of Defense, Igor Konashenkov.
Air raids and airport control
The Russian invasion continues to take place on a ‚Äúlarge scale‚Äù,
as the head of Ukrainian diplomacy, Dmytro Kouleba, classified
, yesterday. The Ukrainian cities of Lutsk and Ivano-Frankivsk (to the west), Chernigov and Kharkiv (further north), Dnipro and Donbas (further east), or even Odessa, Kherson, Melitopol and Mariupol (in the south) were also targeted by air attacks.
Air strike points in Ukraine. Infographics: Jaime Figueiredo
The war started by Russia has already caused at least 137 deaths among military and civilians and 316 injuries on the Ukrainian side, said President Volodymyr Zelensky in an assessment of the first day of conflict in Europe.
Meanwhile, Ukrainian border guards reported on Facebook that ‚Äúseveral people were killed and injured overnight‚Äù, following rocket fire by the Russian army, on the coast between the Crimean peninsula (annexed by Russia) and the separatist area of ‚Äã‚Äãeastern Ukraine. The Ukrainian army believes that Russia is planning to create a corridor between the two regions.
In the last 24 hours, Russia has already bombed 33 civilian areas, the Ukrainian Ministry of Internal Affairs said this Friday. "The Russians say they are not attacking civilian areas. But 33 places were hit in the last 24 hours," said ministry head Vadim Denisenko, quoted by the Interfax news agency.
At least 74 land infrastructures, 11 Ukrainian Air Force airfields, three control centers and a naval base were destroyed by the Russian armed forces, according to Russian Defense Minister General Igor Konashenkov. Four Bayraktar TB2 drones and a helicopter were also shot down.

translated_text:
"The
Eurovision Song Contest is a non-political cultural event. However, the EBU is concerned about what is happening in Ukraine and will continue to monitor the situation closely", says the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), in a statement sent to the North American public radio station NPR.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
On Wednesday, Ukraine's public broadcaster, in an open letter, called on the EBU to exclude Russia's public broadcaster from the European Broadcasting Union, calling it "a mouthpiece of the Kremlin and a key piece of political propaganda financed by the Russian state budget."
In the same letter, UA:PBC calls for Russia to be excluded from the 66th Eurovision Song Contest.
Today, Dutch broadcaster AVROTROS, co-organizer of last year's Eurovision Song Contest, made a similar appeal to UA:PBC.
AVROTROS, in a post shared on the broadcaster's official Twitter account, calls for the suspension of Russia as a member of the EBU, "with immediate effect".
"As a consequence, Russia would not be able to participate in the Eurovision Song Contest in Turin in 2022", reads the publication, in which AVROTROS calls on other countries to "speak up" and "call for Russia's suspension from the EBU".
Russia, like Portugal, has not yet chosen who will represent the country in this year's edition of the competition, which will take place between May 10th and 14th, in Turin.
Among the 41 countries in the competition is also Ukraine, which will be represented by the Kalush Orchestra, with the song "Stefania", replacing Alina Pash, the winner of the competition to choose the country's representative at Eurovision.
On February 19, Ukraine announced that Alina Pash would no longer be the country's representative at Eurovision, after there were protests due to the fact that the singer had performed in Crimea in 2015, a year after Russia occupied that region.
This is not the first time that the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has had implications for Eurovision.
In 2017, Russia refused to participate in the competition held in Kiev, Ukraine, after that country's security services prevented singer Yulia Samoylova from entering, because she had visited Crimea after the Russian annexation.
In 2019, UA:PBC withdrew from participating in the contest, which took place in Israel that year, as it was unable to reach an agreement with the winner of the contest to find the country's representative at Eurovision.
Singer Maruv, who had won the competition with the song "Siren Song", refused to sign the 'Leonine' contract proposed by UA:PBC.
The conditions of the contract included refusing to operate in Russia and being especially careful when addressing the issue of Ukraine's territorial integrity, or making public statements that could damage the country's image internationally.

translated_text:
U
A Ukrainian soldier and engineer sacrificed himself for Ukraine by blowing himself up on a bridge near Crimea to stop the advance of Russian tanks in the region.
In a Facebook post, the Armed Forces of Ukraine described the "heroic act" of Vitaliy Skakun Volodymyrovych, who "significantly slowed down the enemy, allowing the unit to organize defense."
According to the armed forces report, the soldier went to the Henichesk bridge and sabotaged the infrastructure, but when he learned he would not be able to get out in time, he decided to stay and ensure the bridge would collapse.
In the same publication, Ukrainian forces stated that they would consider Vitaliy for posthumous awarding of a medal.
The Henichesk Bridge is located in Kherson, one of the main connecting points between the Crimean peninsula and the rest of Ukraine. Although it has not been confirmed by official authorities, several journalists on the ground point out that the city was taken by Russian forces.

translated_text:
The War
World
Russia wants to "decapitate" the Ukrainian government and install a pro-Moscow regime
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
07:36
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/ALEKSEY NIKOLSKYI/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN
The Russian military, which has "complete air superiority" in Ukraine, approached Kiev on Thursday with the intention of "decapitating the Ukrainian government" and installing a pro-Moscow regime in that country, Western military sources warned.
On the first day of the invasion of Ukraine, the Russian Armed Forces fired more than 160 missiles at Ukrainian military targets and, from Belarus, quickly advanced south "approaching Kiev", a senior Pentagon official reported to France Presse (AFP).
"We believe that, fundamentally, they intend to decapitate the government and install their own governance regime, which would explain this initial advance towards Kiev", he added.
A senior Western intelligence official stressed that Ukraine's "air defenses are currently unusable and unable to defend themselves."
Russia now has "complete air superiority" over Ukraine, according to this source.
"The Russians will seek, in the next few hours, to gather an overwhelming force around the capital and the defense now falls to ground forces and popular resistance", explained this official.
European intelligence predicts that in a "matter of days, if not tomorrow morning [Friday]" given the pace demonstrated, Russian troops will be surrounding Kiev.
So far, Russia has advanced into Ukrainian territory along three axes: from the south, from Crimea to the city of Kherson, across the Dnieper; by the north, from Belarus to Kiev¬†and along two routes to the northeast and northwest of the Ukrainian capital; and east from the Russian city of Belgorod to the main industrial city of Kharkiv, according to Pentagon estimates.
The US Department of Defense pointed out that the Russians have attacked with short-range ballistic missiles, but also medium-range and cruise missiles.
"They also dropped a lot of paratroopers into Kharkiv and we believe there is still heavy fighting" in this area of ‚Äã‚Äãeastern Ukraine, the same source added.
The attacks have focused on military targets, including air bases and the Ukrainian army command, but the Pentagon says the aim is to take control of key cities, including the capital Kiev.
The Russian military attacked in force to gain control of the Antonov military airport, at the gates of the Ukrainian capital, where fighting seemed to continue at the end of the day, and this infrastructure could become a meeting point for the Russian Army in the siege of Kiev.
"If Moscow manages to control it and maintain air superiority (which is very possible), it can use the airport as an entry point to attack Kiev", Michael Horowitz, security expert at Consultant Le Beck International, had highlighted via the social network Twitter.
Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory in the early hours of Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities.
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, announced at the end of the first day of the invasion that at least 137 Ukrainians had died and 316 had been injured.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Merkel has, in recent days, been the target of much criticism in the German press, which contests the "bitter failure of her benevolent diplomacy" towards Moscow.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. A
Russia has not yet fully taken control of Ukrainian airspace, the senior US official said.
"Ukraine's air defense is still active, although it has been damaged by Russian air strikes. (...) They still have anti-missile defense and (...) they still have planes that deny access (to Ukrainian airspace) to Russian planes," the same source reported.
Furthermore, the Ukrainian army's "command and control" capabilities, which allow it to coordinate military operations at the highest level, "are intact," the Pentagon official noted.
"We believe that in the last 24 hours the Russians have lost some of their momentum," the senior official said, explaining that the Russian military has encountered "more resistance than they expected."
However, the Pentagon official highlighted that Russia deployed to Ukraine only a third of the forces it accumulated in recent weeks on the country's borders and that Moscow's objective of taking Kiev to install a pro-Russian regime has not changed.
"The situation could change. It could change very quickly. They have a lot of firepower at their disposal," said the same source.
So far, Russia has advanced into Ukrainian territory along three axes: in the south of Crimea to the city of Kherson, across the Dnieper; in northern Belarus to Kiev, along two routes to the northeast and northwest of the Ukrainian capital; and in the east from the Russian city of Belgorod to the main industrial city of Kharkiv, according to Pentagon estimates.
Although Russian forces have reached the outskirts of Kiev, they have not yet reached the city center.
The city of Kharkiv has also not yet fallen to the Russian army and heavy fighting continues in that area, the Pentagon official said.
To the south, the offensive against Kherson continues, but has expanded to the west, with the landing of several thousand Russian soldiers in the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãAzov and the Black Sea, towards the city of Mariupol, according to the Pentagon.
Today, Russian Marine infantry units launched an offensive west of the city of Mariupol on the shores of the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãAzov in the breakaway region of Donetsk, the Pentagon source said, referring to an "amphibious assault" with thousands of marines.
Russian forces are also trying to take control of a major factory in Kakhovka, northwest of Kherson, where fighting continues.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Russia is facing more resistance than expected
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
18:51
0
Comments
The Russian offensive in Ukraine "lost momentum" in the last 24 hours, faced with "greater" resistance from the Ukrainian military than Moscow expected, a senior Pentagon official said today.
Russia has not yet fully taken control of Ukrainian airspace, the senior US official said.
"Ukraine's air defense is still active, although it has been damaged by Russian air strikes. (...) They still have anti-missile defense and (...) they still have planes that deny access (to Ukrainian airspace) to Russian planes," the same source reported.
Furthermore, the Ukrainian army's "command and control" capabilities, which allow it to coordinate military operations at the highest level, "are intact," the Pentagon official noted.
"We believe that in the last 24 hours the Russians have lost some of their momentum," the senior official said, explaining that the Russian military has encountered "more resistance than they expected."
However, the Pentagon official highlighted that Russia deployed to Ukraine only a third of the forces it accumulated in recent weeks on the country's borders and that Moscow's objective of taking Kiev to install a pro-Russian regime has not changed.
"The situation could change. It could change very quickly. They have a lot of firepower at their disposal," said the same source.
So far, Russia has advanced into Ukrainian territory along three axes: in the south of Crimea to the city of Kherson, across the Dnieper; in northern Belarus to Kiev, along two routes to the northeast and northwest of the Ukrainian capital; and in the east from the Russian city of Belgorod to the main industrial city of Kharkiv, according to Pentagon estimates.
Although Russian forces have reached the outskirts of Kiev, they have not yet reached the city center.
The city of Kharkiv has also not yet fallen to the Russian army and heavy fighting continues in that area, the Pentagon official said.
To the south, the offensive against Kherson continues, but has expanded to the west, with the landing of several thousand Russian soldiers in the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãAzov and the Black Sea, towards the city of Mariupol, according to the Pentagon.
Today, Russian Marine infantry units launched an offensive west of the city of Mariupol on the shores of the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãAzov in the breakaway region of Donetsk, the Pentagon source said, referring to an "amphibious assault" with thousands of marines.
Russian forces are also trying to take control of a major factory in Kakhovka, northwest of Kherson, where fighting continues.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Boris Johnson promises to increase aid
Feb 25, 2022
09:29
0
Comments
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledged to increase British support for Ukraine during a phone call this morning to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky following the attacks on the capital Kiev.
Boris Johnson assured him that "the world is united in horror at what [Russian President Vladimir] Putin is doing" and paid "tribute to the bravery and heroism of the Ukrainian people in facing Russia's campaign of violence", said a spokesman.
"The Prime Minister has committed to providing further UK support to Ukraine in the coming days," without specifying the nature of the aid, according to a Downing Street spokesperson.
Since Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014, the UK has trained more than 22,000 Ukrainian military personnel and supplied defense military equipment worth ¬£2.2 million (‚Ç¨2.63 million) to Ukraine, recently sending 2,000 anti-tank missiles.
On Thursday, Boris Johnson presented a new package of sanctions in Parliament that includes freezing the assets of the main Russian banks, preventing Russian companies from accessing financing and banning the airline Aeroflot from British territory.
In total, more than a hundred people, entities and citizens are affected, including directors of Russian state companies.
The Home Office also announced an extension of work, student or family visit visas in the United Kingdom to Ukrainian citizens, as well as the facilitation of visas for family members of British residents of Ukraine who want to leave the country.

translated_text:
Home
Covers
25 FEB 2022
The hot war
The direction
25¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†01:08
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
Opinion
Editorial
The unease between Russia and Ukraine has a long history, having been intensified by Ukraine's intention to join NATO - and reconfirmed on February 14 this year by the Ukrainian ambassador to the United Kingdom - an organization that Russia considers hostile. About a decade ago, when Ukrainians expressed their desire to move closer to the European Union, with Moscow pushing for this not to happen, this tension was reborn.
The relationship between the two nations has developed in a rotten peace, especially after the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the pro-Russian separatist uprisings in eastern Ukraine. Putin never fully digested the Westernization intention of Kiev's rulers and Europe never accepted the automatism of considering certain regions destined for Russian influence. In a kind of geographical buffer position, Ukraine managed its way, between the opportunities and threats of its neighbors.
Now the world froze in disbelief. We are facing an armed conflict that arrived without official announcements, without the traditional declaration of war, without sirens ringing. Step by step, Putin's regime advanced with soldiers towards the border areas and laughed in front of Western civilization which, successively, began to believe that everything was nothing more than a military exercise or a show of force.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Step by step, Putin intelligently moved the pieces in a dangerous and tactical chess game, right under the noses of all people and international organizations. Each piece that has moved across the board in recent times represented a critical stance taken in Ukraine. First, it was the provinces of Donetsk and Lugansk, whose independence was recognized by Vladimir Putin, and now no one stops the new tsar.
In February 2022, we saw the forced Russification of Ukraine. The Russian attack began with explosions in several cities, with deaths reported, including five who were on board a military plane that crashed near Kiev, the capital. Russia also advanced on the old Chernobyl nuclear power plant. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called this advance "a declaration of war on Europe." While the world reacts and decides on sanctions, none of which have immediate effects - unless they act on the SWIFT financial transfer system, blocking it as expected -, Putin is gaining ground. Zelensky imposed martial law across the country. He decreed the mobilization of all people old enough to serve in the army.
Yesterday went down in history that will be taught to our children and grandchildren and who will ask: why did the war start anyway? If the cold war was marked by tension around the United States-Soviet Union polarization, in the current hot war extremes went from words to weapons, placing Europe, once again, at the center of the war hurricane.
After a violent pandemic that ravaged humanity for two years, no one will be immune to the Russia-Ukraine military conflict. This act of aggression could, in the long term, threaten the territorial integrity of Europe if it extends to other regions, as well as causing a strong shock to the economy and the democratic regimes that we know and in which we live. Despite Kiev being 4095 kilometers from Lisbon, no one will be immune to this war. The consequences will reach Portugal mainly for economic reasons, including the instability of financial markets, rising inflation, rising interest rates and an unprecedented rise in energy prices. If we already risked dealing with a perfect storm, now it will be more than perfect.

Home

Merkel condemns war that marks rupture in Europe
Former German Chancellor says the "war of aggression" waged by Russia against Ukraine marks a "profound rupture in the history of Europe".
¬©¬†Markus Schreiber / POOL / AFP
DN/Lusa
25¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†12:18
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
War in Ukraine
Ukraine
International
Angela Merkel
Related
war in ukraine
Zelensky vs Putin. The face-to-face between the "clown" and the spy
international
There are explosions in the western part of the city of Kiev. Population receives weapons (see video)
war in ukraine
Ukrainian president regrets that European response is "slow"
Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel this Friday condemned the "war of aggression" waged by Russia against Ukraine, which marks a "profound rupture in the history of Europe".
"It is with the greatest concern that I follow the development of the situation after the new attack, which follows the one in 2014 (against Crimea), by Russia led by the President, [Vladimir] Putin, against the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine"
, said Merkel, in a statement released this Friday by her services.
"This war of aggression led by Russia marks a profound rupture in the history of Europe after the end of the Cold War"
, considered Angela Merkel, who left power in December after 16 years of leading Germany.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"This flagrant violation of international law has no justification and I condemn it in the strongest terms"
, said Merkel, who, as chancellor, had very close and difficult relations with Vladimir Putin.
Berlin and Moscow have had numerous disputes in recent years, caused by cyberattacks attributed to Russia targeting German institutions, including the Chancellery, to cases of espionage, including the hospitalization in Germany of opponent of the Russian regime Alexei Navalny, victim of a poisoning attributed to Russian services.
The former chancellor, however, tried to maintain close relations with the Kremlin during his four terms, for example by supporting - against all odds - the construction of the German-Russian gas pipeline Nord Stream 2, which is now suspended.
Merkel has, in recent days, been the target of much criticism in the German press, which contests the "bitter failure of her benevolent diplomacy" towards Moscow.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The Russian President explained the "special military operation" in Ukraine with the need to "demilitarize and denazify" his neighbor and said that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, specifying the Kremlin that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
07:19
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/JASON SZENES
The United States and Albania requested a vote in the UN Security Council on Friday on the draft resolution to condemn Russia for the attacks in Ukraine and demand the withdrawal of Russian troops.
As diplomatic sources revealed to France Presse (AFP), the draft resolution is doomed to failure, due to the right of veto that Russia has in the Security Council, as a permanent member.
But for Washington, the use of this veto by the Russians at the UN Security Council, scheduled for 8pm on Friday, will demonstrate "Moscow's isolation" on the international stage.
Voting on a similar text must take place at the United Nations General Assembly, where resolutions are not binding and where the right of veto does not exist among its 193 members.
According to the resolution, released by AFP, the Council would condemn "in the strongest possible terms Russia's aggression" and violations of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity and would demand "that the Russian Federation immediately, completely and unconditionally withdraw its forces".
This scenario already occurred after Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. Moscow vetoed the project in the Security Council, while China abstained and the other 13 members voted in favor.
Then, in the General Assembly, of the 193 members, the draft resolution received 100 votes in favor, with 11 countries voting against and 58 abstaining, while the rest did not participate in the vote.
According to the European diplomatic source, the big difference compared to 2014 is the "magnitude" of the current situation.
"There is a risk of a major conflict, a major war. The worst-case scenario is a kind of military operation, of the Second World War type, which would naturally cause many civilian casualties," warned the diplomat.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Carnegie Hall replaces Russian conductor close to Putin for three concerts
The North American concert hall also announced that Russian pianist Denis Matsuev, who was also scheduled to perform with Valery Gergieve and the orchestra on Friday, will not be present.
Lusa Agency
Text
Feb 25, 2022, 00:30
i
‚ñ≤
The maestro has already supported Putin's other actions against the neighboring country
Artyom Geodakyan/TASS
‚ñ≤
The maestro has already supported Putin's other actions against the neighboring country
Artyom Geodakyan/TASS
Russian conductor Valery Gergiev, known for being close to Vladimir Putin, was replaced from three performances with the Vienna Philharmonic scheduled for the end of this week at Carnegie Hall, this well-known New York concert hall announced this Thursday.
Valery Gergiev was scheduled to conduct the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in three concerts at Carnegie Hall
, starting on Friday, but the maestro has been urged to react to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, due to his recognized close relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Carnegie Hall, which did not explain the reasons for this last-minute change, revealed that
the Russian will be replaced by Canadian conductor Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin
, according to The New York Times.
Although Valery Gergiev has not yet publicly reacted to the Russian invasion of Ukraine,
the maestro has already supported other actions by Putin against the neighboring country
and its appearance in New York was expected to cause strong protests.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
In the statement, the North American theater also announced that
Russian pianist Denis Matsuev, who was also scheduled to perform with Gergiev and the orchestra on Friday, will not be present
.
This pianist is also close to Vladimir Putin and, in 2014,
expressed support for Russia's annexation of Crimea
.
Valery Gergiev has another appearance planned for Carnegie Hall in May, to lead two concerts with the Mariinsky Orchestra, but in the statement released by the concert hall it was not clear whether these performances will continue.
In Italy, the maestro who directed the premiere of Tchaikovsky's opera ‚ÄúThe Queen of Spades‚Äù, on Wednesday, at the Scala in Milan, was invited this Thursday by the Italian theater to speak about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
The director of La Scala, Dominique Meyer, and the mayor of Milan, Giuseppe Sala,
sent a message to the maestro asking him to make a statement calling for a ‚Äúpeaceful solution‚Äù to the Russian-Ukrainian conflict
, a spokesperson for the Milanese theater told France Presse.
If the maestro refuses, his presence in the next performances of ‚ÄúThe Queen of Spades‚Äù, scheduled for March 5th and 13th, could be at risk.
Giuseppe Sala, who is also president of the board of directors of La Scala, warned this Thursday, in a public debate in Milan, that, if there is no response, ‚Äú
another conductor can be found
‚Äù for the next opera performances.
Valery Gergiev, 68, is the general director of the prestigious Mariinsky Theater in Saint Petersburg and is considered one of the most respected conductors in the world.
His closeness to Putin, whom he has known since 1992, his statements about the annexation of Crimea or the ‚ÄúPussy Riot‚Äù, his concerts in bombed-out South Ossetia and in Palmyra, alongside the Syrian army, have earned him much contestation and controversy over the last decade.
Interviewed by France Presse, in Paris, in 2018, Gergiev said he did not want to talk about politics, but welcomed the re-election for a new term of Putin, with whom he said he met ‚Äúfive to six times a year‚Äù.
‚ÄúHe won the elections, something that the Western world has difficulty understanding,‚Äù he added at the time.
Russia launched this Thursday morning a
military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities
, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
The Russian President,
Vladimir Putin said the ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine aims to ‚Äúdemilitarize and denazify‚Äù its neighbor
and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its ‚Äúresults‚Äù and ‚Äúrelevance‚Äù.
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

"The Prime Minister has committed to providing further UK support to Ukraine in the coming days," without specifying the nature of the aid, according to a Downing Street spokesperson.

In total, more than a hundred people, entities and citizens are affected, including directors of Russian state companies.
The Home Office also announced an extension of work, student or family visit visas in the United Kingdom to Ukrainian citizens, as well as the facilitation of visas for family members of British residents of Ukraine who want to leave the country.
In the early hours of Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Russian advance on three fronts to decapitate government
With total air superiority and control of an airport near the capital, the capture of Kiev could be hours away. Putin claims he does so to prevent ‚Äúgenocide.‚Äù
Family members mourn a victim of Russian bombing in Chuguiv, eastern Ukraine.
¬©¬†ARIS MESSINIS/AFP
Caesar Grandma
24¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†23:36
Facebook

Topics
War in Ukraine
Vladimir Putin
invasion

Related
Russia
Putin says invasion of Ukraine was the only solution
ukraine
Zelensky decrees general mobilization of the population. Says country was left "alone" fighting Russia
international
NATO accuses Russia of having destroyed peace in Europe and says its presence in the east is "to prevent conflict"
In Odessa, the city attacked by the Russians on Thursday, there is a monument of a chair. It is a tribute to the writers Ili√° Ilf and Evgu√©ni Petrov, natives of that city bathed by the Black Sea. The satire on the Soviet Union painted by both
The Twelve Chairs
It passed censorship at the time, in 1928, and was a tremendous sales success. "Where would you go? There's no reason to rush. The GPU [predecessor of the KGB] will find you" is one of the often quoted phrases of the book's swindler protagonist. At this moment, however, it will be difficult for Ukrainians to find a sense of humor in the fact that a former KGB operative, Vladimir Putin, has planned and is executing an invasion of their country, leaving a trail of destruction and despair, with many ignoring that phrase and trying to escape a military power that Ukrainian forces will never be able to sustain, given the difference in forces.
At the end of the afternoon, Moscow said that its military had achieved the objectives set for the first day of its invasion of Ukraine, despite all the sanctions announced and others envisaged by the United States, European Union, Japan, South Korea, Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom. "All tasks assigned to groups of troops of the armed forces of the Russian Federation for this day were completed successfully," said Defense Ministry spokesman Igor Konashenkov. The "success" involved the destruction of more than 70 military targets, including 11 airfields.
Hours earlier, in the early hours of the morning, Vladimir Putin addressed citizens in a television message and said that he would launch a "special military operation" in eastern Ukraine with the aim of "defending" the citizens of the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk from a "genocide of millions of people" and that he would "denazify" and "demilitarize" Ukraine. He stated that preventing NATO from expanding into that territory "is a matter of life and death, a matter for the "historical future of the nation", although he declared that it is not the objective to occupy the country.
Close

and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
After referring to the power of the nuclear arsenal, the Russian leader warned other countries against "the temptation of meddling" and said the response would "lead to consequences that you have never encountered in your history."
Minutes later, the invasion of Ukraine began and not just the east of the country, as Putin had said. Nor was it limited to Ukrainian military infrastructure, as Moscow claimed. It was six in the morning when the first explosions went off in a dozen cities in the east, northeast, as well as in the capital, Kiev. The Russian air strikes, with the launch of around 100 missile launches in the first two hours, in addition to raids by 75 bombers, hit military installations, but also residential areas across the country. Meanwhile, ground forces began to move from the north - through Belarus - on the way to Kiev, to the south - through Crimea -, advancing in all directions, and to the east, from Russian territory, forcing Ukrainians to flee their homes to the sound of sirens and shelling.
Ukraine was the target of cyberattacks hours before the invasion. Hours later, Russian government websites were hit. Joe Biden could bet on cyberwar.
Columns of tanks and armored vehicles rolled across Ukraine from all three fronts. Coming from the north, the invading forces took over the area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, "after a fierce battle", according to an adviser to the Ukrainian president, while fighter jets, airborne troops and dozens of helicopters attacked and took over the Gostomel cargo airport, on the outskirts of Kiev. Several analysts believe that this clue could play a crucial role in plans to take over the capital.
Decapitate the government
Russia is mustering an "overwhelming force" to take the capital, potentially within days, Western sources have warned. For Fran√ßois Heisbourg, from the Foundation for Strategic Research (FRS), "with Russia in total control of the skies, the Ukrainians are in an impossible military situation."
According to the Pentagon - which in this dossier has shown accuracy in its assessments - the Russian invasion of Ukraine aims to take the capital and remove the country's leadership, with troops advancing on three fronts supported by aerial bombardment. The initial phase is focused on major cities, and the Pentagon expects the Russians to advance on Kiev. "They have every intention of basically decapitating the government and installing their own means of governance," said a senior Pentagon official. "We haven't seen a conventional movement like this, from nation to nation, since World War II, certainly nothing of this size, scope and scale."
A French official, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said that in the coming hours airborne troops and large-scale maneuvers coming from the three fronts will continue to take territory and surround the majority of Ukrainian forces. Russia is "on course to occupy all of Ukraine", predicts the Frenchman.
With at least 150,000 soldiers in the region, Moscow will want to resolve the war it has started as quickly as possible. The panorama is of "a rapid Russian military campaign that seeks to quickly displace, surround and destroy Ukrainian forces in a multi-pronged assault", Franz-Stefan Gady, researcher at the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) told AFP.
At around 8pm in Lisbon, Ukrainian Health Minister Viktor Lyashko took stock of the first hours of the invasion: 57 dead and 169 injured, revising downwards the AFP agency's toll of 68 dead, including soldiers and civilians. Conversely, Ukrainian authorities announced that "50 occupants" had died. They also claim to have shot down six Russian military planes and a helicopter. And Ambassador to the United States Oksana Markarova reported the arrest of an entire platoon of the 74th motorized artillery brigade. Furthermore, the Russian Ministry of Defense reported the crash of a military transport plane, which resulted in the death of all Russian passengers, an unspecified number.
Cyberattacks and protests
If a few hours before sending troops to the territory of the neighboring country, Moscow attacked the websites of several Ukrainian banks and government agencies (disabled by so-called denial of service attacks, DDoS), apparently the Russians were victims of the same weapon on Thursday, with a series of government websites, including the Kremlin and the Duma down.
According to NBC, the US president held a meeting with experts about the possibility of carrying out a cyber attack. According to the sources heard, the plans are designed to disrupt but not to destroy, and cannot be classified as an act of war by the United States against Russia. "Our response will be tough and measured, but not so severe as to encourage Putin to take more drastic measures," said a US official. Joe Biden has not yet decided whether to proceed with such an attack, which could involve sabotaging Internet connections in Russia, causing an electrical blackout, or forcing the rail system to stop to delay the country's refueling capacity.
Russia didn't just come with tanks and soldiers and threatening speeches. Thousands of people demonstrated in several cities against the autocrat and his decision to launch an invasion. "No to war", shouted some of the hundreds of people on the streets of Moscow who gathered despite the police's attempt to repress. According to data from the non-governmental organization OVD-Info, 1,300 people were arrested.
Chronology
Troop movement
Washington reports unusual Russian troop movements near the Ukrainian border on November 10. On November 28, Ukraine says Russia is amassing nearly 92,000 troops for an offensive in late January or early February. Moscow not only denies but also accuses Kiev of what was accused, demanding "legal guarantees" that it will never join NATO.
Moscow's demands
On December 7, the US president threatened his Russian counterpart with "strong economic and other measures" if he invaded Ukraine. Ten days later, Moscow presents proposals to limit US and NATO influence over former Soviet and Iron Curtain states.
Military maneuvers
Russian troops begin arriving in Belarus on January 17 for military exercises, which, according to Moscow, aim to "prevent external aggression". The maneuvers begin on February 10th and are 10 days of military maneuvers, after Russia carries out others in the south of the country and in the annexed Crimea.
Allies respond
NATO puts troops on alert and sends ships and fighters to reinforce Europe's eastern defenses on January 24th. Two days later, Washington and Brussels respond to Moscow's demands, which they consider "unrealistic", and call for dialogue.
False start
Moscow says some of its forces are returning to bases on February 15. But NATO sees no signs of withdrawal and Washington claims that Russia is, in fact, sending reinforcements. Two days later, violence flared up on the front line in the Ukrainian regions supported by Russia and the head of US diplomacy accused the Russians of "false provocations" to justify military action.
Failed diplomacy
On the 19th, the same day that Ukrainian President Zelensky proposes a meeting with Putin, which he rejects, the US says that Russia is "on the verge" of invading Ukraine. A summit announced by Frenchman Macron two days later between Putin and Biden also remains on the drawing board.
Putin shows the game
On Tuesday, after the Duma approved a motion to that effect, Putin recognized Donetsk and Lugansk as independent. Later he orders troops to enter eastern Ukraine on a "peacekeeping" mission.
"Special military operation"
While the United Nations Security Council debates the Russian threat, in a body currently chaired by Moscow, Putin announces in a TV speech a "special military operation" in Ukraine that aims at the "demilitarization" of that country, but not its occupation, he declares, in the face of widespread international condemnation.

War in Ukraine
Russian advance on three fronts to decapitate government
With total air superiority and control of an airport near the capital, the capture of Kiev could be hours away. Putin claims he does so to prevent ‚Äúgenocide.‚Äù
Family members mourn a victim of Russian bombing in Chuguiv, eastern Ukraine.
¬©¬†ARIS MESSINIS/AFP
C√©sar Av√≥/Di√°rio de Not√≠cias
25¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†07:09
Share
this article

Share
Comment
In Odessa, the city attacked by the Russians on Thursday, there is a monument of a chair. It is a tribute to the writers Ili√° Ilf and Evgu√©ni Petrov, natives of that city bathed by the Black Sea. The satire on the Soviet Union painted by both
The Twelve Chairs
It passed censorship at the time, in 1928, and was a tremendous sales success. "Where would you go? There's no reason to rush. The GPU [predecessor of the KGB] will find you" is one of the often quoted phrases of the book's swindler protagonist. At this moment, however, it will be difficult for Ukrainians to find a sense of humor in the fact that a former KGB operative, Vladimir Putin, has planned and is executing an invasion of their country, leaving a trail of destruction and despair, with many ignoring that phrase and trying to escape a military power that Ukrainian forces will never be able to sustain, given the difference in forces.
At the end of the afternoon, Moscow said that its military had achieved the objectives set for the first day of its invasion of Ukraine, despite all the sanctions announced and others envisaged by the United States, European Union, Japan, South Korea, Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom. "All tasks assigned to groups of troops of the armed forces of the Russian Federation for this day were completed successfully," said Defense Ministry spokesman Igor Konashenkov. The "success" involved the destruction of more than 70 military targets, including 11 airfields.
Hours earlier, in the early hours of the morning, Vladimir Putin addressed citizens in a television message and said that he would launch a "special military operation" in eastern Ukraine with the aim of "defending" the citizens of the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk from a "genocide of millions of people" and that he would "denazify" and "demilitarize" Ukraine. He stated that preventing NATO from expanding into that territory "is a matter of life and death, a matter for the "historical future of the nation", although he declared that it is not the objective to occupy the country.
After referring to the power of the nuclear arsenal, the Russian leader warned other countries against "the temptation of meddling" and said the response would "lead to consequences that you have never encountered in your history."
Close
Subscribe to newsletter
Subscribe to our newsletter and have the news in your email every day
Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
Minutes later, the invasion of Ukraine began and not just the east of the country, as Putin had said. Nor was it limited to Ukrainian military infrastructure, as Moscow claimed. It was six in the morning when the first explosions went off in a dozen cities in the east, northeast, as well as in the capital, Kiev. The Russian air strikes, with the launch of around 100 missile launches in the first two hours, in addition to raids by 75 bombers, hit military installations, but also residential areas across the country. Meanwhile, ground forces began to move from the north - through Belarus - on the way to Kiev, to the south - through Crimea -, advancing in all directions, and to the east, from Russian territory, forcing Ukrainians to flee their homes to the sound of sirens and shelling.
Ukraine was the target of cyberattacks hours before the invasion. Hours later, Russian government websites were hit. Joe Biden could bet on cyberwar.
Columns of tanks and armored vehicles rolled across Ukraine from all three fronts. Coming from the north, the invading forces took over the area of the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, "after a fierce battle", according to an adviser to the Ukrainian president, while fighter jets, airborne troops and dozens of helicopters attacked and took over the Gostomel cargo airport, on the outskirts of Kiev. Several analysts believe that this clue could play a crucial role in plans to take over the capital.
Decapitate the government
Russia is mustering an "overwhelming force" to take the capital, potentially within days, Western sources have warned. For Fran√ßois Heisbourg, from the Foundation for Strategic Research (FRS), "with Russia in total control of the skies, the Ukrainians are in an impossible military situation."
According to the Pentagon - which in this dossier has shown accuracy in its assessments - the Russian invasion of Ukraine aims to take the capital and remove the country's leadership, with troops advancing on three fronts supported by aerial bombardment. The initial phase is focused on major cities, and the Pentagon expects the Russians to advance on Kiev. "They have every intention of basically decapitating the government and installing their own means of governance," said a senior Pentagon official. "We haven't seen a conventional movement like this, from nation to nation, since World War II, certainly nothing of this size, scope and scale."
A French official, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said that in the coming hours airborne troops and large-scale maneuvers coming from the three fronts will continue to take territory and surround the majority of Ukrainian forces. Russia is "on course to occupy all of Ukraine", predicts the Frenchman.
With at least 150,000 soldiers in the region, Moscow will want to resolve the war it has started as quickly as possible. The panorama is of "a rapid Russian military campaign that seeks to quickly displace, surround and destroy Ukrainian forces in a multi-pronged assault", Franz-Stefan Gady, researcher at the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) told AFP.
At around 8pm in Lisbon, Ukrainian Health Minister Viktor Lyashko took stock of the first hours of the invasion: 57 dead and 169 injured, revising downwards the AFP agency's toll of 68 dead, including soldiers and civilians. Conversely, Ukrainian authorities announced that "50 occupants" had died. They also claim to have shot down six Russian military planes and a helicopter. And Ambassador to the United States Oksana Markarova reported the arrest of an entire platoon of the 74th motorized artillery brigade. Furthermore, the Russian Ministry of Defense reported the crash of a military transport plane, which resulted in the death of all Russian passengers, an unspecified number.
Cyberattacks and protests
If a few hours before sending troops to the territory of the neighboring country, Moscow attacked the websites of several Ukrainian banks and government agencies (disabled by so-called denial of service attacks, DDoS), apparently the Russians were victims of the same weapon on Thursday, with a series of government websites, including the Kremlin and the Duma down.
According to NBC, the US president held a meeting with experts about the possibility of carrying out a cyber attack. According to the sources heard, the plans are designed to disrupt but not to destroy, and cannot be classified as an act of war by the United States against Russia. "Our response will be tough and measured, but not so severe as to encourage Putin to take more drastic measures," said a US official. Joe Biden has not yet decided whether to proceed with such an attack, which could involve sabotaging Internet connections in Russia, causing an electrical blackout, or forcing the rail system to stop to delay the country's refueling capacity.
Russia didn't just come with tanks and soldiers and threatening speeches. Thousands of people demonstrated in several cities against the autocrat and his decision to launch an invasion. "No to war", shouted some of the hundreds of people on the streets of Moscow who gathered despite the police's attempt to repress. According to data from the non-governmental organization OVD-Info, 1,300 people were arrested.
Chronology
Troop movement
Washington reports unusual Russian troop movements near the Ukrainian border on November 10. On November 28, Ukraine says Russia is amassing nearly 92,000 troops for an offensive in late January or early February. Moscow not only denies but also accuses Kiev of what was accused, demanding "legal guarantees" that it will never join NATO.
Moscow's demands
On December 7, the US president threatened his Russian counterpart with "strong economic and other measures" if he invaded Ukraine. Ten days later, Moscow presents proposals to limit US and NATO influence over former Soviet and Iron Curtain states.
Military maneuvers
Russian troops begin arriving in Belarus on January 17 for military exercises, which, according to Moscow, aim to "prevent external aggression". The maneuvers begin on February 10th and are 10 days of military maneuvers, after Russia carries out others in the south of the country and in the annexed Crimea.
Allies respond
NATO puts troops on alert and sends ships and fighters to reinforce Europe's eastern defenses on January 24th. Two days later, Washington and Brussels respond to Moscow's demands, which they consider "unrealistic", and call for dialogue.
False start
Moscow says some of its forces are returning to bases on February 15. But NATO sees no signs of withdrawal and Washington claims that Russia is, in fact, sending reinforcements. Two days later, violence flared up on the front line in the Ukrainian regions supported by Russia and the head of US diplomacy accused the Russians of "false provocations" to justify military action.
Failed diplomacy
On the 19th, the same day that Ukrainian President Zelensky proposes a meeting with Putin, which he rejects, the US says that Russia is "on the verge" of invading Ukraine. A summit announced by Frenchman Macron two days later between Putin and Biden also remains on the drawing board.
Putin shows the game
On Tuesday, after the Duma approved a motion to that effect, Putin recognized Donetsk and Lugansk as independent. Later he orders troops to enter eastern Ukraine on a "peacekeeping" mission.
"Special military operation"
While the United Nations Security Council debates the Russian threat, in a body currently chaired by Moscow, Putin announces in a TV speech a "special military operation" in Ukraine that aims at the "demilitarization" of that country, but not its occupation, he declares, in the face of widespread international condemnation.

According to diplomatic sources revealed to France Presse (AFP), the draft resolution is doomed to failure, due to the right of veto that Russia has in the Security Council, as a permanent member.
But for Washington, the use of this veto by the Russians at the UN Security Council, scheduled for 8pm on Friday, will demonstrate "Moscow's isolation" on the international stage.
Voting on a similar text must take place at the United Nations General Assembly, where resolutions are not binding and where the right of veto does not exist among its 193 members.
According to the resolution, released by AFP, the Council would condemn "in the strongest possible terms Russia's aggression" and violations of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity and would demand "that the Russian Federation immediately, completely and unconditionally withdraw its forces".
This scenario already occurred after Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. Moscow vetoed the project in the Security Council, while China abstained and the other 13 members voted in favor.
Then, in the General Assembly, of the 193 members, the draft resolution received 100 votes in favor, with 11 countries voting against and 58 abstaining, while the rest did not participate in the vote.
According to the European diplomatic source, the big difference compared to 2014 is the "magnitude" of the current situation.
"There is a risk of a major conflict, a major war. The worst-case scenario is a kind of military operation, of the Second World War type, which would naturally cause many civilian casualties," warned the diplomat.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

On the night of Wednesday to Thursday, Canada -- which has the second largest Ukrainian diaspora in the world -- had warned that Russia's "revolting acts" "would not go unpunished."
Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early this morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which Ukrainian authorities say caused dozens of deaths in the first few hours.

translated_text:
O
The Asian country wants to find an "impossible balance by aiming for three objectives: strategic partnership with Russia; defense of long-standing principles of its foreign policy, of 'territorial integrity and non-interference' in the internal affairs of other countries; and the desire to minimize the collateral damage of the sanctions imposed on Moscow", says, in statements to Lusa, the vice-president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace think tank, Evan A. Feigenbaum.
Feigenbaum, who supervises the group's research centers in Washington, Beijing and New Delhi, considers that China "will have to give up one or two principles", given the "impossibility of reconciling" "contradictory" objectives, or else "changing its position, day after day, in the face of international scrutiny".
"China's almost certain choice will be to abandon its principles while prioritizing practical considerations," he predicts.
For now, the analyst observes the lack of definition in the Chinese position as a contrast, compared to similar situations that occurred in the past.
In 2008, when Russia invaded Georgia and recognized two territories -- Abkhazia and South Ossetia -- as "independent" states, Beijing openly expressed "concern" about Russian actions.
Six years later, when Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula, Beijing sought to maintain some flexibility by abstaining from key United Nations resolutions and avoiding openly supporting Moscow's arguments and positions.
"Today, however, Beijing is employing some of Russia's own arguments [about security policy], while pointing the finger at Washington, not Moscow," observes the analyst.
On Thursday, after Russia began its offensive on Ukraine, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, that China "understands Russia's security concerns", but stressed that Beijing "has always respected the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries", according to a transcript released by Chinese diplomacy.
In recent years, China-Russia ties have been strengthened under the command of Chinese President Xi Jinping, who received his counterpart Vladimir Putin in Beijing earlier this month.
Xi and Putin issued a joint statement at the time against NATO enlargement in Eastern Europe. However, Beijing refrained from referring to Ukraine or supporting a military offensive.
China shares with Russia the defense of a new multipolar world order, pointing to the redistribution of power, in opposition to North American hegemony.
Beijing also faces a legally binding North American alliance system in the Indo-Pacific region, which includes Japan, Australia or Taiwan, the island that Beijing claims as its province.
But Russian actions "categorically violate" China's "long-standing" principles on issues of sovereignty, territorial integrity and non-interference, notes Evan A. Feigenbaum.
On Wednesday, Chinese diplomacy spokeswoman Hua Chunying accused the West of creating "fear and panic" with the crisis, and said that the United States was "adding gasoline to the fire" by supplying weapons to Kiev.
"The tilt towards Moscow, especially when compared to 2008, is so notable that, in practice, Beijing will not be able to avoid the perception that it is enabling Russian politics through silence, complicity or even active support", says Feigenbaum.
"By abandoning its principles while falsifying that choice in the fog of cunning diplomatic language, Beijing has made clear that the most decisive element of Chinese [foreign] policy now is its tilt toward Moscow," he concludes.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The War
World
Russia announces "partial restriction" on access to Facebook
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
18:12
0
Comments
Russian authorities today announced a "partial restriction" on access to Facebook, after the American social network limited the accounts of several media supported by the Kremlin, following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Russian communications regulator Rozkomnadzor said today, according to the Associated Press (AP), that it asked Facebook to lift restrictions placed on Thursday on the state news agency RIA Novosti, the state television channel Zvezda and the pro-Kremlin websites loja.ru and gazeta.ru.
The Russian regulatory agency stated that the North American social network, led by Mark Zuckerberg, did not fully restore the accounts of those media outlets.
Account restrictions, according to Rozkomnadzor, included marking their content as not credible and imposing technical restrictions on search results to reduce their Facebook post audiences.
The Russian regulator stated that the "partial restriction" on Facebook takes effect today, without clarifying exactly what this position means.
In its official communication, Rozkomnadzor classified its actions as "measures to protect the Russian press", stating that the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Moscow Prosecutor's Office considered Facebook "complicit in the violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the rights and freedoms of Russian nationals".
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on three fronts in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused more than 120 deaths on Ukrainian territory, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Home
