Russia lost the Champions League final and this is the organizing committee's reaction
Russia lost the Champions League final and this is the organizing committee's reaction
Share
on Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Email
Share
Saint Petersburg lost the Champions League final
Photography:¬†EPA
Share
on Facebook
Writing
25¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†7:12 pm
The decisive game of the competition will be played in Paris.
The organizing committee of the Champions League final, scheduled for Saint Petersburg, regretted the event's move to Paris, justified by UEFA on "security grounds" after Russia's military operation in Ukraine.
Related
Champions League.
Champions League final leaves Russia and will be played in Paris
"We regret the transfer of the 2021/22 Champions League final. The organizing committee and city authorities were ready for this great celebration of football at the highest level for tens of thousands of fans from all over the world", said the entity.
After the 2020 and 2021 finals were relocated, to Lisbon and Porto, respectively, due to the covid-19 pandemic, which prevented them from being held in Istanbul, the challenge that will crown the European champion changes stage again.
"Preparations for the final were underway, all infrastructure and organizational issues were ready. Russia has proven itself to be an impeccable organizer of gigantic international sporting events and a reliable partner for world federations. During several years of preparation for the Champions League final, we met all of UEFA's demands and wishes", reinforced the organization.
This reaction follows that of the Kremlin, which described UEFA's decision as "regrettable", considering that Saint Petersburg "could have offered ideal conditions for holding a football festival".
One day after having "vehemently condemned the military invasion", UEFA met the executive committee to assess the situation in Ukraine, deciding to withdraw Russia from organizing the "Champions" final, scheduled for May 28.
The stadium that would host the final in Saint Petersburg is named after energy giant Gazprom, one of UEFA's main sponsors since 2012.
Also read
Extra
The war in Ukraine to the minute: Zelensky welcomes Germany's arms shipment
Russian Federation President Vladimir Putin announced on Thursday the start of a military operation in eastern Ukraine, claiming it is intended to protect ethnic Russian civilians in the self-proclaimed breakaway republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, which he recognized as independent on Monday.
The European football governing body also decided today that "clubs and national teams from Russia and Ukraine will play their home games on neutral grounds, until further notice".
In the early hours of Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "opera√ß√£o militar especial" na Ucr√¢nia visa "desmilitarizar e desnazificar" o seu vizinho e que era a √∫nica maneira de o pa√≠s se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durar√° o tempo necess√°rio, dependendo de seus "resultados" e "relev√¢ncia".

translated_text:
O
Retired general Egon Ramms stated today that, in the event of an aggression, the German Army would not be able to defend the country from a hypothetical attack, according to an interview with public television ZDF, cited by the Efe agency.
The Bundeswehr "can currently fulfill the commitments it has with NATO, but not much more than that", said Ramms, who attributed the situation to a lack of funding, a reduction in the size of the army and a lower production of ammunition and spare parts.
The Army Inspector himself, Alfons Mais, expressed himself on Thursday in similar terms and indicated that the Bundeswehr "is more or less without coverage" and added that the options to offer support to the Atlantic alliance are "extremely limited".
The highest-ranking German armed forces officer harshly criticized the policy followed to date towards Russia, and wrote, in a post on the social network Linkedin, that "everyone saw it coming", in relation to the conflict in Ukraine.
"We were unable to make our arguments heard, to draw conclusions from the annexation of Crimea and to put them into practice," he added.
The German parliament's commissioner for the armed forces, Eva H√∂gl, also expressed, on Thursday, doubts regarding the Bundeswehr's preparation for a possible conflict and called for urgent restructuring.
"The cold start capacity is not what it should be", he stated in an interview with Phoenix television and admitted that, regarding the need for remodeling, he did not expect it to "occur so quickly and so brutally".
Eva H√∂gl pointed out as an example that some German soldiers deployed in Lithuania, as part of the NATO combat group, lack clothing against the cold and humidity, something that "is not acceptable in one of the richest countries in the world".
This week, Germany announced that it will increase its contingent of soldiers stationed in the Baltic country - now numbering 850 - and the commissioner did not rule out other states in eastern Europe asking for more military support.
According to the weekly Der Spiegel, Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht is considering giving NATO the deployment of another 150 soldiers and a dozen tanks to the eastern flank, as well as Patriot anti-aircraft defense systems.
This Thursday, after the start of the Russian incursion into Ukraine, Germany implemented the so-called national alarm measures following NATO's decision, which imply that the Bundeswehr will prepare for a deployment as part of the alliance's response forces.
In a statement, the German Ministry of Defense warned that this could mean that military vehicles will move in the coming days and that there will be traffic disruptions on some of the country's roads.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
Sport
Saint Petersburg regrets the loss of organizing the 'Champions' final
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
19:04
0
Comments
The organizing committee of the Champions League final, scheduled for Saint Petersburg, today regretted the move of the event to Paris, justified by UEFA on "security grounds" after Russia's military operation in Ukraine.
"We regret the transfer of the 2021/22 Champions League final. The organizing committee and city authorities were ready for this great celebration of football at the highest level for tens of thousands of fans from all over the world", said the entity.
After the 2020 and 2021 finals were relocated, to Lisbon and Porto, respectively, due to the covid-19 pandemic, which prevented them from being held in Istanbul, the challenge that will crown the European champion changes stage again.
"Preparations for the final were underway, all infrastructure and organizational issues were ready. Russia has proven itself to be an impeccable organizer of gigantic international sporting events and a reliable partner for world federations. During several years of preparation for the Champions League final, we met all of UEFA's demands and wishes", reinforced the organization.
This reaction follows that of the Kremlin, which described UEFA's decision as "regrettable", considering that Saint Petersburg "could have offered ideal conditions for holding a football festival".
One day after having "vehemently condemned the military invasion", UEFA met the executive committee to assess the situation in Ukraine, deciding to withdraw from Russia the organization of the 'Champions' final, scheduled for May 28th.
The stadium that would host the final in Saint Petersburg is named after energy giant Gazprom, one of UEFA's main sponsors since 2012.
The European football governing body also decided today that "clubs and national teams from Russia and Ukraine will play their home games on neutral grounds, until further notice".
In the early hours of Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

A Ucr√¢nia n√£o tencionava tornar-se uma base para invadir a R√∫ssia. Se tentou aderir √† Nato foi porque sabia que s√≥ a obriga√ß√£o de defesa m√∫tua da Alian√ßa Atl√¢ntica poderia dissuadir Putin da invas√£o.
25 fev 2022, 00:20
Tem acesso livre a todos os artigos do Observador por ser nosso assinante.
Porque √© que Putin atacou, apesar da amea√ßa das san√ß√µes ocidentais? Pensem nisto: quando √© que a Alemanha suspendeu a ‚Äúcertifica√ß√£o‚Äù do gasoduto Nord Stream 2? H√° dois dias. Os clientes ocidentais do seu g√°s trataram at√© de aumentar a depend√™ncia energ√©tica em rela√ß√£o √† R√∫ssia. Com este precedente, acham que Putin tinha motivos para levar a s√©rio a ret√≥rica ocidental? As san√ß√µes eram para antes das bombas come√ßarem a cair, n√£o para depois, como explicou o presidente da Ucr√¢nia. Ningu√©m o ouviu.
Percebe-se assim porque √© que a Ucr√¢nia, desde 2014, insistiu na ades√£o √† Nato. N√£o, a Ucr√¢nia tal como a Hungria, a Pol√≥nia ou os pa√≠ses b√°lticos, n√£o tencionava tornar-se uma base para a invas√£o da R√∫ssia. A Ucr√¢nia tentou aderir √† Nato porque sabia que s√≥ a obriga√ß√£o de defesa m√∫tua da Alian√ßa Atl√¢ntica poderia dissuadir Putin de invadir. Em 1994, a Ucr√¢nia renunciou √†s suas armas nucleares. A Nato era a garantia que lhe restava. E por isso mesmo, talvez esta guerra se tenha tornado inevit√°vel no s√°bado passado, quando o presidente ucraniano perguntou mais uma vez aos l√≠deres da Nato se era vi√°vel a entrada na organiza√ß√£o, e estes nada lhe responderam. Putin deve ter pressentido que o presidente americano que entregou Kabul ia tamb√©m entregar Kiev.
Antes de 1989, a Alian√ßa Atl√¢ntica, ou mais exactamente, o compromisso dos EUA de defender os seus aliados na Europa, foi a raz√£o pela qual existiram democracias liberais no continente. Sim, nem todos os membros da Nato eram democracias liberais (como Portugal at√© 1974, ou a Turquia agora), e nem todas as democracias europeias eram membros da Nato (como a Su√©cia): mas sem a press√£o da Nato, nem as democracias teriam prevalecido, nem outros pa√≠ses (como Portugal em 1975) se teriam democratizado. A vontade dos povos de viverem livremente tamb√©m conta? Sem d√∫vida. Mas os h√∫ngaros em 1956 e os checoslovacos em 1968 mostraram essa vontade, e foram esmagados pela R√∫ssia ent√£o comunista. Agora, com uma nova autocracia, a R√∫ssia voltou. A Nato parece o √∫nico limite √† reconstitui√ß√£o do seu imp√©rio. Por isso, a Ucr√¢nia a procurou. A porta devia-lhe ter sido aberta. Ora, todos esses partidos ‚Äì o PSD, o CDS, a IL, o Chega ‚Äî est√£o do lado certo na quest√£o fundamental. Talvez seja √≥bvia agora a suja distrac√ß√£o que, √† conta do fantasma da ‚Äúradicaliza√ß√£o da direita‚Äù, foram as ‚Äúlinhas vermelhas‚Äù, as ‚Äúcercas sanit√°rias‚Äù e ainda os ‚Äúmanifestos clarificadores‚Äù dos inevit√°veis idiotas √∫teis. A fronteira da liberdade est√° onde sempre esteve. √â pena ter sido preciso o assassinato de um pa√≠s e de uma democracia para alguns perceberem.

translated_text:
Rui Ramos
Follow
√ó
Follow Rui Ramos and receive an alert as soon as a new article is published.
Observer columnist
Red lines in Ukraine and¬†Portugal
Ukraine did not intend to become a base for invading Russia. If he tried to join Nato it was because he knew that only the Atlantic Alliance's mutual defense obligation could dissuade Putin from the invasion.
25 Feb 2022, 00:20
You have free access to all Observador articles by being our subscriber.
Why did Putin attack despite the threat of Western sanctions? Think about this: when did Germany suspend the ‚Äúcertification‚Äù of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline? Two days ago. And when did Putin annex Crimea? Eight years ago. Putin began the occupation of Ukraine in 2014. What happened to him? Western customers of their gas even tried to increase their energy dependence on Russia. With this precedent, do you think Putin had reason to take Western rhetoric seriously? The sanctions were for before the bombs started falling, not after, as the president of Ukraine explained. Nobody heard him.
This explains why Ukraine, since 2014, insisted on joining Nato. No, Ukraine, like Hungary, Poland or the Baltic countries, did not intend to become a base for an invasion of Russia. Ukraine tried to join NATO because it knew that only the Atlantic Alliance's mutual defense obligation could dissuade Putin from invading. In 1994, Ukraine renounced its nuclear weapons. Nato was his remaining guarantee. And for that reason, perhaps this war became inevitable last Saturday, when the Ukrainian president once again asked Nato leaders if it was viable to join the organization, and they gave him no answer. Putin must have sensed that the American president who handed over Kabul was also going to hand over Kiev.
Before 1989, the Atlantic Alliance, or more accurately, the US commitment to defend its allies in Europe, was the reason liberal democracies existed on the continent. Yes, not all Nato members were liberal democracies (like Portugal until 1974, or Turkey now), and not all European democracies were Nato members (like Sweden): but without Nato pressure, neither democracies would have prevailed, nor other countries (like Portugal in 1975) would have democratized. Does the will of people to live freely also count? Undoubtedly. But the Hungarians in 1956 and the Czechoslovakians in 1968 showed this will, and were crushed by then communist Russia. Now, with a new autocracy, Russia has returned. Nato seems the only limit to the reconstitution of his empire. That's why Ukraine reached out to her. The door should have been opened for him. It wasn't because Ukraine wanted to join NATO that there was war; there is war, because Ukraine did not enter.
The Atlantic Alliance failed Ukraine. Still, it is the main guarantee of liberal democracy in Europe. Therefore, it separates those who, although with different ideologies, support liberal democracy, and those who want another type of regime. In 2015, President Cavaco Silva demanded a written commitment on the Atlantic Alliance and the EU to inaugurate Ant√≥nio Costa. Some people found it strange. I shouldn't have been surprised. In front of Ukraine, PCP and BE were unable to hide what they are: either they support Putin (PCP), or, in a hypocritical variant, they blame Nato (BE). It was to these parties that Ant√≥nio Costa offered influence in the government in Portugal for six years. In fact, he did more: at the same time as he broke down the wall that had separated him from the enemies of liberal democracy on the left, he managed to get the parties on his right to build walls between themselves. Now, all these parties ‚Äì the PSD, the CDS, the IL, Chega ‚Äî are on the right side of the fundamental issue. Perhaps it is obvious now what a dirty distraction, due to the ghost of the ‚Äúradicalization of the right‚Äù, the ‚Äúred lines‚Äù, the ‚Äúsanitary fences‚Äù and even the ‚Äúclarifying manifestos‚Äù of the inevitable useful idiots were. The frontier of freedom is where it has always been. It's a shame that it took the murder of a country and a democracy for some to realize.

O
Russian army invaded Ukraine
during the early hours of Thursday and threatened countries that try to intervene in the conflict with "consequences that have never been seen before."
During the day, Russian President Vladimir Putin justified the "special military operation" with the need to
"demilitarize and denazify" Ukraine
.
The first day of the war in Ukraine was marked by
death of 137 Ukrainians
, according to President Volodymyr Zelensky's latest report.
There are still 316 injured
.
Despite sanctions from several countries around the world against Russia,
Russian forces approach the capital Kiev
and during this morning
several explosions were heard in the area
, caused by anti-aircraft defense fire to repel a Russian missile attack.
Follow the latest developments on the conflict in Ukraine here BY THE MINUTE:

Good afternoon! Here we end another UP-to-the-Minute follow-up of the conflict in Ukraine.

The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, was available to talk and negotiate with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"I would like to address the President of Russia once again. The conflict is raging across Ukraine. Let's sit down at a negotiating table. To stop the killings"
, said Zelensky, according to the newspaper Novaya Gazeta.
According to a Zelensky spokesman, cited by Sky News, Ukraine is open to discussing its neutral status with Russia.

ykhailo Podolyak, advisor to the Ukrainian presidential office, indicated, this Friday morning, what he says is Russia's plan for the invasion carried out in the country. The Russians, according to information revealed by Podolyak, want to "capture Kiev", the capital of Ukraine, and kill President Volodymyr Zelensky, says SkyNews.
The advisor also assured that the Ukrainian head of state is still in Kiev, despite rumors that he has fled the city.
Remember that Zelensky said today that Ukraine is defending itself, lamented that
"The world's most powerful forces are watching from afar"
and maintained that international sanctions are insufficient. "We defend our state alone. The most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar," said Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a speech addressed to the nation, the Ukrainian head of state added: "Did yesterday's sanctions [Thursday] persuade Russia? We feel in our heavens and on our earth that this is not enough."
Ukrainian authorities admitted today that Russian forces are approaching the capital, Kiev.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

Sandra Fernandes, a researcher specializing in International Relations at the University of Minho, spoke to "Jornal de Not√≠cias" about the contours of the Russian invasion of Ukraine and also spoke about the Russians' ability to resist Western sanctions.
The Ukrainian president,
Volodymyr Zelensky
, regretted that the
Ukraine
was left alone to fight the Russians. What can allied countries do in the face of the Russian invasion?
The president of Ukraine finds himself in the worst situation. Not being a state of
NATO
, and having the
USA
and the
European Union
said, since the beginning of the crisis, that they would not directly join the Ukrainian forces to defend the territory of Ukraine... The president
Zelensky
is effectively alone on the front line.
On the ground he is alone, despite the support of his
USA
and from
EU
...
Of course, you are not completely alone, because there is a lot of financial support and defensive equipment has already been delivered. But in fact there is a "trade-off" here that President Putin understood very well - and it is part of what we can understand why he ended up attacking, despite it being a big surprise - it was clear that there would be no armed intervention by allied entities.
From Ukraine's point of view it is a huge disappointment, but at the same time it is a necessity because the alternative is a world war. If there was direct support, we would be facing a world war.
So how can you stop Putin?
This is the big question, given that Westerners have ruled out the possibility of becoming militarily involved in a conflict such as war. I think that at this moment no one can stop Putin in
Ukraine
. We have to see tomorrow, we have to look further and understand how to stop Putin beyond Ukraine.
What could the seizure of Kiev mean: forcing the current Government to fall or is it an attempt to force openness to Russian interests?
The objective is very clear, a change of regime in
Ukraine
. A regime that is not pro-Western and that is not anti-Putin. A war is not exactly a factor of attraction, as Russia's attractiveness is decreasing and is, in fact, one of the counterproductive effects that is expected for Putin.
What could Putin be thinking about invading Kiev?
In a completely taken over Ukraine and in an urban guerrilla scenario, which is what is expected to happen, most Ukrainians will not be in favor of the Russian presence. The change of power is the first step and is fundamental to control all institutions of power, executive, legislative and judicial institutions. It is the first step towards giving Russia medium-term dividends but it will not be easy to control the country.
And what could follow the fall of the Ukrainian capital?
At this moment we are in suspense waiting for a cohesive and strong action that will force Putin to stop. Why did this happen in
Ukraine
, we can glimpse another type of destabilization actions in Belarus itself, which is already a country very aligned with Putin, but could still undergo changes that could transform that state into an even less sovereign state than it already is. And we look at the
Moldova
, for the
South Caucasus
, to South Ossetia and Abkhazia, and we realize that we find ourselves in a very high risk situation, without a doubt. Ukraine had lost Crimea, it had factually lost
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
, Ukraine will now be left without much, if not all, of its territory. The situation is very serious.
PUB
Will Western sanctions be enough to reverse the current war situation?
The sanctions of
EU
They really have to be very strong. They have to be more than a sign, there have to be consequences. As difficult as it is for them to produce an immediate effect, they have to have some kind of effect.
What kind of effects are expected?
The effect has to be on the Economy. There are two levels of effects: the symbolic, which we already know has no impact on Putin, which is to condemn an ‚Äã‚Äãaction. A condemned state is considered a pariah. This effect has been in practice since 2014 and has not worked. The second type includes the material, economic and financial dimension of the effects of sanctions and operates in two dimensions. We are talking about an autocratic and corrupt country. There is an understanding between those in power and those who run the big Russian companies and consortiums, the oligarchs. Sanctions can actually affect those people's portfolios and those people's trading volume. But I think that, in the immediate term, these elites are willing to bear the consequences because they are aligned with Putin. Therefore, despite going into these people's wallets, the sanctions may not have any impact.
What is the other dimension?
Another dimension is to look at the people. Sanctions could have an effect on Russians' daily lives and their ability to buy consumer goods, meat, bread, butter... We do not have widespread public opinion in Russia that supports the military option in Ukraine. If the sanctions affect the day-to-day lives of Russians, eventually what is expected, and once again it is not immediate, is that civil society will begin to pressure the Government for changes. But this will not happen today, tomorrow or in a month. As long as Putin's leadership and his succession are not called into question, the effects of the sanctions can only be expected in the medium term.
The sanctions will not have any immediate effect...
A
Russia
You can also adopt counter-sanctions and, for example, turn off the gas tap. And decide that you will bear the consequences for a certain period of time. It is known that there is a certain Russian capacity because it has a low external debt and has large cash reserves. A
Russia
has the capacity to resist sanctions measures for many months.
Maria Cl√°udia Monteiro

Here are the main points to highlight on this second day of the Russian offensive against Ukraine.
- Several incidents during the night: Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, was hit by

Russian troops surrounded the city

.
- According to a United Nations report,
more than 50 thousand Ukrainians left the country
in 48 hours. And several thousand came out of their homes, looking for
refuge in Kiev metro stations
and other cities, where men, women, elderly people, children and young people gathered to spend the night.
People found shelter in metro stations
Photo:¬†Stringer/EPA
- The Russian Army once again claimed the
control of Antonov military airport
, in Gostomel, on the outskirts of Kiev and the blockade of the Ukrainian capital, isolating the city from the western region.
- After the
Russian troops arrived in Oblon
, a residential area of the capital, where tanks were filmed circulating in the streets,
the Ukrainian Defense Ministry called on citizens to make Molotov cocktails
to "neutralize the enemy".
- Kiev assured that
Ukrainian military is defending the borders on four fronts
, despite being in numerical inferiority, and which are
ready to counterattack
thanks to the weapons provided by the allies.
PUB
- Ukraine's nuclear agency and the country's Parliament revealed that
radiation levels increased
in the area of the extinct Chernobyl nuclear power plant, taken by Russian forces. "Due to the occupation and hostilities, it is currently impossible to establish the causes," Ukrainian authorities said. On the other hand, the Russian Army said that the radiation "is within normal levels" and that the plant's employees remain on site.
Ukrainian military in Kiev
Photo:¬†Mikhail Palinchak/EPA
- Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that the
Kremlin is ready to send a delegation to Minsk
, capital of Belarus (Putin's ally), to talk to a delegation from Ukraine. Kiev responded that it is
"consider the proposal"
. Earlier, an advisor to the Ukrainian presidential office had already told Reuters that the country wants peace and is prepared to talk to Russia.
- On the other hand,
Vladimir Putin called on Ukrainian troops to turn against their own government
: "It seems easier for us to reach an agreement with you [soldiers] than with those drug-addicted neo-Nazis in Kiev." And Sergei Lavrov, Russia's Foreign Minister, assured that "Ukraine will have a new government."
- In a televised address to the nation, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky praised the "heroism" of those resisting the Russian invasion, which he compared to the Nazi offensive in 1941. And
called on Russia to sit at the table with Ukraine to put an end to the fighting
, denouncing that Moscow is also targeting civilian areas. He further accused
Europe reacted slowly
in aid to Kiev and called for more assertive intervention from the continent.
Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukrainian president
Photo:¬†Ukrainian Presidency/AFP
- The European Council gave
green light for more sanctions
to Russia, for the financial, energy, transport, exports and visa policy sectors (which include, for example, members of the Russian National Security Council and Belarusian officials), as well as the cut to deposits above 100 thousand euros in European banks, targeting the Russian elite. The United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, Japan and other countries also came forward with more sanctions.
- The
Council of Europe suspended Russia
"with immediate effect" of their representation rights in the Committee of Ministers and in the Parliamentary Assembly.
- UEFA announced that the
Champions League football final
, which was to be held in Saint Petersburg, Russia, will move to Paris.
O
Formula 1 Grand Prix
in Russia it was also canceled
.
- The well-known hacker group "Anonymous" declared
cyber warfare on the Russian government
: has already attacked the Ministry of Defense website and state television RT News.
Follow all developments on the War in Ukraine here
Rita Salcedas

A
Russia approaches the center of Kiev on the second day of its invasion of Ukraine, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky ensuring that he will not abandon the capital, but admitting that the night will be "very difficult".
NATO announced in the afternoon that it would support Ukrainian troops with anti-aircraft material and warned that Russia does not intend to stop its expansion into Ukraine.
The alliance also announced that it would mobilize, for the first time in its history, the rapid reaction force
However, more than 50,000 Ukrainians have already left the country for border territories, but many choose to stay to fight against the Russian invaders.

translated_text:
The War
World
Putin asks Ukrainian army to seize power in Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
16:05
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Russian President Vladimir Putin today called on the Ukrainian military to "seize power" in Kiev, overthrowing President Volodymyr Zelensky and his team, whom he described as "neo-Nazis" and "drug addicts".
"Take power into your hands. It seems to me that it will be easier to negotiate between you and me", Putin launched at the Ukrainian army in an intervention broadcast on Russian television, stating that he is not fighting army units, but nationalist formations that behave "like terrorists" using civilians "as human shields".
Putin also classified Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his ministers as "a clique of drug addicts and neo-Nazis, who established themselves in Kiev and took the entire Ukrainian people hostage."
Despite Zelensky having Jewish origins, Moscow has called the Ukrainian authorities "neo-Nazis" or "junta" since 2014, when the war began in eastern Ukraine, between pro-Russian separatists and Kiev forces.
The "drug addict" accusations refer to statements made by Zelensky's detractors during the 2019 presidential elections, which the President won by a large margin.
Russia accuses Ukraine of having integrated units close to the extreme right into its armed forces and pointed to the "denazification" of Ukraine as one of the objectives of its invasion.
Putin today accused these¬†units of acting ‚Äúlike terrorists.‚Äù
Ukraine also compared Russia's actions to those of "Nazi Germany" during World War II.
Putin's appeal to the Ukrainian army was made hours after Zelensky called on the Russian President to sit at the negotiating table, an option that the Kremlin did not immediately rule out, but left without a clear response.
On the first day of the Russian invasion, on Thursday, Zelensky¬†denounced that the aim of the attack was to remove him from power.
"According to our information, I am the enemy's number one target. My family is the second [target]. They [the Russians] want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state," he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

15:42

Photo EPA
The Russian Army today claimed control of a strategic airport on the outskirts of the Ukrainian capital and blocked Kiev, isolating it from the western region.
The loss of control of the Antonov military airport, in Gostomel, on the outskirts of Kiev, was recognized on Thursday by the Ukrainian authorities, who claimed its recovery overnight.
Today, the Russian Army stated that it controls this important military airport, with a long runway, capable of landing and lifting heavy transport planes, allowing air troops to be transported directly to the Ukrainian capital area.
Russian Defense Ministry spokesman Major General Igor Konashenkov said today that Russian airborne forces used 200 helicopters for the control operation, considering that this position allows Russian troops to isolate Kiev from the western region of Ukraine.
According to a Russian military report, published on the social network Telegram, Moscow's airborne troops have already joined the forces that took control of Gostomel airport, "ensuring the blockade of Kiev".
The report asserts that, in the capture of that airfield, 35 kilometers northwest of Kiev, "around 200 nationalists from Ukrainian special units" were annihilated, an operation in which Russian forces "suffered no casualties."
During the day on Thursday, the Ukrainian Army announced that fighting was underway for control of the Antonov military airport, following an attack by Russian forces.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
A
Military reform in Russia in 2008 - following the war with Georgia, when the Kremlin decreed a profound change in its military sector - forced significant cuts in Russia's firepower - which had been inherited from the Soviet Union in the Cold War era - forcing the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation to significantly reduce its human contingent and weapons.
In 2012, the number of land military units had been reduced from 1,870 to 172 (a 90% cut) and the air force had a cut of around 50% in its personnel, weakening its geopolitical military position.
Even so, Russia remains one of the most relevant world powers, with a military force much more powerful than that of Ukraine, despite the external aid (in particular from the United States) received by Kiev in recent months.
According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IIEE), Russia has a military budget of between 35 billion and 60 billion euros annually, which allows it to feed a human contingent of around 900,000 active soldiers and around two million reservists.
These numbers compare with around 195,000 soldiers on the Ukrainian side, according to the IIEE, divided between 125,000 ground troops, 35,000 air troops and 15,000 naval troops, in addition to the approximately 900,000 reservists, who have now been called into active duty by President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Ukraine's firepower is essentially concentrated in the Army, which has 2,000 tanks, 1,960 artillery pieces and 2,870 armed vehicles, as well as around 400 air-to-ground missiles and 2,000 anti-tank weapons that were recently supplied by the United Kingdom.
In the air, Ukraine has 146 warplanes, including 69 fighters, and 42 attack helicopters and only 38 active warships, without any aircraft carriers or submarines.
Russia has 280,000 active Army troops, more than 165,000 airborne troops and 150,000 naval personnel.
Russia's firepower is distributed across more than 13,000 war tanks, around 6,000 artillery pieces and 20,000 armed vehicles, in addition to a vast arsenal of missiles (the number of which the Kremlin never disclosed, even during negotiations to expand the disarmament treaty with the United States).
It is known that Russia has dozens more launch bases for ballistic missiles, with nuclear capabilities, the asset that has been reserved as a deterrent until now.
In the air, according to the IIEE, Russia has 4,100 warplanes, including 772 fighters.
At sea is another Russian stronghold, with more than 600 warships, including an aircraft carrier and 70 submarines.
These differences also reflect the territorial differences of the two countries: despite being the two largest countries in Europe, Russia is the country with the largest territory in the world, being 28 times the size of Ukraine.
In terms of population, Ukraine has 44 million people and Russia has 144 million people.
Still, in recent months - faced with the threat of Russian intervention in eastern Ukraine, where pro-Russian separatists received support from Moscow in the fight against government forces - Kiev received strong military aid from the United States and several European countries.
This week, in his speech condemning the Russian invasion, US President Joe Biden recalled the military aid given to Kiev during 2021, of around 650 million dollars (around 600 million euros), to which was added aid of around 200 million dollars (around 180 million euros) in recent weeks, in the midst of the escalation of the crisis.
In recent days, Ukrainian forces have been reinforced with military equipment, from defensive missiles to uniforms, including warplanes, in an effort to provide Kiev with greater resistance to Russian supremacy.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

"We are not on the verge of a Third World War, nor a general war in Europe"
Researcher at the Portuguese Institute of International Relations, advisor to the Institute of National Defense and former Advisor to Presidents Ramalho Eanes, M√°rio Soares and Jorge Sampaio, Carlos Gaspar believes that Russia "wants to put an end to Ukraine as an independent State", but does not foresee the war spreading to other territories. The "security guarantee" of NATO states lies, he emphasizes, in "strategic nuclear weapons".
¬©¬†Orlando Almeida / Global Imagens

How do you assess the relationship of forces between Russia and Ukraine and Russia and NATO?
The military balance between Russia and Ukraine is clearly asymmetric, even without taking the nuclear dimension into account. In recent years, the Russian armed forces have been able to modernize and, despite professionalization efforts since the annexation of Crimea, the Ukrainian armed forces have only a limited ability to oppose Russia's military superiority.
The strategic balance between Russia and NATO is defined by strategic nuclear weapons that guarantee, in the classic formula, an assured capacity for mutual destruction.
The strategic balance between Russia and NATO is defined by strategic nuclear weapons that guarantee, in the classic formula, an assured capacity for mutual destruction. This is the guarantee of the security of NATO allies in the face of Russia's resurgence as a revisionist power, a guarantee that does not include Ukraine, as it is not a member of the Atlantic Alliance.

and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Will it be a quick war or should we expect it to last and spread to other territories?
It is unlikely that the war will spread to other territories, particularly NATO member states. An aggression by Russia against the Baltic Republics, against Poland, Romania or Bulgaria means a nuclear war. Russia is a revisionist power, but it is not suicidal.
Are we on the brink of a third world war? What will count most to avoid it?
We are not on the verge of a third world war, nor of a general war in Europe. The deterrent capacity of strategic nuclear weapons guarantees the containment of Russia and any external power that wants to threaten the transatlantic community.
Is history repeating itself and are we witnessing a "rerun" of what happened to Georgia in 2008? What are the differences and similarities?
The allies did not want to recognize the lessons of the Georgian War, nor the annexation of Crimea, nor the de facto annexation of the Donbass territories occupied by Russian separatists.
Putin also wants to precipitate the political decapitation of the state and force a change of political regime to put an end to Ukraine as an independent state
But in the case of Ukraine, Putin's Russia seems to want to go further than recognizing puppet entities and destroying the armed forces, as it did in Georgia, and also wants to precipitate the political decapitation of the state and force a change of political regime to put an end to Ukraine as an independent state.
What are Russia's main advantages at the moment?
Russia has the advantage of the strategic initiative, although the United States reduced this advantage when President Biden timely reported that Putin was going to invade Ukraine.
Furthermore, Russia is increasingly isolated: Germany has stopped Nord Stream II, the Group of 7, the transatlantic community and the European community are united and even China itself is trying to demarcate itself from Putin's adventurism, even when it does not expressly condemn Russia's aggression against Ukraine.
How has Russia's military power grown compared to that of NATO countries?
Since the Georgian War, Russia has significantly increased its investments in defense and not only continues to be the second largest nuclear power, it has significantly modernized its conventional capabilities and developed important new capabilities, particularly in the cyber domain.
Russia does not have a military capacity comparable to that of the United States and NATO, but it has clear superiority in this critical area compared to China, which is the main threat to its strategic security in the medium term.
However, Russia does not have a military capacity comparable to that of the United States and NATO, but it has clear superiority in this critical area compared to China, which is the main threat to its strategic security in the medium term.
What repercussions can we expect in Portugal? There are those who talk about mass cyber attacks... Would Russia be interested in doing so in Portugal?
Portugal is a member state of NATO and the European Union and, within this framework, is a target of Russia's offensive strategies, like all other allies and partners.

Loss of control of the Antonov military airport, in Gostomel, on the outskirts of Kiev, was recognized on Thursday by the Ukrainian authorities, who claimed its recovery overnight.
Today, the Russian Army stated that it controls this important military airport, with a long runway, capable of landing and lifting heavy transport planes, allowing air troops to be transported directly to the Ukrainian capital area.
Russian Defense Ministry spokesman Major General Igor Konashenkov said today that Russian airborne forces used 200 helicopters for the control operation, considering that this position allows Russian troops to isolate Kiev from the western region of Ukraine.
According to a Russian military report, published on the social network Telegram, Moscow's airborne troops have already joined the forces that took control of Gostomel airport, "ensuring the blockade of Kiev".
The report asserts that, in the capture of that airfield, 35 kilometers northwest of Kiev, "around 200 nationalists from Ukrainian special units" were annihilated, an operation in which Russian forces "suffered no casualties."
During the day on Thursday, the Ukrainian Army announced that fighting was underway for control of the Antonov military airport, following an attack by Russian forces.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Cross profile: Former clown Zelensky and former spy Putin
When in 1991, after the collapse of the USSR, Vladimir Putin resigned from the KGB, Volodymyr Zelensky, aged 13, still only made his classmates laugh. Only four years later would he realize that humor was serious and he would start doing stand-up comedy. He would graduate in Law, just like Putin, but it was political satire that made him famous... and a millionaire. Now they face each other in a conflict in which everyone loses. The report made by journalist Helena Tecedeiro, international affairs journalist at Di√°rio de Not√≠cias.

When Volodymyr Oleksandrovych Zelensky was born, on a cold January day in 1978, into a Jewish family in Kryvyi Rih, in the southeastern metallurgical zone of the then Soviet republic of Ukraine, Vladimir Putin had already joined the KGB, the Soviet secret services, three years ago, after graduating in Law. Zelensky himself would end up being seduced by the study of laws, also graduating in Law at the National University of Economics in Kiev, even though he had already been involved in comedy since he was 17 years old. This will perhaps be one of the few common traits between the men who are now the faces of both sides in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
"April 1st, what a fantastic day to win. After all, I'm a clown!", exclaimed the man who campaigned only as "Ze", in an interview with the newspaper Ukrayinska Pravda in the middle of the campaign for the 2019 presidential elections in Ukraine. In just a few months, the comedian who had gained fame with the television program Servo do Povo, in which he played the role of a professor who accidentally becomes president, managed to imitate in reality the fiction he had represented.
Zelensky celebrates victory in 2019.
¬©¬†Genya SAVILOV / AFP
In a country that had not yet forgotten the events of 2014 - the overthrow of pro-Russian president Viktor Ianukovych due to pro-Western street protests - Zelensky's joking campaign, which refused to discuss serious issues or participate in debates, convinced voters that the president they saw on the screen making jokes with his wife or cycling to work with a panicked face was really the best to occupy the head of state. And they gave him victory, refusing a new mandate to Petro Poroshenko and generating comparisons with the Italian Silvio Berlusconi or the American Donald Trump, other figures from the
show-business
who reached the top in the politics of their countries.
Close
Subscribe to newsletter
Subscribe to our newsletter and have the news in your email every day
Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
Elected with almost three-quarters of the votes, the actor who became an instant politician saw his victory hailed from across the border by Vladimir Putin, who had been at the top of power for more than 20 years - almost always in the presidency, with a short stint as head of government. The Russian president stated that he expected Zelensky to have "common sense", "honesty" and pragmatism" to improve the bilateral relationship. After the pro-Western Poroshenko, Moscow did not take a bad look at the coming to power in Kiev of a young man without any political experience. The former comedian himself had promised to get closer to Russia, while maintaining independence.
Just in case, three days after Zelensky's victory, Putin signed an order to issue Russian passports to hundreds of thousands of residents of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-speaking and partially under the control of Moscow-backed separatists since Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. A step that has now gained new weight, with Putin claiming that the deployment of troops to Ukraine aims in part to protect these citizens Russians.
Read the full report at dn.pt
Obsession since the days of the KGB
To understand Putin's fixation with Ukraine it is necessary to go back to his youth. After all, the president, born Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, now Saint Petersburg, like many Russians of his generation - subjected to the force of Soviet propaganda while growing up - still has the wounds of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the loss of its sphere of influence very fresh.
Putin was in the KGB between 1975 and 1991.
¬©¬†Vladimir Putin/Kremlin personal archive
The son of a veteran seriously injured in World War II, Putin likes to remember that his paternal grandfather, Spiridon Putin, worked as a cook, first for Lenin, the leader of the Bolshevik revolution that overthrew the tsar in 1917, and then for his successor, Stalin, serving the latter at his dacha in the Moscow region.
In the 1980s, while Zelensky followed his family to Erdenet, the Mongolian city where his father, a mining engineer, worked for four years before returning to Ukraine for his son to enter primary school, Putin was rising in the KGB. And it was from Dresden, in communist East Germany, where he was stationed between 1985 and 1990 as a secret agent, that he lived through the last years of the Soviet Union.
Putin himself has said many times how he went through the same difficulties as his companions during the collapse of the USSR, and even recently confessed to having had to work as a taxi driver to pay the bills when he returned to Russia. For many Russians, the years following the dismantling of the Soviet Union were marked by humiliation and poverty - a clear contrast to the triumphalism and prosperity of the West at the time.
Putin has already considered the end of the Soviet Union as "the greatest catastrophe of the 20th century", worse in his opinion than the two world wars. And last Monday, in the speech in which he recognized the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, Putin went back to 1991 to argue that Ukraine is not "a state", having been "stolen" from Russia by the collapse of the Soviet Union. ‚ÄúUkraine has become a huge puppet colony,‚Äù he assured. Before adding that Ukrainians "wasted not only what we gave them during the Soviet Union, but even everything they inherited from the Russian empire. Even the work created by Catherine the Great," he said. And not even Lenin escaped his criticism, with Putin considering him "author and creator" of Ukraine.
Political rise vs. career in humor
Putin with Yeltsin.
¬©¬†AFP
For Putin, the 1990s also meant leaving the KGB and entering politics. After resigning from the secretariat in 1991, following the coup against Mikhail Gorbachev, he began working in the office of the Mayor of Saint Petersburg, where he remained until 1996, when he resigned after losing the elections. It was then that he moved to Moscow. After a brief stint at the Presidential Department of Property Management, President Boris Yeltsin appointed him head of protocol, later being responsible for the regions before being named prime minister on August 9, 1999.
Coming out of his childhood at the collapse of the Soviet Union and the independence of Ukraine, while Putin exchanged his role as a spy for that of a politician, Volodymyr Zelensky began to realize that humor was his future. In 1995, at the age of 17, the man who always made his classmates laugh joined KVN, a local comedian competition, and ended up winning the national edition. With your own team of
stand-up comedy
, Kvartal 95, toured Ukraine, but also Russia and other countries of the former USSR. In 2003, Kvartal 95 became the name of his studio that produced television programs. His specialty: political satire.
Also a film star, it was with the television program Servo do Povo that he gained fame and made a fortune. From criticizing politicians in fiction to criticizing politicians in reality was a step. In March 2019, he confessed in an interview with the German magazine
Der Spiegel
his desire to enter politics to "bring decent and professional people" to power. Once in office, he made oligarchs one of his targets, seeking to move away from the past in which he had worked for one - Ihor Kolomoisky.

"V
ladimir Putin is willing to send a Russian delegation to Minsk, at the level of the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs and elements of the presidential administration, for negotiations with a Ukrainian delegation", announced Dmitri Peskov.
The Russian Presidency spokesman alluded to a recent statement by Volodymyr Zelensky, in which the Ukrainian President said he was willing to discuss the country's neutrality status, which would imply renouncing his aspiration to join NATO.
Russia insists that Kiev's desire to join the Atlantic Alliance is a direct threat to its security, like other NATO expansion plans into post-Soviet territory.
Zelensky returned today to ask Putin to sit at the negotiating table to stop the Russian military operation in Ukraine, which began in the early hours of Thursday.
"I want to address the President of Russia once again. There is fighting throughout Ukraine. We will sit down at the negotiating table to put an end to the death of human beings," he said in a television message.
The Kremlin spokesman also announced today a conversation between Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, who would be willing to "create all the conditions" for the start of negotiations, in Minsk, between Kiev and Moscow, which since Thursday have not had diplomatic relations.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The Russian President said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on the "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with unprecedented sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Putin willing to send delegation to Minsk to negotiate with Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
14:39
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Russian President Vladimir Putin is ready to send a delegation to Minsk, the capital of his ally Belarus, for talks with Ukraine, his spokesman said today, cited by Russian news agencies.
"Vladimir Putin is willing to send a Russian delegation to Minsk, at the level of the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs and elements of the presidential administration, for negotiations with a Ukrainian delegation", announced Dmitri Peskov.
The Russian Presidency spokesman alluded to a recent statement by Volodymyr Zelensky, in which the Ukrainian President said he was willing to discuss the country's neutrality status, which would imply renouncing his aspiration to join NATO.
Russia insists that Kiev's desire to join the Atlantic Alliance is a direct threat to its security, like other NATO expansion plans into post-Soviet territory.
Zelensky returned today to ask Putin to sit at the negotiating table to stop the Russian military operation in Ukraine, which began in the early hours of Thursday.
"I want to address the President of Russia once again. There is fighting throughout Ukraine. We will sit down at the negotiating table to put an end to the death of human beings," he said in a television message.
The Kremlin spokesman also announced today a conversation between Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, who would be willing to "create all the conditions" for the start of negotiations, in Minsk, between Kiev and Moscow, which since Thursday have not had diplomatic relations.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The Russian President said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on the "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with unprecedented sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Russia has military supremacy in all combat areas
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
17:45
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Ukrainian Armed Forces seek to resist Russia's military onslaught, despite a large discrepancy in resources in the military sector between the two countries, which reveals Russian military supremacy in all areas of combat.
The military reform in Russia in 2008 - following the war with Georgia, when the Kremlin decreed a profound change in its military sector - forced significant cuts in Russia's firepower - which had been inherited from the Soviet Union in the Cold War era - forcing the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation to significantly reduce its human contingent and weapons.
In 2012, the number of land military units had been reduced from 1,870 to 172 (a 90% cut) and the air force had a cut of around 50% in its personnel, weakening its geopolitical military position.
Even so, Russia remains one of the most relevant world powers, with a military force much more powerful than that of Ukraine, despite the external aid (in particular from the United States) received by Kiev in recent months.
According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IIEE), Russia has a military budget of between 35 billion and 60 billion euros annually, which allows it to feed a human contingent of around 900,000 active soldiers and around two million reservists.
These numbers compare with around 195,000 soldiers on the Ukrainian side, according to the IIEE, divided between 125,000 ground troops, 35,000 air troops and 15,000 naval troops, in addition to the approximately 900,000 reservists, who have now been called into active duty by President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Ukraine's firepower is essentially concentrated in the Army, which has 2,000 tanks, 1,960 artillery pieces and 2,870 armed vehicles, as well as around 400 air-to-ground missiles and 2,000 anti-tank weapons that were recently supplied by the United Kingdom.
In the air, Ukraine has 146 warplanes, including 69 fighters, and 42 attack helicopters and only 38 active warships, without any aircraft carriers or submarines.
Russia has 280,000 active Army troops, more than 165,000 airborne troops and 150,000 naval personnel.
Russia's firepower is distributed across more than 13,000 war tanks, around 6,000 artillery pieces and 20,000 armed vehicles, in addition to a vast arsenal of missiles (the number of which the Kremlin never disclosed, even during negotiations to expand the disarmament treaty with the United States).
It is known that Russia has dozens more launch bases for ballistic missiles, with nuclear capabilities, the asset that has been reserved as a deterrent until now.
In the air, according to the IIEE, Russia has 4,100 warplanes, including 772 fighters.
At sea is another Russian stronghold, with more than 600 warships, including an aircraft carrier and 70 submarines.
These differences also reflect the territorial differences of the two countries: despite being the two largest countries in Europe, Russia is the country with the largest territory in the world, being 28 times the size of Ukraine.
In terms of population, Ukraine has 44 million people and Russia has 144 million people.
Still, in recent months - faced with the threat of Russian intervention in eastern Ukraine, where pro-Russian separatists received support from Moscow in the fight against government forces - Kiev received strong military aid from the United States and several European countries.
This week, in his speech condemning the Russian invasion, US President Joe Biden recalled the military aid given to Kiev during 2021, of around 650 million dollars (around 600 million euros), to which was added aid of around 200 million dollars (around 180 million euros) in recent weeks, in the midst of the escalation of the crisis.
In recent days, Ukrainian forces have been reinforced with military equipment, from defensive missiles to uniforms, including warplanes, in an effort to provide Kiev with greater resistance to Russian supremacy.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Kiev threatened
Ukraine admits that fighting is getting closer to the capital
Images of the destruction caused by Russian attacks on civilian buildings on the outskirts of Kiev
Photo:¬†GENYA SAVILOV / AFP
25¬†February¬†2022

Fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces is intensifying near the capital of Ukraine, with Ukraine's deputy defense minister admitting the advance of enemy troops near Kiev.
"Enemy occupation of Vorsel and the surrounding villages is possible," wrote Hanna Malyar on the social network Facebook.
Malyar's statements come at a time when the Ukrainian army reported fighting with Russian armored units in Dymer and Ivankiv, respectively 45 and 80 kilometers north of the capital, ensuring that they destroyed two tanks and that the advance of "superior enemy forces was stopped on the bank of the Teterov River. The bridge over the river was destroyed".
Vorzel is a village in the Ukrainian region, about 35 kilometers from the capital, where explosions were heard this morning, which Interior Ministry advisor Anton Gerashchenko attributed to the firing of anti-aircraft batteries defending the city.
The same Kiev anti-aircraft defense shot down a Russian plane, which crashed next to a residential building in the city, in the Darnitsk district, wrote the same source on the Telegram messaging platform.
Still north of Kiev, in the Oblonsky district, there are reports of explosions.
On Thursday, the first day of the invasion, Russian troops had already taken the Vilcha border point, also in the Kiev region, 50 kilometers from the Belarusian border.
PUB
Shortly afterwards, they stormed the Hostomel airfield, 35 kilometers from the capital, where they arrived with 200 paratroopers, according to the army, but the Ukrainian armed forces managed to regain control, according to presidential advisor Alexei Aristovich.
"Another tactical group of the Defense Forces maintains control of Hostomel airport, where Russian paratroopers arrived yesterday [Thursday]", the General Command of the Armed Forces reiterated today.
Russia extended the invasion of Ukraine to the outskirts of the capital and, even at dawn, the United States said it was convinced that the siege of Kiev was imminent.
Explosions sounded before dawn in Kiev. The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that the Government had information that "subversive groups" were invading the city.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Kiev "could very well be surrounded".
US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin, in a telephone call with members of the US Congress, said that the Russian mechanized forces that entered from Belarus were just over 30 kilometers from the Ukrainian capital.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

The Mayor of Lisbon, Carlos Moedas (PSD), considered this evening that the Russian offensive against Ukraine is "an unspeakable act by Vladimir Putin", reiterating that the Portuguese capital is with Kiev.
"Lisbon is with Kiev today. Lisbon is with Ukraine, with all those who suffer, to say no to this war. [...] We are here to help, we are here united", highlighted the mayor in a video message on Twitter.

The facade of Lisbon City Hall was lit up this evening with the colors of the Ukrainian flag as a "manifestation of solidarity" with the country, following the military offensive launched this morning by Russia.
"As a manifestation of solidarity, the facade of Lisbon City Hall will be illuminated tonight with the colors of the Ukrainian flag from 8pm and the moment will be attended by the Ukrainian ambassador to Portugal", said an official source from the municipality.
Carlos Moedas had already today considered the Russian military offensive in Ukraine "unacceptable", assuring Ukrainians living in the Portuguese capital and Portuguese-Ukrainians that "Lisbon is with Kiev, Lisbon is with Ukraine".
"It's a very sad day and my word goes first to the Ukrainian and Portuguese-Ukrainian Lisbon residents to tell them that Lisbon is with Kiev, Lisbon is with Ukraine and that what is happening is unacceptable", said Carlos Moedas, on the sidelines of a visit he made this morning to the ARCOmadrid contemporary art fair, in the Spanish capital.
The municipal official also highlighted that his "solidarity is total with Ukraine", arguing that "the world has to react" and that he will play his role, "which is small, in a world that is getting closer".
In the early hours of Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

The War
World
Bolsonaro says he is in solidarity with Brazilians in Ukraine without citing Russian invasion
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
01:23
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/Joedson Alves
The President of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, said yesterday that he was "fully committed to the effort to protect and assist Brazilians in Ukraine", but declined to make any comment about Russia's military invasion of the country.
"I am fully committed to the effort to protect and assist Brazilians in Ukraine," Bolsonaro wrote on his personal account on the social network Twitter, without mentioning the conflict triggered today by Russian military troops who entered Ukraine's territory.
"Our embassy in Kiev remains open and ready to assist the approximately 500 Brazilian citizens living in Ukraine and all others who are there temporarily", added the Brazilian President.
Jair Bolsonaro also published part of a note issued by his country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to guide citizens who are in Ukraine.
In the statement, the ministry asked Brazilians in Ukraine to remain in contact with the Brazilian embassy and advised them to travel to Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, as soon as security conditions allow.
"The Brazilian embassy in Kiev remains open and dedicated, as a priority, since the worsening of tensions, to the protection of approximately 500 Brazilian citizens in Ukraine (...) Brazilian citizens in Ukrainian territory, particularly those in the east of the country and other regions in conflict conditions, are requested to maintain daily contact with the embassy", the statement reads.
"If they need assistance to leave Ukraine, they should follow the embassy's guidance and, in the case of residents in the east, move to Kiev as soon as security conditions allow," the note added.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

The War

Ukrainian government says it has regained control of airport on the outskirts of Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 24, 2022
23:09
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Ukrainian Government assured today that it has under control the Hostomel airport, 35 kilometers from Kiev, which had been taken over by Russian soldiers as part of the military operation launched this morning by Russia against Ukraine.
‚ÄúHostomel airport is already ours,‚Äù presidential advisor Alex√©i Arest√≥vich wrote on Facebook.
Anton Gershchenko, advisor to the Minister of the Interior, confirmed the information in another message on the same social network, saying that the Ukrainian Army achieved its "first big victory" by reconquering Antonov International Airport.
The Ukrainian Land Army said Russia had infiltrated the airport with 200 paratroopers.
Early this evening, the Russian Armed Forces announced control of the Antonov military airport, in Gostomel, on the outskirts of Kiev, and Western intelligence services recognized that Russian air superiority in Ukraine was "total".
"Ukraine's air defenses have been destroyed and are unable to protect themselves. In the coming hours, the Russians will attempt to gather an overwhelming force around the capital," a Western intelligence source said.
"Russian troops are already gathering around Kiev. It's a matter of days, or hours", explained the source, highlighting the speed with which Moscow's forces are moving around the Ukrainian capital, taking positions such as the military airport in Gostomel.
During the day, the Ukrainian Army announced that fighting was underway for control of the Antonov military airport, following an attack by Russian forces.
"Fighting is underway at Gostomel airport", located a few kilometers northwest of Kiev, announced the head of the Ukrainian Army, Valery Zaloujny, and images on social media show that the military airport was attacked by several helicopters.
Hours later, Ukrainian authorities admitted that they had lost control of the airport, after a Russian air unit attacked with helicopters, with the doors open, from which soldiers fired machine guns, before descending by 'abseiling', according to witnesses.
"There were people sitting in helicopters, doors open, flying over our houses," said Sergiy Storojouk, a Ukrainian who lives near the airport.
The Russian helicopters arrived late in the morning from Belarus, skimming the roofs of houses and sowing terror on their way to Kiev, according to a report by a journalist from the France Presse agency.
Antonov Airport, in Gostomel, is in the far north of Kiev, proving that Russian forces are very close to the center of the Ukrainian capital.
According to Olexander Kovtonenko, a 30-year-old civilian who lives near the airport, the Russian helicopters were supported by two fighter planes, which fired missiles at Ukrainian ground units at the beginning of the attack.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.
