translated_text:
V
ladimir Putin once again made public statements, broadcast on Russian state television. The President of Russia urged Ukrainians to lay down their weapons and classified the Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, and his ministers as "a clique of drug addicts and neo-Nazis, who established themselves in Kiev and took the entire Ukrainian people hostage", quotes the
New York Times.
Vladimir Putin addressed the Ukrainian forces this Friday. According to Reuters, the President of Russia: "Take power in your hands. It seems to me that it will be easier to negotiate between you and me."
Putin also praised the Russian army, which he considers to be performing ‚Äúcourageous and heroic‚Äù.
Despite Zelensky having Jewish origins, Moscow has called the Ukrainian authorities "neo-Nazis" or "junta" since 2014, when the war began in eastern Ukraine, between pro-Russian separatists and Kiev forces.
The "drug addict" accusations refer to statements made by Zelensky's detractors during the 2019 presidential elections, which the President won by a large margin.
Russia accuses Ukraine of having integrated units close to the extreme right into its armed forces and pointed to the "denazification" of Ukraine as one of the objectives of its invasion.
Putin today accused these units of acting "like terrorists."
Ukraine also compared Russia's actions to those of "Nazi Germany" during World War II.
Putin's appeal to the Ukrainian army was made hours after Zelensky called on the Russian President to sit at the negotiating table, an option that the Kremlin did not immediately rule out, but left without a clear response.
On the first day of the Russian invasion, on Thursday, Zelensky denounced that the aim of the attack was to remove him from power.
"According to our information, I am the enemy's number one target. My family is the second [target]. They [the Russians] want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state," he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.
Russian forces are already in the capital. According to the latest report, a group of soldiers arrived in the residential neighborhood of Obolon, around 10 kilometers from the center. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky criticized the lack of support from other countries and stated that the sanctions imposed on Russia are "not enough".

"T
terrible missile attacks on Kiev. The last time our capital suffered something similar was in 1941, when it was attacked by Nazi Germany", wrote the head of Ukrainian diplomacy on the social network Twitter.

Moscow launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

I had already warned today that the night will be very difficult, more so than the day
.¬†"I appeal to those who defend us. Tonight will be very difficult, and the enemy will use all available forces to break the resistance of the Ukrainians. We need to understand what awaits us. Tonight we have to stand firm. The fate of Ukraine is being decided now", he stressed.
"Many cities are under attack: Chernihiv, Sumy, Kharkiv, our boys and girls in Donbass, the southern cities, special attention to Kiev", he pointed out, also issuing a warning: "We cannot lose the capital".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

American actor is in Kiev to "tell the world the truth about the Russian invasion". Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky recorded the meeting between the two and thanked them for their support.
American actor and director Sean Penn, 61, traveled to Ukraine before Russia invaded the territory, finding himself in Kiev where, yesterday, he was in the front row of the government press conference.
"The director purposely came to Kiev to film everything that is currently happening in Ukraine, and to tell the world the truth about the Russian invasion of our country", reads a statement from the Ukrainian Presidency Office.
The ongoing documentary will focus on the consequences of military forces' attacks and orders from Russian President Vladimir Putin and Sean has already visited Ukrainian troops in Donetsk. He was also received by Volodymyr Zelensky, who shared the moment on social media. For him, the artist demonstrates "courage and honesty". "The more friends of Ukraine are in the country supporting the fight for freedom, the faster we will stop Russia's treacherous attack," Zelensky added.
Penn had already been to the region in November for his new film, ending up bringing forward his return due to the geopolitical tension that led to the military conflict that has marked recent days. An admitted activist, this is not the first time that the actor and director has headed to complicated latitudes. In 2010 he was in Haiti, after the earthquakes that destroyed that country. He also sparked controversy when, in 2016, he interviewed Mexican drug trafficker El Chapo for "Rolling Stone" magazine.

translated_text:
A
The military offensive that Russia launched yesterday morning in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, took us all by storm. The signs that suggested a war ended up becoming reality and the world shook. The Ukrainian community in Portugal in particular.
Lyudmyla Serhiyenko, 25 years old, is Ukrainian and has lived in Portugal for 11 years. He lived almost half his life here, but his connection to Ukraine and his family there made yesterday particularly difficult.
But it wasn't just yesterday that panic took over.
"During the last few days, I lived in a state of internal panic that I was trying not to
show.
It's that feeling when you're almost absolutely sure that this is going to happen, but you still have that little hope because as they say 'hope is the last to die'", he told
News by the Minute
.
It was panic, shock and mainly fear. Fear for my country, people and obviously family
Despite knowing that the attack was possible, Lu, as she prefers to be treated, did not expect the scale of it, that it would be directed at "so many cities" or that it would happen yesterday. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt expect it to happen at all,‚Äù he laments.
A call from her family, the one who lives in Portugal, yesterday morning was what alerted her. Lu says he answered with the usual ‚Äúgood morning‚Äù, but in response he heard
‚Äúit‚Äôs daytime, but it‚Äôs not good,¬†Ukraine is at war.‚Äù
"It was a shock. A bucket of cold water being poured on me. An electric shock. It's a feeling I've never felt and never thought I would feel. It was panic, shock and mainly fear. Fear for my country, people and obviously family.
It took me a long time to understand all this, I think I'm still trying. I keep hoping it's just a nightmare. But unfortunately, in this case, the nightmare became reality", he describes.
Lu's relatives in Ukraine are not in any of the bombed cities, yet the fear is great. "My family and I are from a city called Ternopil, which is close to Lviv, which is on the border with Poland. So far, nothing has happened in our city, but that doesn't mean it won't happen", he explains, indicating that his family members have decided to stay in Ternopil for the time being.
The young woman who studied Marketing in Portugal states that both she and her family in Ukraine believe and trust the Ukrainian military. "The government's orders are not to panic, so that's what they're doing," he explains.
We trust the Ukrainian military with our lives
But it is no easy task. Here, the young Ukrainian admits that
yesterday was "horrible", from the moment of the first call until the end of the night
, with every piece of news I saw.
"With each piece of news, tears appear in their eyes, but with each plane shot down, each tank shot down, a little joy appears deep in their hearts.
But it's the day when
I couldn't do anything: eat, drink, work and live a normal life.
It was the day to have Portuguese news on television, Ukrainian news on the computer, chats on the cell phone, such as Telegram and social networks in general", he tells the
News by the Minute
.
My heart sank with each news of a new bombing, with each new video from my friends in Ukraine
Serhiyenko also details that a great anger arises within him for "every lie that is being transmitted by the Russians".
"The great brainwashing that they are having and that they genuinely believe that Russia came to defend [the separatists] and we are attacking our own cities", he describes.
"I've already lost a family member to the Russians, I don't want to lose any more"
At the end of 2014 and beginning of 2015, during the war in Ukraine in which Russia managed to occupy Crimea,
Lyudmyla's¬†uncle was one of those who fought. And one of them lost his life
. The young woman fears that the same thing will happen again to another family member.
"My biggest fear is that my uncle died for nothing in January 2015 protecting the city of Luhansk.
I have already lost a family member to the Russians, I don't want to lose any more family members and, above all, my country.
We fought for a long time to have our freedom and we are not ready and willing to lose it", he admits.
The young woman fears that Russia will take over her country, where she has happy family and childhood memories.
"The biggest fear is that Russia will take over my country. The country where I and everyone in my family was born. Where I spent my childhood and youth. Where I was happy. Where I want to take my children one day and tell stories about my happy childhood. I don't want to tell war stories. My biggest fear is losing my country. My Ukraine",
account.
"We would rather die than be subject to Russia"
From the desire to maintain the independence of 'his' Ukraine to the cry for action instead of sanctions, Lu explains how he sees this war and how he believes that Putin must be fought in another way.
"My view of all this is that we and they
we are dying because of a sick idea from an old man who wants to bring the Soviet Union back together
. He never liked our independence and wants to end it. He wants us submissive. But that won't happen.
We would rather die than be submissive to Russia", he emphasizes, indicating that this is his and his family's vision.
As for sanctions, the
Ukrainian woman argues that they are "boring" and will not solve the problem that grows day by day
. Lu claims that world leaders are not doing enough and that what is being done is not enough.
"Obviously, I hope for help. It's not sanctions. Every time I hear the word sanctions, it makes me sick.
Sanctions will not save our soldiers. Sanctions will not stop civilians from dying. Sanctions won't help me sleep better. I don't even care how I sleep anymore. Sanctions won't help my family stay safe
", he begins by saying.
"I expect military help, I expect monetary help, I expect help with weapons that they were promising so much over the last few days. Unfortunately, after seeing the speeches of world leaders today, it became clear that Ukraine will not receive any military help.
They are ready to protect the European Union and NATO partners and countries. But not us. And we need this help so much. To win, to live, to survive
", he concludes.
Offensive has already killed at least 120 and displaced around 100,000
Since yesterday morning, Russia's military offensive in Ukraine has caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported last night that 100,000 were displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said the "special military operation" in Ukraine aimed to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way the country could defend itself. How long this invasion will last is uncertain, with the Kremlin stating that it will depend on its "results" and "relevance", without specifying exactly what the objectives are.
The attack was vehemently condemned by most of the international community. Emergency meetings were held between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.
Following these meetings, mass sanctions were approved against Russia but also specifically against Putin and Lavrov.
It should also be noted that Russians took to the streets yesterday en masse to protest against Putin's war, with the authorities repressing these protests. More than 1,800 protesters were detained in Russia for demonstrating against the war.

"I am the enemy's number one target. My family is the second [target]. They want to destroy Ukraine politically, destroying the head of state", revealed the president of Ukraine. He stated that there are Russian sabotage groups in the capital Kiev.
President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky

Without a suit and tie, but in a t-shirt, the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, appeared in a video published on the Kiev Government website, in which he indicates that on the first day of the Russian invasion, 137 Ukrainian citizens died and 316 were injured.
"Today [Thursday] Russia attacked the entire territory of Ukraine. And today our defenders did a lot.
The enemy attacks not only military installations, as they claim, but also civilians. They kill people and turn peaceful cities into military targets. This is vile and will never be forgiven," he stressed.
Zelensky also said that the country was left "alone" in the face of Moscow's military offensive. "They left us alone to defend our State", he lamented.

"Who is willing to fight with us? I don't see anyone. Who is willing to give Ukraine a guarantee of NATO membership? Everyone is scared," said Zelensky,
indicating the presence of Russian sabotage groups in the capital.
In his address to the nation, Zelensky assured that both he and his family remain in Kiev.
"According to our information, I am the enemy's number one target. My family is the second [target]. They want to destroy Ukraine politically, destroying the head of state", he stressed.
Previously, the Ukrainian head of state decreed on Thursday the general mobilization of the population subject to "military conscription and reservists" to combat the Russian invasion of the country, which began in the early hours of Thursday.
According to the decree signed by Zelensky and published on the Ukrainian presidency's website, the measure covers all people subject to "military conscription and reservists" and will be applied within 90 days in all regions of Ukraine.
Local administrations, with the support of companies and institutions of "all types", will have to guarantee the arrival of mobilized people and requested vehicles at meeting points and military bases, according to the decree.
Volodymyr Zelensky has already presented the decree to the Ukrainian parliament, as revealed by the head of state on his Telegram social network account.
Also today, the President of Ukraine had already imposed martial law across the country today after the start of Russia's military operation.
"
We impose martial law throughout the territory of our State",
revealed, through Telegram.
"We cut diplomatic relations with Russia"
Zelensky also announced the severing of diplomatic relations between Ukraine and Russia following the military aggression against Ukrainian territory ordered by Kremlin chief Vladimir Putin.
"This morning made history, but this story is absolutely different for our country and for Russia. We have cut diplomatic relations with Russia," declared Zelensky.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Home

Russians and Ukrainians will compete in UEFA competitions in neutral stadiums
Russians and Ukrainians will compete in UEFA competitions in neutral stadiums
Share
on Facebook
Twitter

(FILES) This file photo taken on April 30, 2020, shows the lawn in repair of the "Stade de France" in Saint-Denis, north of Paris. - France will host this season's Champions League final after Saint Petersburg was stripped of the match due to Russia's military invasion of Ukraine, UEFA announced on February 25, 2022. It will be played at the Stade de France on May 28, European football's governing body (UEFA) said, and also announced that Russian and Ukrainian clubs and national teams competing in international competitions must play home matches at neutral venues "until further notice". (Photo by FRANCK FIFE / AFP)
Photography:¬†AFP
Share
on Facebook
Writing with Lusa
25¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†10:58
European competition games to be played in Ukraine or Russia will move to neutral ground, UEFA announced this Friday, following Russia's military offensive in Ukraine.
"At the meeting of the Executive Committee it was also decided that the clubs and national teams of Russia and Ukraine will play their home games on neutral grounds, until further notice", says UEFA.
Related
International.
Jos√© Mourinho's Roma face Vitesse in the round of 16 of the Conference League
International.
Manchester United are considering Rudiger to replace Maguire
Spartak Moscow is the only team from both countries still competing in senior men's football competitions, entering the draw for the round of 16 of the Europa League, which also includes FC Porto and Braga.
Another situation forced to a neutral venue will be the reception of the Ukrainians from Dynamo Kiev to Sporting, in the round of 16 of the UEFA Youth League, a competition that each season replicates the group stages of the Champions League for juniors.
The game between Dynamo Kiev and Sporting, which was supposed to be played in Ukraine, had already been postponed on Tuesday from March 2nd to March 9th, following the worsening of the political-military situation in Ukraine, even before the Russian attack.
On Thursday, Poland, which was supposed to visit Russia on March 24, the Czech Republic and Sweden, possible opponents of the Russians, appealed to FIFA not to play on Russian territory in the qualifying play-offs for the 2022 World Cup.
"The signatories of this appeal do not consider traveling to Russia and playing football matches in the country. The military escalation that we are observing implies serious consequences and a considerable loss of security for our teams", states the letter to FIFA from the football federations of Poland, the Czech Republic and Sweden.
Also today, at the same meeting of its Executive Committee and for the same reasons, UEFA decided to remove the 2020/21 Champions League final game from Saint Petersburg, transferring it to the Stade de France, in Paris.
The stage for the final of the European club competition is changed for the third consecutive year, after Lisbon and Porto hosted the 2019/20 and 2020/21 finals, due to the covid-19 pandemic, in both cases to the detriment of Istanbul, Turkey.
After "vehemently condemning the military invasion" on Thursday, UEFA brought together the executive committee to assess the situation in Ukraine, deciding to withdraw Russia from organizing the "Champions" final, scheduled for May 28.
The stadium that would host the final in St. Petersburg is named after energy giant Gazprom, one of UEFA's main sponsors since 2012.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, spoke to the nation again today in a message that demonstrates the seriousness of the situation in Ukraine. The night will be very difficult, more so than the day, the Ukrainian head of state has no doubt about that.

The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Latvia is available to host the Ukrainian government in case of exile
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
14:56
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Latvia is willing to welcome a possible Ukrainian government in exile, if it is forced to leave Kiev because of the Russian invasion, Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics announced today.
In the worst-case scenario, if Ukrainian political leaders have to leave the country because Kiev fell to Russian troops, Latvia is willing to take on the role of host for the government in exile, Rinkevics said.
"If the Ukrainian government has to leave Kiev, it will fight from anywhere in the country. But if the legitimate leaders of Ukraine have to leave temporarily, Latvia is ready to receive them," said Rinkevics, who hopes this is just a theoretical hypothesis.
Rinkevics visited Ukraine this week and left the country by road on Thursday, after the start of the war, expressing his satisfaction at having been able to travel to Kiev on Wednesday, at the same time as a plane with Stinger anti-aircraft missiles donated by Latvia arrived in the Ukrainian capital.
Latvia's head of diplomacy said that his country, as well as other NATO countries, are studying how to supply military equipment to Ukraine now that airspace in the region has closed.
Rinkevics also said that Latvia needs more anti-aircraft defense and maritime surveillance systems for the naval defense of the Baltic, a task it shares with Sweden, which has increased its military presence on the island of Gotland.
The Latvian Foreign Minister argued that, to improve the security of the Baltic countries, NATO needs to address the issue of policing the so-called Suwalki Gap, a strip on the Lithuanian border with Poland, which stretches from Belarus to the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Conflict
Putin targeted by sanctions, Zelensky criticizes European ‚Äúslowness‚Äù
Vladimir Putin, Russian head of state, and Volodymyr Zelensky, President of Ukraine
Photo:¬†AFP
25¬†February¬†2022
JN/Agencies
Yesterday¬†at¬†21:00
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
Topics
World
Russia-Ukraine crisis
Vladimir Putin
Volodymyr Zelensky
Putin targeted by sanctions, Zelensky criticizes European ‚Äúslowness‚Äù
Comment
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Share
JN/Agencies
Yesterday¬†at¬†21:00
Facebook
Twitter

Comment
Russian President Vladimir Putin learned this Friday that he will be subject to sanctions from the European Union and the United Kingdom, while in Kiev his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky, called for faster aid to his country.
The heads of European Union (EU) diplomacy today reached an agreement to sanction Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, with a freeze on financial assets, following the invasion of Ukraine.
The sanctions package expands the list of Russian personalities, individuals and entities subject to sanctions, extending it to the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, as well as the Prime Minister, the Minister of Defense, which was already included, the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of the Interior.
At the same time, European Union (EU) finance ministers also committed to applying "for as long as necessary" the financial sanctions agreed by European leaders on Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, promising that "they will be complemented by additional decisions".
Hours earlier, Vladimir Putin expressed his willingness to send a delegation to Minsk, the capital of his ally Belarus, for talks with Ukraine.
"Vladimir Putin is willing to send a Russian delegation to Minsk, at the level of the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs and elements of the presidential administration, for negotiations with a Ukrainian delegation", announced Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov.
PUB
The Russian President's spokesman even said that Moscow would analyze the statement by the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, about his readiness to discuss his country's neutrality.
"It's a new statement. We paid attention to it. It's a step towards the positive side. Now it's up to us to analyze it. I can't say more at the moment," said Kremlin (Russian Presidency) spokesman Dmitri Peskov.
This is because, in a speech to the nation on Thursday night, the Ukrainian President said that his country is not afraid of Russia, nor afraid of "talking to Russia, of talking about everything: guarantees for our State, the status of neutrality".
Early in the morning, however, Russia showed a greater determination to make its warlike intentions prevail and made it known that it intends for the Ukrainian armed forces to lay down their arms to "free the Ukrainians from oppression" and return to negotiations.
"We are ready for negotiations at any time, as soon as the Ukrainian armed forces hear our appeal and lay down their arms," ‚Äã‚Äãsaid the head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
Lavrov reiterated that the objective of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered by President Vladimir Putin is to free Ukrainians from oppression, an indication that Moscow intends to overthrow the current government of President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Faced with this position of strength, Zelensky asked the NATO countries of the so-called Bucharest Nine group for help to defend Ukraine and to form an "anti-war coalition" that would bring Russia to the negotiating table.
"We defend our freedom, our land. We need effective international assistance. I discussed this with Andrzej Duda [President of Poland]. I appealed to the Bucharest Nine for defense help, sanctions, pressure on the aggressor," Zelensky wrote on the social network Twitter.
Later, Zelensky lamented that Europe's response to the Russian invasion was too slow and invited Europeans with combat experience to travel to Ukraine and repel the Russian army.
‚ÄúHow are you going to defend yourselves if you are so slow to help Ukraine?‚Äù asked Volodymyr Zelensky, in a speech to international journalists, in which he criticized the European response to the ongoing Russian invasion.
The Ukrainian President's words sounded as Russian forces approached Kiev and shots were heard in the center of the Ukrainian capital.
But the Ukrainian President assured that the Government remains firm and that his advisors are in Kiev working to defend the country from the Russian invasion, in a video in which he appears on the street surrounded by his closest team.
"We are here. We are in Kiev. We are defending Ukraine", says Volodymyr Zelensky, in the 32-second video, recorded by him on Bankova Street, in front of the Office of the President of Ukraine.
The Pentagon also acknowledged that the Russian offensive in Ukraine "lost momentum" in the last 24 hours, faced with "greater" resistance from the Ukrainian military than Moscow expected.
Russia has not yet fully taken control of Ukrainian airspace, a senior US official said.
In this scenario, more than 50,000 Ukrainians fled their country in less than 48 hours since the start of the Russian invasion, revealed the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who also counted 100,000 displaced people in Ukraine.
"More than 50,000 Ukrainian refugees have fled their country in less than 48 hours - the majority to Poland and Moldova - and many more are heading towards the borders," wrote Filippo Grandi on the social network Twitter.
Meanwhile, the Council of Europe decided to "suspend" the participation of Russian diplomats and delegates in the main bodies of this pan-European organization "with immediate effect", in response to the "armed attack" against Ukraine.
This decision excludes the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR, its French acronym), the judicial arm of the Council of Europe, which will continue to provide protection to Russian citizens, the international organization announced in a statement.

intergovernmental organization, with 38 member countries, gathered its Council to take "a series of initial decisions" against the regime of Russian President Vladimir Putin, after, on Thursday, he condemned "Russia's large-scale aggression against Ukraine in the strongest terms".
"Firstly, the Council decided to formally end the accession process with Russia, which had been postponed in 2014", the year in which Russia occupied Crimea, the OECD announced in a statement.
The Council also resolved to close the OECD office in Moscow and "to put an end to all invitations to Russia at ministerial level and in bodies in which it participated as a guest".
The OECD has also suspended the conclusion of any new voluntary contributions agreements with Russia and its secretary general must "take the necessary measures to prevent any projects financed through voluntary contributions from Russia, which have not yet been started".
The Council also announced that OECD support for the Ukrainian government will be reinforced and reiterated solidarity with the Ukrainian people.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities that have already caused at least 120 deaths.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by the international community and prompted emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
A
The city of Lviv in western Ukraine has introduced a curfew between 10pm and 6am.
The information was provided by the Interfax Ukraine news agency, citing a city official.
"We will provide passes to residents of the region employed in critical infrastructure," the head of the local military administration, Maxim Kozitsky, told Interfax.
Remember that yesterday thousands of Ukrainians fled to the west of the country to try to find a safe place as Russia's attack targets Ukraine from the north, south and east. Lviv is located near the border with Poland, the country where thousands of Ukrainians fled yesterday, leaving everything behind.
The Russian military offensive against Ukraine began early yesterday morning. Since then, it has caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported last night that 100,000 were displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said the "special military operation" in Ukraine aimed to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way the country could defend itself. How long this invasion will last is uncertain, with the Kremlin stating that it will depend on its "results" and "relevance", without specifying exactly what the objectives are.
The attack was vehemently condemned by most of the international community. Emergency meetings were held between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.
Following these meetings, mass sanctions were approved against Russia but also specifically against Putin and Lavrov.
It should also be noted that Russians took to the streets yesterday en masse to protest against Putin's war, with the authorities repressing these protests. More than 1,800 protesters were detained in Russia for demonstrating against the war.

J√∫nior Moraes, a forward born in Brazil, is available to the country's military forces under attack by Russia for having become a naturalized Ukrainian three years ago.

Living in a moment of apprehension and fear, the forward, according to the newspaper "GloboEsporte", is "the only one of the 30" footballers from Canary Islands who play in the country's first division - the next edition of which has no starting date - from Eastern Europe with dual nationality, obtained in 2019.
For now, and while the confrontation rages in several areas of Ukraine, J√∫nior Moraes is, according to the Brazilian newspaper, located in a hotel in the Kiev region, together with Brazilian colleagues from Shakhtar, in an improvised space for protection.
Formed at Santos, J√∫nior Moraes, currently 34 years old, moved to Ukraine in 2011, to wear the shirt of Metalurg Donetsk, a club located in a region that was one of the first to face Russian military attacks.
J√∫nior Moraes stayed in the Eastern European country for several years. In the same year he arrived, he went on loan to CSKA Sofia and, in 2015, signed for Dynamo Kiev, a club in the capital, before heading to Chinese football in 2017, but for a short time.
Four months later, he transferred to Shakhtar Donetsk, a club he continues to represent, despite the next edition of the Ukrainian football league being suspended due to the war led by Russia in Ukraine. In 2019, he decided to become a naturalized Ukrainian citizen and later served on the national team.
Now, instead of entering a football pitch to attack the opposite goal and score goals, J√∫nior Moraes, depending on the state of mobilization decreed in Ukraine, will be able to join the army and start defending Ukrainian territory.

Zelensky vs Putin. The face-to-face between the "clown" and the spy
When in 1991, after the collapse of the USSR, Vladimir Putin resigned from the KGB, Volodymyr Zelensky, aged 13, still only made his classmates laugh. Only four years later would he realize that humor was serious and he would start doing stand-up comedy. He would graduate in Law, just like Putin, but it was political satire that made him famous... and a millionaire. Now they face each other in a conflict in which everyone loses.
In 2019, Zelensky and Putin were together in Paris.
¬©¬†Ian LANGSDON / POOL / AFP
Helena Tecedeiro

When Volodymyr Oleksandrovych Zelensky was born, on a cold January day in 1978, into a Jewish family in Kryvyi Rih, in the southeastern metallurgical zone of the then Soviet republic of Ukraine, Vladimir Putin had already joined the KGB, the Soviet secret services, three years ago, after graduating in Law. Zelensky himself would end up being seduced by the study of laws, also graduating in Law at the National University of Economics in Kiev, even though he had already been involved in comedy since he was 17 years old. This will perhaps be one of the few common traits between the men who are now the faces of both sides in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
"April 1st, what a fantastic day to win. After all, I'm a clown!", exclaimed the man who campaigned only as "Ze", in an interview with the newspaper Ukrayinska Pravda in the middle of the campaign for the 2019 presidential elections in Ukraine. In just a few months, the comedian who had gained fame with the television program Servo do Povo, in which he played the role of a professor who accidentally becomes president, managed to imitate in reality the fiction he had represented.
Zelensky celebrates victory in 2019.

In a country that had not yet forgotten the events of 2014 - the overthrow of pro-Russian president Viktor Ianukovych due to pro-Western street protests - Zelensky's joking campaign, which refused to discuss serious issues or participate in debates, convinced voters that the president they saw on the screen making jokes with his wife or cycling to work with a panicked face was really the best to occupy the head of state. And they gave him victory, refusing a new mandate to Petro Poroshenko and generating comparisons with the Italian Silvio Berlusconi or the American Donald Trump, other figures from the
show-business
who reached the top in the politics of their countries.
Elected with almost three-quarters of the votes, the actor who became an instant politician saw his victory hailed from across the border by Vladimir Putin, who had been at the top of power for more than 20 years - almost always in the presidency, with a short stint as head of government. The Russian president stated that he expected Zelensky to have "common sense", "honesty" and pragmatism" to improve the bilateral relationship. After the pro-Western Poroshenko, Moscow did not take a bad look at the coming to power in Kiev of a young man without any political experience. The former comedian himself had promised to get closer to Russia, while maintaining independence.
Just in case, three days after Zelensky's victory, Putin signed an order to issue Russian passports to hundreds of thousands of residents of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-speaking and partially under the control of Moscow-backed separatists since Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. A step that has now gained new weight, with Putin claiming that the deployment of troops to Ukraine aims in part to protect these citizens Russians.
Obsession since the days of the KGB
To understand Putin's fixation with Ukraine it is necessary to go back to his youth. After all, the president, born Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, now Saint Petersburg, like many Russians of his generation - subjected to the force of Soviet propaganda while growing up - still has the wounds of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the loss of its sphere of influence very fresh.
Putin was in the KGB between 1975 and 1991.
¬©¬†Vladimir Putin/Kremlin personal archive
The son of a veteran seriously injured in World War II, Putin likes to remember that his paternal grandfather, Spiridon Putin, worked as a cook, first for Lenin, the leader of the Bolshevik revolution that overthrew the tsar in 1917, and then for his successor, Stalin, serving the latter at his dacha in the Moscow region.
In the 1980s, while Zelensky followed his family to Erdenet, the Mongolian city where his father, a mining engineer, worked for four years before returning to Ukraine for his son to enter primary school, Putin was rising in the KGB. And it was from Dresden, in communist East Germany, where he was stationed between 1985 and 1990 as a secret agent, that he lived through the last years of the Soviet Union.
Putin himself has said many times how he went through the same difficulties as his companions during the collapse of the USSR, and even recently confessed to having had to work as a taxi driver to pay the bills when he returned to Russia. For many Russians, the years following the dismantling of the Soviet Union were marked by humiliation and poverty - a clear contrast to the triumphalism and prosperity of the West at the time.
Putin has already considered the end of the Soviet Union as "the greatest catastrophe of the 20th century", worse in his opinion than the two world wars. And last Monday, in the speech in which he recognized the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, Putin went back to 1991 to argue that Ukraine is not "a state", having been "stolen" from Russia by the collapse of the Soviet Union. ‚ÄúUkraine has become a huge puppet colony,‚Äù he assured. Before adding that Ukrainians "wasted not only what we gave them during the Soviet Union, but even everything they inherited from the Russian empire. Even the work created by Catherine the Great," he said. And not even Lenin escaped his criticism, with Putin considering him "author and creator" of Ukraine.
Political rise vs. career in humor
Putin with Yeltsin.
¬©¬†AFP
For Putin, the 1990s also meant leaving the KGB and entering politics. After resigning from the secretariat in 1991, following the coup against Mikhail Gorbachev, he began working in the office of the Mayor of Saint Petersburg, where he remained until 1996, when he resigned after losing the elections. It was then that he moved to Moscow. After a brief stint at the Presidential Department of Property Management, President Boris Yeltsin appointed him head of protocol, later being responsible for the regions before being named prime minister on August 9, 1999.
Coming out of his childhood at the collapse of the Soviet Union and the independence of Ukraine, while Putin exchanged his role as a spy for that of a politician, Volodymyr Zelensky began to realize that humor was his future. In 1995, at the age of 17, the man who always made his classmates laugh joined KVN, a local comedian competition, and ended up winning the national edition. With your own team of
stand-up comedy
, Kvartal 95, toured Ukraine, but also Russia and other countries of the former USSR. In 2003, Kvartal 95 became the name of his studio that produced television programs. His specialty: political satire.
Also a film star, it was with the television program Servo do Povo that he gained fame and made a fortune. From criticizing politicians in fiction to criticizing politicians in reality was a step. In March 2019, he confessed in an interview with the German magazine
Der Spiegel
his desire to enter politics to "bring decent and professional people" to power. Once in office, he made oligarchs one of his targets, seeking to move away from the past in which he had worked for one - Ihor Kolomoisky.
Zelensky in Servant of the People
From cooperation to confrontation
A Kremlin strongman for more than two decades, Putin has had a tense relationship with the West in recent years. And he made it very clear that one of his red lines is the continued expansion of NATO eastward. This explains that after the auspicious beginning when he came to power, the relationship with Zelensky deteriorated to the point of military confrontation. The two even participated in a meeting in Paris to try to resolve the conflict in Donbass, which has claimed more than 14,000 lives since 2014, but Zelensky's statement at the end that "very little" had been achieved seems to have soured Kiev-Moscow relations.
Putin has since accused Zelensky's government of "discriminating" against Russian-speaking residents and reneging on promises to resolve the conflict in the country's east. Zelensky's proposal in January for a summit between him, Putin and American President Joe Biden received no response from Moscow. The tone rose this week, with Putin recognizing the independence of the Donetsk and Luhansk separatists and, yesterday, launching a large-scale military operation in response to, he said, the "genocide" in eastern Ukraine. And he guaranteed that it was a "demilitarization" and "denazification" of the country and not an "occupation".
"Nazification" and the Jewish leader
The idea that Ukraine is controlled by "neo-Nazis" and "fascists" had previously been conveyed by the Kremlin, referring to ultranationalist and far-right groups that operate in the country, often resorting to intimidation and violence to impose their agendas, often with the complicity of the authorities. The response from the Jew Zelensky - who recalled that his grandfather lost three brothers in the Holocaust - arrived yesterday: "They tell you that we are Nazis. How can a people who lost 8 million lives fighting Nazism support Nazism?"
Until now, the Ukrainian president had almost made people forget his lack of political experience. It remains to be seen how he will deal with the biggest challenge of his short political career - a war against the very experienced Putin.

translated_text:
The War
World
Putin assures the Chinese President that he is willing to talk to Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
12:59
0
Comments
Russian President Vladimir Putin today told his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, that he is willing to hold "high-level negotiations" with Ukraine, after having launched a military operation against that country.
Quoted by state television CCTV, Xi Jinping called on Kiev and Moscow to "resolve their problems through negotiations".
The Chinese leader added that Beijing "respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of States", but stressed that it is "important to respect the legitimate security concerns of all countries involved".
China has adopted a discreet and somewhat contradictory stance on the Ukrainian issue, while trying to balance its political relationship with Moscow with its trade and economic ties with the European Union (EU) and the United States and its own long-standing principles on territorial sovereignty and non-interference in the internal affairs of other countries.
Chinese diplomacy has stated that it "understands" Russian security concerns, but also that it "respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries."
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
Sport
UEFA 'transfers' Russian and Ukrainian games to neutral grounds
Feb 25, 2022
10:54
0
Comments
European competition games to be played in Ukraine or Russia will move to neutral ground, UEFA announced today, following Russia's military offensive in Ukraine.
"At the meeting of the Executive Committee it was also decided that the clubs and national teams of Russia and Ukraine will play their home games on neutral grounds, until further notice", says UEFA.
Spartak Moscow is the only team from both countries still competing in senior men's football competitions, entering today the draw for the round of 16 of the Europa Football League, which also includes FC Porto and Sporting de Braga.
Another 'obligatory' situation at a neutral venue will be the reception of the Ukrainians from Dynamo Kiev to Sporting, in the round of 16 of the UEFA Youth League, a competition that each season replicates the group stages of the 'Champions' in juniors.
The game between Dynamo Kiev and Sporting, which was supposed to be played in Ukraine, had already been postponed on Tuesday from March 2nd to March 9th, following the worsening of the political-military situation in Ukraine, even before the Russian attack.
On Thursday, Poland, which was due to visit Russia on March 24, the Czech Republic and Sweden, possible opponents of the Russians, appealed to FIFA not to play on Russian territory in the qualifying play-offs for the 2022 World Cup.
"The signatories of this appeal do not consider traveling to Russia and playing football matches in the country. The military escalation that we are observing implies serious consequences and a considerable loss of security for our teams", states the letter to FIFA from the football federations of Poland, the Czech Republic and Sweden.
Also today, at the same meeting of its Executive Committee and for the same reasons, UEFA decided to remove the 2020/21 Champions League final game from Saint Petersburg, transferring it to the Stade de France, in Paris.
The stage for the final of the European club competition is changed for the third consecutive year, after Lisbon and Porto hosted the 2019/20 and 2020/21 finals, due to the covid-19 pandemic, in both cases to the detriment of Istanbul, Turkey.
After "vehemently condemning the military invasion" on Thursday, UEFA brought together the executive committee to assess the situation in Ukraine, deciding to withdraw Russia from organizing the 'Champions' final, scheduled for May 28.
The stadium that would host the final in St. Petersburg is named after energy giant Gazprom, one of UEFA's main sponsors since 2012.

Russian President Vladimir Putin told his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, this Friday that he is willing to hold ‚Äúhigh-level negotiations‚Äù with Ukraine, after having launched a military operation against that country.
Quoted by state television CCTV, Xi Jinping called on Kiev and Moscow to ‚Äúresolve their problems through negotiations‚Äù.

tries to balance its political relationship with Moscow
with its trade and economic ties with the European Union (EU) and the United States and its own long-standing principles on territorial sovereignty and non-interference in the internal affairs of other countries.

Chinese diplomacy has stated that it ‚Äúunderstands‚Äù Russian security concerns, but also that ‚Äú
respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries
‚Äú.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine aims to ‚Äúdemilitarize and denazify‚Äù its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its ‚Äúresults‚Äù and ‚Äúrelevance‚Äù.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

O
The heads of European Union (EU) diplomacy today reached an agreement to sanction Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, with a freeze on financial assets, following the invasion of Ukraine.
The sanctions package expands the list of Russian personalities, individuals and entities subject to sanctions, extending it to the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, as well as the Prime Minister, the Minister of Defense, which was already included, the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of the Interior.
At the same time, European Union (EU) finance ministers also committed to applying "for as long as necessary" the financial sanctions agreed by European leaders on Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, promising that "they will be complemented by additional decisions".
Hours earlier, Vladimir Putin expressed his willingness to send a delegation to Minsk, the capital of his ally Belarus, for talks with Ukraine.
"Vladimir Putin is willing to send a Russian delegation to Minsk, at the level of the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs and elements of the presidential administration, for negotiations with a Ukrainian delegation", announced Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov.
The Russian President's spokesman even said that Moscow would analyze the statement by the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, about his readiness to discuss his country's neutrality.
"It's a new statement. We paid attention to it. It's a step towards the positive side. Now it's up to us to analyze it. I can't say more at the moment," said Kremlin (Russian Presidency) spokesman Dmitri Peskov.
This is because, in a speech to the nation on Thursday night, the Ukrainian President said that his country is not afraid of Russia, nor afraid of "talking to Russia, of talking about everything: guarantees for our State, the status of neutrality".
Early in the morning, however, Russia showed a greater determination to make its warlike intentions prevail and made it known that it intends for the Ukrainian armed forces to lay down their arms to "free the Ukrainians from oppression" and return to negotiations.
"We are ready for negotiations at any time, as soon as the Ukrainian armed forces hear our appeal and lay down their arms," ‚Äã‚Äãsaid the head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
Lavrov reiterated that the objective of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered by President Vladimir Putin is to free Ukrainians from oppression, an indication that Moscow intends to overthrow the current government of President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Faced with this position of strength, Zelensky asked the NATO countries of the so-called Bucharest Nine group for help to defend Ukraine and to form an "anti-war coalition" that would bring Russia to the negotiating table.
"We defend our freedom, our land. We need effective international assistance. I discussed this with Andrzej Duda [President of Poland]. I appealed to the Bucharest Nine for defense help, sanctions, pressure on the aggressor," Zelensky wrote on the social network Twitter.
Later, Zelensky lamented that Europe's response to the Russian invasion was too slow and invited Europeans with combat experience to travel to Ukraine and repel the Russian army.
‚ÄúHow are you going to defend yourselves if you are so slow to help Ukraine?‚Äù asked Volodymyr Zelensky, in a speech to international journalists, in which he criticized the European response to the ongoing Russian invasion.
The Ukrainian President's words sounded as Russian forces approached Kiev and shots were heard in the center of the Ukrainian capital.
But the Ukrainian President assured that the Government remains firm and that his advisors are in Kiev working to defend the country from the Russian invasion, in a video in which he appears on the street surrounded by his closest team.
"We are here. We are in Kiev. We are defending Ukraine", says Volodymyr Zelensky, in the 32-second video, recorded by him on Bankova Street, in front of the Office of the President of Ukraine.
The Pentagon also acknowledged that the Russian offensive in Ukraine "lost momentum" in the last 24 hours, faced with "greater" resistance from the Ukrainian military than Moscow expected.
Russia has not yet fully taken control of Ukrainian airspace, a senior US official said.
In this scenario, more than 50,000 Ukrainians fled their country in less than 48 hours since the start of the Russian invasion, revealed the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who also counted 100,000 displaced people in Ukraine.
"More than 50,000 Ukrainian refugees have fled their country in less than 48 hours -¬†the majority to Poland and Moldova -¬†and many more are heading towards the borders," Filippo Grandi wrote on the social network Twitter.
Meanwhile, the Council of Europe decided to "suspend" the participation of Russian diplomats and delegates in the main bodies of this pan-European organization "with immediate effect", in response to the "armed attack" against Ukraine.
This decision excludes the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR, its French acronym), the judicial arm of the Council of Europe, which will continue to provide protection to Russian citizens, the international organization announced in a statement.
Portugal joined this chorus of protests and the Portuguese Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, warned that Russia "cannot even dream" of attacking NATO or its friends, after the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that Finland's accession to the Alliance would have repercussions.
"Russia must understand that not only does it have to stop military aggression against Ukraine, but it cannot even dream of taking any aggressive action towards any NATO country, or any NATO-friendly country, as is the case with Sweden and Finland", stressed Ant√≥nio Costa.
In the midst of the diplomatic siege, Putin called his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, telling him that he is willing to hold "high-level negotiations" with Ukraine, after having launched a military operation against that country.
In response, Xi Jinping called on Kiev and Moscow to "resolve their problems through negotiations".
Harsh messages were coming from Europe and the spokesman for the European Union's head of diplomacy accused the Russian President of "behaving like the Nazis" and being on the verge of committing genocide.

Russia today vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning its aggression against Ukraine, isolated in a vote that reached 11 votes in favor and three abstentions, including from China.
At issue is a resolution co-sponsored by the United States and Albania, condemning Russia, "in the strongest terms", for its "aggression against Ukraine" and calling on it to "immediately" withdraw its troops from that neighboring country.
The text, co-sponsored by dozens of countries around the world, received the support of 11 of the 15 members of the Security Council, three abstentions and a single vote against, from Russia.
As one of the five permanent members of the Security Council (P5), Russia has veto power in votes.

In a televised speech addressed to the nation, Volodymyr Zelensky also praised Ukrainian "heroism" in the face of the Russian advance.

The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

Comment
Valery Gergiev, known for being close to Vladimir Putin, was replaced from three performances with the Vienna Philharmonic scheduled for the end of this week at Carnegie Hall, in New York.
Valery Gergiev was scheduled to conduct the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in three concerts at Carnegie Hall, starting this Friday, but the maestro has been urged to react to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, due to his recognized close relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Carnegie Hall, which did not explain the reasons for this last-minute change, revealed that the Russian will be replaced by Canadian conductor Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin, as reported by "The New York Times".
Although Valery Gergiev has not yet publicly reacted to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the maestro has already supported Putin's other actions against the neighboring country and his appearance in New York should cause strong protests.
In the statement, the American concert hall also announced that Russian pianist Denis Matsuev, who was also going to perform with Gergiev and the orchestra on Friday, will not be present.
This pianist is also close to Vladimir Putin and, in 2014, expressed support for Russia's annexation of Crimea.
Valery Gergiev has another appearance planned for Carnegie Hall in May, to lead two concerts with the Mariinsky Orchestra, but in the statement released by the concert hall it was not clear whether these performances will continue.
PUB
In Italy, the maestro who directed the premiere of Tchaikovsky's opera "The Queen of Spades", last Wednesday, at the Scala in Milan, was invited today by the Italian theater to speak about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
The director of La Scala, Dominique Meyer, and the president of the Milan Chamber, Giuseppe Sala, sent a message to the maestro asking him to make a statement calling for a "peaceful solution" to the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, a spokesperson for the Milanese theater told Agence France Presse.
If the maestro refuses, his presence in the next performances of "The Queen of Spades", scheduled for March 5th and 13th, could be at risk.
Giuseppe Sala, who is also president of La Scala's board of directors, warned today, in a public debate in Milan, that, if there is no response, "another conductor could be found" for the next opera performances.
Valery Gergiev, 68, is the general director of the prestigious Mariinsky Theater in Saint Petersburg and is considered one of the most respected conductors in the world.
His closeness to Putin, whom he has known since 1992, his statements about the annexation of Crimea or Pussy Riot, his concerts in bombed-out South Ossetia and in Palmyra, alongside the Syrian army, have earned him much contestation and controversy over the last decade.
Interviewed by France Presse, in Paris, in 2018, Gergiev said he did not want to talk about politics, but welcomed the re-election for a new term of Putin, with whom he said he meets "five to six times a year".
"He won the elections, something that the Western world has difficulty understanding," he added at the time.

translated_text:
The War
World
Kiev says radiation in Chernobyl has increased, Russia says it is under control
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
14:29
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Ukraine warned today that it had recorded worrying radiation data at the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which fell into the hands of the Russian army on Thursday, but Moscow guarantees that everything is under control.
"There was an increase in indicators above control levels at 03:20 (01:20 in Lisbon)," said the deputy director of the Ukrainian department for safety issues at nuclear installations, Alexander Grigorach, quoted by the French news agency AFP.
"We cannot verify [what is happening], because all employees have been removed" from the facilities, explained Grigorach.
The Ukrainian parliament (Verkhovna Rada) also indicated, in its account on the Telegram messaging network, that the automatic control system issued a warning of an increase in "gamma rays", a sign of radioactivity, without specifying the level.
"Because of the occupation and hostilities, it is currently impossible to establish the causes" for these readings, he indicated.
A spokesman for the Russian army assured, in turn, that there was no need to worry about the safety of the reactor that exploded in 1986, releasing radiation to part of Europe, nor with the nuclear installations, guaranteeing, contrary to what the Ukrainians said, that the plant's employees remain on site.
"An agreement was reached with a battalion of the Ukrainian atomic energy security force for the joint security of the power blocks and shelter of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant," Russian Defense Ministry spokesman Igor Konashenkov said.
"Radiation in the nuclear plant area is within normal levels", he assured, stating that "plant employees (...) are monitoring the radioactivity situation".
Cooperation between Russian and Ukrainian soldiers to ensure the security of the plant "is a guarantee that nationalist formations or other terrorist organizations will not be able to use the country's situation to create a nuclear provocation," the spokesman added.
The worst nuclear accident in history occurred on April 26, 1986 in Ukraine - which was, at the time, one of the 15 Soviet republics - when a reactor at the Chernobyl plant, located around 100 kilometers from Kiev, exploded, contaminating around three-quarters of Europe, especially Ukraine, Russia and Belarus.
Almost 350,000 people had to be evacuated from a 30-kilometer perimeter around the nuclear plant.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Control over the Chernobyl nuclear power plant was lost to the Russians, after intense clashes in the area.
Mykhailo Podolyak, an advisor to the Ukrainian President, admitted that it is unknown, after the fighting in the area, what condition the plant's facilities are in, where there is a protective shelter and a nuclear waste storage unit.

And
This information was advanced by the Ukrainian regulator to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which further reported that Chernobyl was taken over by "unidentified armed forces".
Ukraine had already warned today that it had recorded worrying radiation data at the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which fell into the hands of the Russian army on Thursday, although Moscow assured that everything is under control.
The international agency revealed that Ukraine's regulatory authority reported¬†that the cause¬†of the high radiation measurements at the site "may have been caused by heavy military vehicles stirring up soil still contaminated from the 1986 accident."
The IAEA said in a statement that it assesses that the readings reported by the regulator -- of up to 9.46 microSieverts per hour -- are low and remain within the operational range measured in the Exclusion Zone since it was established and therefore do not pose any danger to the public, the statement read.
The worst nuclear accident in history occurred on April 26, 1986 in Ukraine - which was, at the time, one of the 15 Soviet republics - when a reactor at the Chernobyl plant, located around 100 kilometers from Kiev, exploded, contaminating around three-quarters of Europe, especially Ukraine, Russia and Belarus.
Almost 350,000 people had to be evacuated from a 30-kilometer perimeter around the nuclear plant.
This international agency also warned in the press release that operations at nuclear facilities in Ukraine, which is facing an invasion from Russia, should not be "affected or interrupted in any way."
"It is vitally important that the safe and secure operations of nuclear installations in the area are not affected or interrupted in any way", highlighted Rafael Mariano Grossi, ¬†director general of that agency, cited in a statement.
Ukraine also informed the IAEA today that the country's nuclear power reactors continue to operate safely.
But the head of this agency reiterated a call for "maximum containment to avoid any action that could compromise the security of the plants".
This agency further assured that it "continues to closely monitor this and other developments in Ukraine, with a special focus on the safety and security of its nuclear reactors."
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Ukraine's Foreign Minister announced today that the country has started collecting data on the actions of the Russian Armed Forces in the context of the invasion of Ukrainian territory to send it to the International Criminal Court (ICC).
"Today's Russian attacks on a children's garden and an orphanage are war crimes and violations of the Rome Statute," wrote Dmytro Kuleba on the social network Twitter, where he announced that these "and other facts" will be sent to the ICC.
The head of Ukrainian diplomacy assured that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is collecting evidence to send it "immediately" to The Hague (Netherlands), where the headquarters of the international body is located.
"They will not be able to avoid punishment," he added.
Since the beginning of the Russian military operation against Ukraine, ordered on Thursday by the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, Ukrainian authorities have denounced the occurrence of attacks against civilian installations, which was denied by the Russian Ministry of Defense.
"The Russian military takes all measures to avoid casualties among the civilian population", declared today the spokesman for the Russian military institution, Igor Konashenkov, who, in turn, accused the Ukrainian army of placing several launchers in populated areas to use the population as a "human shield".
During a press conference in Moscow, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said today that the aim of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered by President Vladimir Putin is to free Ukrainians from oppression and prevent the country from continuing to be ruled by "neo-Nazis and those who promote genocide."
In the same statements, Lavrov lamented that the international community "is in chorus denying that there are obvious symptoms of genocide in Ukraine" and announced that Moscow will present evidence of this to the UN Human Rights Council next week.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Erdogan criticizes NATO and EU for "lack of determination"
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
14:12
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whose country is a member of NATO, today criticized the Atlantic Alliance and the European Union (EU) for the lack of "determined action" in the face of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
"NATO should have taken more decisive measures. Europe lacks determination in its approach. All they do is give advice and warnings to Ukraine", insisted the Turkish head of state to the press.
The Turkish President considered that "a serious blow to peace" was underway and warned his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, that Turkey "will not recognize any measure that affects the integrity of Ukraine".
Erdogan informed Putin of Turkey's position during a telephone conversation.
The Turkish head of state also told Putin that a military conflict "will bring nothing to anyone", without specifying how long the conversation lasted for his Russian counterpart.
Erdogan called for a solution found based on the 2014 and 2015 Minsk Agreements.
The Minsk Agreements, signed by Kiev and the separatists under the aegis of Paris, Berlin and Moscow, made it possible to reduce the intensity of the conflict, which claimed more than 14,000 lives, according to the latest UN report.
The Turkish President reaffirmed his commitment "to the continuation of diplomatic contacts and talks" and assured that Turkey is "ready to take its part to reduce tension".
Erdogan had already considered Moscow's recognition (on Monday) of the pro-Russian separatist republics of Donetsk and Lugansk, in eastern Ukraine, "unacceptable" on Tuesday.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" Ukraine and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on the "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.
