According to the head of the Regional Executive, there are currently 189 Ukrainian tourists in Madeira who were supposed to return to Kiev on Saturday, but Ukraine's airspace is closed and the flight is not expected to take place.
"We will find a solution. I think that this afternoon or later tomorrow morning [Saturday morning] we will find a solution so that people don't become homeless", said the Madeiran government official, highlighting that many of these people "already have their accounts cancelled".
Miguel Albuquerque admitted that housing these tourists in a hotel in the region could "be a solution".
But, he stressed, the "priority" objective of the steps being taken is "to see if there is any indirect way, through another country, for companies to be able to land and transport these people to their destination".
The Madeiran official also added that 223 Russian tourists are also in the region, who arrived in the archipelago through the connection made between Madeira and Moscow airports.
"We are currently preparing all steps to support these people", he pointed out, ensuring that, "if necessary", Madeira "will also support" these Russian citizens.
Miguel Albuquerque also highlighted the consequences of Russia's invasion of Ukraine in terms of tourism and for the citizens of the two communities residing in the region, as Madeira has direct air links with both countries.
"We have a completely well-integrated resident community. We have 328 Ukrainian permanent residents and 413 Russian citizens. People who are completely integrated into our society are always welcome," he emphasized.
The president of the Madeiran government also stressed that "these people have nothing to do with regimes or violations perpetrated by the Russian Government".
"What we want is for the situation to be resolved quickly so that we can continue the [aerial] operations that were important for Madeira," he said.
Asked about the possibility of Madeira welcoming refugees, Miguel Albuquerque recalled that this availability has always existed.
On Thursday, the Secretary of Tourism of Madeira, Eduardo Jesus, recalled that the tourist operation with Russia involves a weekly direct flight from Moscow, the same happening with Ukraine, with a direct connection between Kiev and Madeira.
"The operations were expected to continue until October this year and would generate the possibility of each of them bringing around 7,000 people to Madeira", he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Portugal
Golden visas attract investment of 277.8 million from Russia and 32.5 million from Kiev
The Minister of State and Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, at the Permanent Commission meeting to discuss the situation in Ukraine.

Investment from Russia captured by the 'gold' visa program totals more than 277.8 million euros in nine years and that from Ukraine totals 32.5 million euros, according to SEF data requested by Lusa.
In total, since the Residence Permit for Investment Activity (ARI) program was launched, 431 'gold' visas have been granted to Russian citizens, which corresponds to an investment of 277,811,929.38 euros, according to the Foreigners and Borders Service (SEF).
"Ukrainian citizens were allocated 51 ARI, implying an investment of 32,547,593.49 euros", according to the same source. This year, seven 'golden' visas have been granted to Russian citizens. Last year, 65 ARIs were granted to Russia, totaling 33,608,503.58 euros, compared to 63 'gold' visas granted in 2020, totaling 37,730,418.17 euros.
Also in 2020, seven Ukrainian citizens obtained residence permits for investment activities, worth 3,7979,500 euros.
With regard to the job creation criterion, Ukraine was responsible for 11 jobs in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãcomputer consultancy and programming in Lisbon and Russia for 11 jobs in Set√∫bal, in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãhotels and restaurants.
Since the ARI grant program was launched in October 2012, 6,147,874,500.99 euros have been raised through this instrument. Of this amount, the majority corresponds to the purchase of real estate, which until January totaled 5,545,982,427.40 euros, with the acquisition for urban rehabilitation totaling 376,804,564.85 euros.
The investment resulting from the capital transfer is 601,892,073.59 euros.
PUB
Sanctions in Portugal
The Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs guaranteed on Thursday that any Russian citizen whose name is on the list of people and entities targeted by the sanctions approved by the European Union is subject to them, even if they are also a Portuguese citizen.
"Any Russian citizen, residing in Portugal in any capacity, with any type of authorization, whether or not he is a Portuguese citizen, who is part of the list of those sanctioned is subject to the limitation of movements in Portugal and the freezing of his financial assets", stated Augusto Santos Silva in parliament.
In a debate on the crisis that led to Russia's military attack on Ukraine and responding to deputy Pedro Filipe Soares, from BE, - who asked whether there will be sanctions decided at national level, such as the suspension of the granting of so-called 'golden visas' -, Santos Silva recalled that Portugal does not have a national sanctions regime, but applies sanctions decided at European Union level.
"Whatever type of authorization they hold, if they are on the list of those sanctioned, they are sanctioned in Portugal as in any other EU state", guaranteed the head of Portuguese diplomacy.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Thirteen Ukrainian guards, who were defending a small island in the Black Sea, Serpent Island, died at the hands of Russian forces after refusing to surrender.
In an audio that is circulating on social media it is possible to hear the last words of one of the Ukrainian soldiers addressed to the Russian vessel: "F*** you".
"This is a military warship. This is a Russian military warship. I suggest you lower your weapons and surrender to avoid bloodshed and unnecessary casualties. Otherwise, you will be bombed", the audio heard. After a brief silence, the response comes from the other side, "Russian warship, f*** off." The audios have been widely shared on social media.
They died in a "heroic way"
The group of thirteen Ukrainian soldiers died trying to defend Snake Island - so the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, announced that the soldiers will be awarded the posthumous "Heroes of Ukraine" award for the "heroic" way in which they lost their lives, without giving up.
The island, located in the Black Sea, is approximately 16 hectares, belongs to Ukraine and is approximately 300 kilometers from Crimea, a territory annexed by Russia in 2014. All soldiers guarding the island died when they refused to surrender, Ukrainian officials announced.

translated_text:
And
The cause is a resolution co-sponsored by the United States and Albania, condemning Russia, "in the strongest terms", for its "aggression against Ukraine" and asking it to "immediately" withdraw its troops from that neighboring country.
The text, supported by dozens of countries around the world, received the support of 11 of the 15 members of the Security Council, three abstentions and a single vote against, from Russia.
As one of the five permanent members of the Security Council (P5), Russia has veto power in votes.
China, India and the United Arab Emirates were the countries that abstained.
Brazil, one of the countries whose vote was in doubt, ended up supporting the resolution after insisting during the negotiations on the need to maintain a balance that allows Russian actions to be denounced, but not close the door to the possibility of negotiations to stop the conflict.
Before the vote, the Ukrainian ambassador to the UN, Sergiy Kyslytsya, considered that the vote would represent "a moment of truth": It means knowing "who is on the right side", he said.
Although the United States and other supporters of the resolution anticipated that the resolution would not be approved, given Russia's already anticipated veto, they argued that the vote would highlight Moscow's international isolation.
The room where the Security Council met in New York, despite the result, became a place for international pressure on Russia and for defining Government positions.
US Ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield reacted to the failure of the resolution by emphasizing that it is not a surprise and insisted that Russia will ultimately be held accountable for its actions.
"Russia can veto this resolution, but it cannot veto our voices, it cannot veto the truth, it cannot veto the Ukrainian people", insisted the American diplomat.
"History will judge us by our actions or lack thereof," he added.
It is now expected, after Russia's veto, that the draft resolution will be taken to the 193 members of the UN General Assembly.
After months of tensions, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The United Kingdom, in addition to sanctioning five banks and three oligarchs on Tuesday, imposed a new package of sanctions against Russia on Thursday, banning the airline Aeroflot from operating on British soil and also targeting the banking sector, technology exports and five businesspeople.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

The War
World
Heavy military vehicles may have caused increased radiation at Chernobyl
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
22:56
0
Comments
High radiation measurements at the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, now controlled by Russian forces following the invasion of Ukraine, may have been caused by the passing of heavy military vehicles, the Ukrainian regulator reported today.
This information was advanced by the Ukrainian regulator to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which further reported that Chernobyl was taken over by "unidentified armed forces".
Ukraine had already warned today that it had recorded worrying radiation data at the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which fell into the hands of the Russian army on Thursday, although Moscow assured that everything is under control.
The international agency revealed that Ukraine's regulatory authority reported¬†that the cause¬†of the high radiation measurements at the site "may have been caused by heavy military vehicles stirring up soil still contaminated from the 1986 accident."
The IAEA said in a statement that it assesses that the readings reported by the regulator -- of up to 9.46 microSieverts per hour -- are low and remain within the operational range measured in the Exclusion Zone since it was established and therefore do not pose any danger to the public, the statement read.
The worst nuclear accident in history occurred on April 26, 1986 in Ukraine - which was, at the time, one of the 15 Soviet republics - when a reactor at the Chernobyl plant, located around 100 kilometers from Kiev, exploded, contaminating around three-quarters of Europe, especially Ukraine, Russia and Belarus.
Almost 350,000 people had to be evacuated from a 30-kilometer perimeter around the nuclear plant.
This international agency also warned in the press release that operations at nuclear facilities in Ukraine, which is facing an invasion from Russia, should not be "affected or interrupted in any way."
"It is vitally important that the safe and secure operations of nuclear installations in the area are not affected or interrupted in any way", highlighted Rafael Mariano Grossi, ¬†director general of that agency, cited in a statement.
Ukraine also informed the IAEA today that the country's nuclear power reactors continue to operate safely.
But the head of this agency reiterated a call for "maximum containment to avoid any action that could compromise the security of the plants".
This agency further assured that it "continues to closely monitor this and other developments in Ukraine, with a special focus on the safety and security of its nuclear reactors."
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Ints Kalnins - Reuters
Here we follow all developments regarding the military operation launched by Russia in Ukraine.
More updates
18:08 ‚Äì The routine of Ukrainians when the sirens sound
6:07 pm ‚Äì Russia out of this year‚Äôs Eurovision contest
Russia "will not participate" in the 66th Eurovision Song Contest, scheduled for May in Turin, Italy, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which promotes the contest, announced today.
"The EBU Executive Board took the decision following a recommendation from today's festival organization, based on the event's rules and EBU values. The organization's recommendation also has the support of the EBU television department", reads a statement released this afternoon on the EBU's official website.
18:01 ‚Äì ‚ÄúWe must be ready to do more, even if it means paying the price‚Äù, warns NATO
NATO's secretary general warned today that ‚Äúthe Kremlin's objectives are not limited to Ukraine‚Äù and considered that President Putin's decision to continue his aggression ‚Äúis a tremendous strategic error for which Russia will pay a high price in the years to come‚Äù.
Jens Stoltenberg recalled that ‚ÄúNATO allies and the European Union have already taken very significant sanctions and our partners around the world have joined us‚Äù.
‚ÄúWe have to be ready to do more, even if it means we have to pay the price, because we are in this for the long term‚Äù, added the official.
5:58 pm - Costa warns that Russia "cannot even dream" of attacking NATO or its friends
The Portuguese Prime Minister warned today that Russia "cannot even dream" of attacking NATO or its friends, after the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that Finland's accession to the Alliance would have repercussions.
"Russia must understand that not only does it have to stop military aggression against Ukraine, but it cannot even dream of taking any aggressive action towards any NATO country, or any NATO-friendly country, as is the case with Sweden and Finland", stressed Ant√≥nio Costa.
5:53 pm ‚Äì NATO will highlight more elements at sea, land and air. ‚ÄúThere will be no room for miscalculations‚Äù
NATO's secretary general has just announced that the Alliance will ‚Äúdeploy more elements of the response force at sea, on land and in the air, to strengthen our position and respond quickly to any contingency‚Äù.
‚ÄúWe have more than 100 fighter planes on high alert, operating in more than 30 locations, as well as 120 vessels from the north to the Mediterranean, including aircraft carrier groups‚Äù, specified Jens Stoltenberg.
"There will be no room for miscalculation. We will do whatever it takes to protect and defend any and all allies in every inch of NATO territory," he added.
5:26 pm ‚Äì Government gave instructions for ‚Äúimmediate visas‚Äù to Ukrainians who want to come to Portugal
Ant√≥nio Costa once again stressed that Portugal ‚Äúis fully available to welcome all those who want to continue their lives among us‚Äù, thus escaping the conflict caused by Russia in Ukraine.
‚ÄúInstructions have already been given, both to our embassy in Ukraine and in neighboring countries, to grant immediate visas‚Äù to anyone who wants to come to Portugal.
5:23 pm ‚Äì EU diplomacy chiefs agree to sanction Putin and Lavrov
The heads of European Union diplomacy reached an agreement today to sanction Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, with a freeze on financial assets, following the invasion of Ukraine.
The information was announced today by the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, at a press conference in Brussels, at the end of an extraordinary meeting with his EU counterparts.
5:08 pm ‚Äì Portugal will send an infantry company to Romania
Portugal, in addition to the forces assigned to NATO's European command this year, ‚Äúdecided to bring forward from the second semester to the first semester the mobilization and commitment of an infantry company that will operate in Romania and that will be projected in the coming weeks‚Äù, said Ant√≥nio Costa.
‚ÄúSeveral other countries are currently either anticipating, or reinforcing, or deciding to reinforce their participation‚Äù so that there is unity in deterring Russian action.
Asked about the size of this force, Ant√≥nio Costa confirmed that the number of soldiers that will be sent "in the coming weeks" will be 174, already foreseen in the plan for Portuguese participation in international missions for 2022, under NATO's 'Tailored Forward Presence'.
5:05 pm ‚Äì NATO will ‚Äústrengthen deterrence actions‚Äù, says Ant√≥nio Costa
At the end of the NATO meeting, Ant√≥nio Costa said that ‚Äúthere was a total convergence in the understanding that it is essential to reinforce deterrence actions, taking into account this clear violation of international law‚Äù and the fact that ‚Äúthere was totally unjustified military action‚Äù on the part of Russia.
‚ÄúThere was unanimity among all States regarding the need to reinforce NATO's presence on the borders of Ukraine and in all Alliance countries that are close to the Ukrainian region‚Äù, added the Portuguese Prime Minister.
4:58 pm ‚Äì United Nations warns of increase in civilian casualties in Russian offensive
The United Nations today warned of an increase in civilian casualties in the Russian offensive in Ukraine, with at least 25 dead and 102 injured in bombings, although it acknowledged that the real number would certainly be higher.
Most of the deaths were reported in areas controlled by the Ukrainian Government in the regions of Donetsk, Cherkasy, Chernihiv, Kharkov, Kherson and Lugansk, explained the spokeswoman for the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
"Civilians are terrified of a possible escalation of the conflict. Many of them are trying to leave their homes and take refuge as best they can," the spokeswoman said.
The Ukrainian Government, for its part, raised to at least 137 the number of Ukrainians killed in the invasion launched by Russia, according to the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky.
4:53 pm ‚Äì Russia will limit population access to Facebook
The Russian communications regulator, Roskomnadzor, said today that it will partially limit access to Facebook, in response to the restrictions that the social network imposed on Moscow.
Russia accuses Mark Zuckerberg's platform of ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù.
4:50 pm ‚Äì Chernobyl: Ukraine says radiation has increased, Russia guarantees that everything is under control
‚ÄúThere was an increase in indicators above control levels at 03:20,‚Äù said the deputy director of the Ukrainian department for safety issues at nuclear facilities, Alexander Grigorach.
‚ÄúWe cannot verify what is happening, because all employees have been removed‚Äù, he concluded.
The spokesman for the Russian Ministry of Defense, Igor Konashenkov, states, in turn, that ‚Äúradiation in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe nuclear power plant is within normal levels‚Äù.

4:44 pm ‚Äì The UN warns that more than 50,000 people have left Ukraine in less than 48 hours
4:39 pm ‚Äì Ukraine accuses Russian soldiers of opening fire on ambulances and hospital
Ukraine's Health Minister recently accused Russian troops of shooting at ambulances in the Zaporizhzhya and Chernihiv regions.
Viktor Lyashko also said that Russian forces opened fire on a psychiatric hospital in Chernihiv.
4:27 pm ‚Äì European Finance Ministers reinforce sanctions against Russia
European Economy and Finance Ministers today decided on new additional sanctions against Russia, with France also announcing the freezing of all assets of Russian elite figures such as political leaders and oligarchs.
"The finance ministers, who met this morning with the European Commission and the European Central Bank, will put into practice all the sanctions adopted. We will touch all Russian interests, as long as necessary [...] We also took the decision to prepare new, even more penalizing sanctions against Russian financial institutions", said the French Minister of Economy and Finance, Bruno Le Maire, speaking to journalists.
Jo√£o Le√£o, Minister of Finance of Portugal, was also present at this meeting and, at the end, explained that ‚Äúsanctions will necessarily have economic impacts‚Äù on the European population.
4:24 pm ‚Äì Russia fires at two foreign ships in the Black Sea
Russia today fired at two foreign ships near the port of Pivdennyi, on the Black Sea, the Ukrainian Ministry of Infrastructure announced minutes ago.
According to Kiev, Russia fired on the ‚ÄúNamura Queen‚Äù, a ship flying the Panamanian flag, and the ‚ÄúMillenial Spirit‚Äù, flying the Moldovan flag.
Both ships were evacuated and their crew were taken to the port of Chernomorsk by Ukrainian rescue services.
4:18 pm ‚Äì EU spokesperson accuses Putin of behaving like Nazis
The spokesman for the head of European Union diplomacy today accused Russian President Vladimir Putin of "behaving like the Nazis" and being on the verge of committing genocide.
Vladimir Putin says he "wants to avoid genocide (against Russian speakers in eastern Ukraine), which is complete nonsense, because he is about to commit one there" against Ukrainians, said Peter Stano, spokesman for Josep Borrell, who was speaking in Brussels at the EU executive's daily press conference.
"Basically, he wants to destroy Ukraine. He wants to inflict harm and suffering on the Ukrainian people. It's completely inhumane," Peter Stano said.
4:15 pm ‚Äì Tourists from Ukraine and Russia stranded in Madeira without flights and bank accounts
More than 400 Ukrainian and Russian tourists are stranded in Madeira.
These tourists are unable to return to Kiev and Moscow. Flights are canceled and so are bank accounts.
The president of the Regional Government, Miguel Albuquerque, says that the authorities are trying to help these tourists.
At this time, in Madeira, there are 220 tourists from Ukraine and 189 from Russia.
4:12 pm ‚Äì EU taking ‚Äúextreme care‚Äù with sanctions so they don‚Äôt ricochet
RTP commentator Helena Garrido explains that the European Union is being ‚Äúextremely careful‚Äù regarding sanctions against Russia, so that they do not ricochet and severely harm Europe.
The journalist and economist also explains that Russia had been planning the invasion of Ukraine for a long time and, therefore, began to protect itself from sanctions even before they were announced.
4:07 pm ‚Äì Boris Johnson and Northern allies believe that ‚Äúmore sanctions‚Äù are necessary
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Northern European allies agreed today that "more sanctions" are needed against Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, particularly the "close circle" of Russian President Vladimir Putin.
After a call between Boris Johnson and his allies from the Joint Expeditionary Force (JEF), which brings together ten states, including the Baltics, "the leaders agreed that more sanctions are necessary, focusing above all on President Putin's close circle".
"Added support must be given to Ukraine with all urgency", insisted Boris Johnson, quoted by France-Presse (AFP), adding that "President Putin's harmful acts can never be normalized and his aggression against Ukraine taken as a fait accompli".
3:54 pm ‚Äì Russia suspended from the Council of Europe
Russia has just been suspended from the Council of Europe due to its invasion of Ukraine. The information has just been provided by the Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs.
‚ÄúThe Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, whose presidency is currently held by Italy, has taken the decision to exclude the Russian Federation from its members,‚Äù Luigi di Maio said in a statement.
The Council of Europe was formed after World War II to protect human rights and the rule of law on the continent. It is a separate entity from the European Union.
‚ÄúItaly considers this a necessary measure in view of the unacceptable Russian military aggression against Ukraine‚Äù, added the Italian minister.
3:45 pm ‚Äì Russia claims control of military airport and isolation of Kiev
The Russian Army today claimed control of a strategic airport on the outskirts of the Ukrainian capital and blocked Kiev, isolating it from the western region.
The loss of control of the Antonov military airport, in Gostomel, on the outskirts of Kiev, was recognized on Thursday by the Ukrainian authorities, who claimed its recovery overnight.
3:37 pm ‚Äì Santos Silva confirms that sanctions against Putin are on the table in Brussels
The heads of European diplomacy may today place Russian President Vladimir Putin himself on the list of individuals targeted for sanctions for the military aggression against Ukraine, Minister Augusto Santos Silva confirmed upon arrival at the Council.
Meeting for the third time this week, the 27 foreign ministers are expected to approve the second package of sanctions on Russia today.
"I confirm that it is one of the proposals that we will discuss, in the set of new sanctions that we will approve, following, in fact, the guidelines that came out of the European Council yesterday", declared the head of Portuguese diplomacy.
3:25 pm ‚Äì Latvia is available to welcome the Ukrainian government in case of exile
Latvia is willing to welcome a possible Ukrainian government in exile, if it is forced to leave Kiev because of the Russian invasion, Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics announced today.
In the worst-case scenario, if Ukrainian political leaders have to leave the country because Kiev fell to Russian troops, Latvia is willing to take on the role of host for the government in exile, Rinkevics said.
"If the Ukrainian government has to leave Kiev, it will fight from anywhere in the country. But if the legitimate leaders of Ukraine have to leave temporarily, Latvia is ready to receive them," said Rinkevics, who hopes this is just a theoretical hypothesis.
Rinkevics visited Ukraine this week and left the country by road on Thursday, after the start of the war, expressing his satisfaction at having been able to travel to Kiev on Wednesday, at the same time as a plane with Stinger anti-aircraft missiles donated by Latvia arrived in the Ukrainian capital.
Latvia's head of diplomacy said that his country, as well as other NATO countries, are studying how to supply military equipment to Ukraine now that airspace in the region has closed.
3:12 pm ‚Äì Poland will close airspace to Russian flights
The Prime Minister of Poland, Mateusz Morawiecki, announced today that Polish airspace will be closed to Russian planes, which will prevent them from taking off or landing in the country.
"I have ordered the preparation of a resolution by the council of ministers that will lead to the closure of Polish airspace to Russian aviation companies," Morawiecki wrote in a brief message on his Facebook account.
3:10 pm ‚Äì Putin asks the Ukrainian army to ‚Äútake power‚Äù in Kiev
"Take power into your hands. It seems to me that it will be easier to negotiate between you and me", Putin launched at the Ukrainian army in an intervention broadcast on Russian television, stating that he is not fighting army units, but nationalist formations that behave "like terrorists" using civilians "as human shields".
Putin also classified Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his ministers as "a clique of drug addicts and neo-Nazis, who have established themselves in Kiev and taken the entire Ukrainian people hostage."
Despite Zelensky having Jewish origins, Moscow has called the Ukrainian authorities "neo-Nazis" or "junta" since 2014, when the war began in eastern Ukraine, between pro-Russian separatists and Kiev forces.
The "drug addict" accusations refer to statements made by Zelensky's detractors during the 2019 presidential election, which the president won by a landslide.
3:01 pm - Pope was at the Russian embassy to express his concern about the conflict
The Pope was personally at the Russian embassy next to the Vatican today to express to the ambassador his concern about Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the Vatican's communications department confirmed.
Pope Francis' unprecedented gesture of visiting the Russian embassy, ‚Äã‚Äãlocated on Via de la Conciliazone, in Rome, is part of the Vatican's effort for dialogue and the return to the negotiating table of the parties involved in the conflict over Ukraine.
The Russian ambassador to the Vatican, Alexander Avdeev, is preparing the second meeting between Francis and Patriarch Kirill of the Russian Orthodox Church, keeping the Pope constantly informed about the conflict in Ukraine.
2:52 pm - Ukraine says Russia lost almost 2,800 soldiers in the attacks
Ukraine's deputy defense minister said Russian forces lost around 2,800 troops, 80 tanks, 516 armored fighting vehicles, 10 aircraft and seven helicopters.
2:45 pm ‚Äì Ukrainians living in Portugal organized vigils and appealed for peace
Ukrainians living in Portugal are calling on the international community to put an end to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Yesterday, they demonstrated in Porto, Lisbon and Faro.
The Russian embassy and consulate were two of the stages of the demonstrations. But it was Pra√ßa do Munic√≠pio, in the capital, that brought together the most protesters.
2:25 pm ‚Äì Many Ukrainian refugees head to Poland
It is expected that one million Ukrainians will be able to cross the border. Poland is preventing the entry of men between 18 and 60 years old, as noted by RTP envoy, Jos√© Rodrigues dos Santos.
2:23 pm ‚Äì MNE rejects criticism of the slowness of the European response, saying there is ‚Äúunity and speed‚Äù
The Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs rejects the accusations made by the President of Ukraine, who today considered Brussels' response to the conflict to be ‚Äúslow‚Äù.
Augusto Santos Silva says that there are two characteristics ‚Äúthat punctuate the European reaction‚Äù: unity and speed. The person responsible understands, however, Volodymyr Zelensky's situation.
‚ÄúI understand the words of the Ukrainian president, who is currently, for all intents and purposes, surrounded - as Russian troops are at the gates of Kiev -, in a war that he did not provoke and of which he is only a victim, and in very difficult conditions for his people, who are the target of a brutal aggression‚Äù.
2:07 pm ‚Äì The differences in military power between Russia and Ukraine
In conflict in Eastern Europe are two countries with completely different military power.
The Russians kept the missiles and nuclear weapons and never stopped investing in the Armed Forces. Ukrainians are limited to some of the weapons they inherited more than 30 years ago, when the Soviet Union ended.
2:00 pm ‚Äì Australia accuses Beijing of being Moscow‚Äôs ‚Äúlife buoy‚Äù
Japan announced that it will ban semiconductor exports to Russia. And Australia accuses China of "helping" Vladimir Putin to "circumvent" some sanctions announced by his allies.
1:55 pm ‚Äì Ukrainian military vehicles enter Kiev to defend the city
Ukrainian military vehicles are beginning to enter the city of Kiev to defend it from approaching Russian troops.
The information has just been provided by the Ukrainian Interior Minister.
The mayor of Kiev said, moments before, that the capital was now entering ‚Äúa defensive phase‚Äù.
1:52 pm ‚Äì One hundred thousand Ukrainians fled the country
The UN estimates that around one hundred thousand Ukrainians have fled their homes. Yesterday, there were massive movements at the borders with Poland and Romania.
The director general of the International Organization for Migration, Ant√≥nio Vitorino, admits that the number of displaced people could exceed three million people.
1:49 pm ‚Äì Protests in Moscow and Saint Petersburg against the invasion of Ukraine
Russia is willing to negotiate, but only if Ukraine lays down its arms. The guarantee is from the Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs. Lavrov reaffirms that the objective is to denazify Ukraine.

3:40 am ‚Äì Missile attack hits border post in Zaporizhzhya
A missile attack hit a Ukrainian border post in the Zaporizhzhya region, killing and wounding an as yet undetermined number of guards. The information is confirmed by the border guard service in statements to Reuters.
3:11 am ‚Äì RTP envoys in Ukraine confirm explosions in Kiev
RTP special envoys were called to the shelter after the two explosions this morning.
RTP journalist C√¢ndida Pinto reports on the situation at the shelter, where there are journalists, other guests - including children - and people who work at the hotel.
Hotels, moreover, are starting to have difficulties in guaranteeing meals for guests.
2:51 am ‚Äì Two large explosions heard in Kiev
Ukrainian Deputy Minister of the Interior, Anton Gerashchenko, told France Presse that these were cruise or ballistic missile attacks.
2h37 ‚Äì Portuguese Prime Minister highlights the issue of energy security
I also highlighted that this situation highlights the importance of Europe's energy security, through the diversification of supply sources and energy decarbonization.
pic.twitter.com/1vimRAiqaz
‚Äî Ant√≥nio Costa (@antoniocostapm)
February 25, 2022
2h16 ‚Äì Costa admits economic bill for Portugal
Asked when the third package of sanctions on Russia will be approved, Ant√≥nio Costa began by responding that the EU has adopted ‚Äúa position of openness to dialogue and diplomatic commitment‚Äù, to ensure peace and avoid military clashes. But when Russia decreed the independence of separatist territories, the EU declared a first package of measures, with the aim of dissuading Moscow from proceeding with the invasion.
And now, with Russia having gone ‚Äúto military action with a generalized war in Ukraine, the EU has approved a second package with very harsh and extensive measures‚Äù that affects several sectors of the Russian economy. ‚ÄúIf Russia continues its action, (‚Ä¶) the European Union will consider adopting additional measures.‚Äù
Regarding the impacts in Portugal, Ant√≥nio Costa stated that ‚Äúthere is no war in Europe that does not have negative effects on all of us‚Äù.
‚ÄúWars not only affect the victims of bullets, they also affect the entire continent from a social and economic point of view‚Äù, he declared.
‚ÄúNaturally, all of these sanctions applied to Russia have effects on the European economy and, therefore, also on the Portuguese economy‚Äù, also referring to the energy crisis and the effects of energy, gas and oil prices.
2h00 - EU imposes ‚Äúmassive measures‚Äù on Russia‚Äôs financial, energy and transport sector, says Ant√≥nio Costa
After the European Council meeting on the situation in Ukraine, Ant√≥nio Costa spoke to journalists and accused Russia of having gone ‚Äúfrom violating the International Law to War Action against a free and democratic country‚Äù.
During the meeting, the leaders contacted the Ukrainian president, a moment that the Portuguese prime minister reported as ‚Äúa particularly dramatic and emotional moment‚Äù, in which the situation in Ukraine was described, ‚Äúclearly denying the version that it is a special military operation focused on the separatist regions‚Äù.
‚ÄúThis action requires a response from the international community,‚Äù Costa told journalists. ‚ÄúOn the one hand, NATO will certainly give the answer tomorrow, in the sense of deterrence and guaranteeing the defense of all NATO countries and especially those that have a border with Ukraine, or are close to Ukraine‚Äù.
Recalling that the European Union ‚Äúis not a military organization‚Äù, the head of the Executive stated that ‚Äúa proposal made by the European Commission‚Äù was approved, which aims to approve ‚Äúa second package of sanctions, after many months of diplomatic discourse‚Äù and with ‚Äúmassive measures, which aim to affect, in particular, the financial, energy and transport sectors‚Äù.
According to Costa, these measures also limit ‚Äúthe international financing capacity of Russian state companies and the Russian State‚Äù and also ‚Äúthe granting of visas to holders of diplomatic or service passports‚Äù.
‚ÄúThe Council mandated the Commission to continue monitoring the situation and prepare a new package of sanctions in case Russia persists in violating International Law, in its military action and does not withdraw its military and offensives in relation to Ukraine, not respecting its territorial integrity‚Äù, he continued.
1h56 ‚Äì Ant√≥nio Costa speaks after the European Council
The Portuguese Prime Minister is speaking to journalists at the end of the European Council. Ant√≥nio Costa says that European leaders were able to speak via videoconference with the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky. An "exciting" moment, said the head of Government.
1h40 - Emmanuel Macron: "Putin wants to rewrite history"
The French president said that Belarus was "accomplice" in these actions and that it will therefore also be included in the package of new sanctions.
Emmanuel Macron also announced a new aid package for Ukraine, of which 300 million euros will be made available by France alone.
1:30 am ‚Äì EU reinforces sanctions against Russia
The press conference is already taking place after the European Council. Charles Michel, president of the European Council, Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Emmanuel Macron, French president, who currently holds the rotating presidency of the EU council, announce new sanctions against Russia following Moscow's incursion into Ukrainian territory.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen highlighted that all EU countries are united in condemning Russia after the invasion. The new sanctions package is based on five pillars: financial sector, energy sector, transport sector, export controls and ban on export financing, and visa policy.
With these sanctions, the EU prevents Russia from accessing the most important capital markets, affecting 70 percent of the Russian banking market. The sanctions will also target some of Russia's main state-owned companies.
"These sanctions will increase Russia's borrowing costs, increase inflation and gradually erode Russia's industrial base," the official explained.
In energy terms, and at a time when the EU is quite energy dependent on Russia, there will be a "limitation on exports that will affect oil, making it impossible for Russia to modernize its oil refineries.
This specific point gave Russia export revenue worth 24 billion euros in 2019, said the president of the European Commission.
The sale of "spare parts and aeronautical equipment to Russian airlines will also be prohibited, which will degrade the key sector of the Russian economy and the country's connectivity."
Another point of limitations on exports is the limitation of Russia's access to "fundamental technology", such as semiconductors.
Regarding visas, diplomats and big businessmen will no longer have access to the European Union.
The president of the European Commission highlighted that these sanctions will have "the maximum impact on the Russian economy and the political elite", the latter with the restriction of deposits. Big Russian businessmen will no longer ‚Äúcontinue hiding their money in safe havens in Europe‚Äù.
Ursula von der Leyen says that these sanctions were adopted in coordination with partners and allies, such as the United Kingdom and the United States.
"Our unity is our strength. The Kremlin knows this and has tried its best to divide us, but has completely failed and achieved exactly the opposite: we are more united than ever and we are determined," he said.
Status point
Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory during the early hours of Thursday. The advances were made with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities.
In the first hours of the invasion
, the conflict has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which were civilians on Ukrainian territory, said Kiev. There are still more than 160 people who were injured.
In the last few hours, the highlight was the statement by the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, who decreed the general mobilization of the population. Ukrainians are thus subject to "military conscription", as well as the call for reservists to combat the Russian incursion.
According to data from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), around 100,000 people have already abandoned their homes in Ukraine during the first hours of conflict.
According to the United States, one of the most worrying cities at the moment is Chernobyl.  White House spokeswoman Jen Psaki confirms the existence of hostages at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine.
At a press conference, he called it "outrageous" that Russian soldiers are holding hostages at the Chernobyl facility and demanded their release.

"Gold" visas attract investment of 277.8 million euros from Russia and 32.5 million euros from¬†Kiev
431 "gold" visas were granted to Russian citizens, corresponding to an investment of 277,811,929.38 euros. Seven Ukrainian citizens have obtained residence permits for investment.
Lusa Agency

Investment from Russia captured by the ‚Äúgold‚Äù visa program totals more than 277.8 million euros in nine years and that from Ukraine totals 32.5 million euros, according to SEF data requested by Lusa.
In total, since the Residence Permit for Investment Activity (ARI) program was launched,
431 ‚Äúgold‚Äù visas for Russian citizens
, which corresponds to an investment of
277,811,929.38 euros
, according to the Foreigners and Borders Service (SEF).
‚ÄúUkrainian citizens were allocated 51 ARI, implying an investment of 32,547,593.49 euros‚Äù, according to the same source.
This year, seven ‚Äúgolden‚Äù visas have been granted to Russian citizens.
Last year, 65 ARIs were allocated to Russia, totaling
33,608,503.58 euros
, against 63 ‚Äúgold‚Äù visas granted in
2020
, in an amount of
37,730,418.17 euros
.

Still in 2020,
seven Ukrainian citizens
obtained residence permits for investment activity, worth
3,7979,500 euros
.
With regard to the job creation criterion, Ukraine was responsible for 11 jobs in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãcomputer consultancy and programming in Lisbon and Russia for 11 jobs in Set√∫bal, in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãhotels and restaurants.
Since the ARI grant program was launched in October 2012, funds have been raised through this instrument
6,147,874,500.99 euros
. Of this amount, the majority corresponds to
purchase of real estate
, which totaled until January
5,545,982,427.40 euros
, and the acquisition for
urban rehabilitation
added
376,804,564.85 euros
.
The investment resulting from the capital transfer is 601,892,073.59 euros.
The Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs guaranteed on Thursday that any Russian citizen whose name is on the list of people and entities
targeted by sanctions
approved by the European Union is subject to them, even if he is also a Portuguese citizen.
‚ÄúAny Russian citizen, residing in Portugal in any capacity, with any type of authorization, whether or not he or she is a Portuguese citizen, who
If you are on the list of those sanctioned, you are subject to limited movement in Portugal and the freezing of your financial assets
‚Äù, stated Augusto Santos Silva in parliament.
In a debate on the crisis that led to Russia's military attack on Ukraine and responding to deputy Pedro Filipe Soares, from BE ‚Äî who asked whether there will be sanctions decided at national level, such as the suspension of the granting of so-called ‚Äúgolden visas‚Äù ‚Äî¬†Santos Silva recalled that Portugal does not have a national sanctions regime, but applies sanctions decided at European Union level.
‚ÄúWhatever type of authorization they hold, if they are on the list of those sanctioned, they are sanctioned in Portugal as in any other EU state‚Äù, guaranteed the head of Portuguese diplomacy.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine aims to ‚Äúdemilitarize and denazify‚Äù its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its ‚Äúresults‚Äù and ‚Äúrelevance‚Äù.
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

Russia wants surrender to free Ukrainians and return to negotiations
Lavrov said the aim of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered by President Vladimir Putin is to free Ukrainians from oppression.
The head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov
¬©¬†EPA/RUSSIAN FOREIGN
DN/Lusa
25¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†11:59

Twitter
Comment

Zelensky vs Putin. The face-to-face between the "clown" and the spy

Russia wants Ukraine's armed forces to lay down their arms to "free Ukrainians from oppression" and return to negotiations, the head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov, said this Friday.
"We are ready for negotiations at any time, as soon as the Ukrainian armed forces hear our call and lay down their arms"
, said Lavrov at a press conference in Moscow, cited by the Spanish EFE and French AFP agencies.
Lavrov said that the aim of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered by President Vladimir Putin is to free Ukrainians from oppression, an indication that Moscow intends to overthrow the current government of President Volodymyr Zelensky.

"President Putin made the decision for this special military operation to demilitarize and denazify Ukraine so that, freed from this oppression, Ukrainians can freely choose their future"
, he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The Russian President explained the "special military operation" in Ukraine with the need to "demilitarize and denazify" his neighbor and said that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, specifying the Kremlin that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The FIDE congress, scheduled to take place in Russia, will also be scheduled for another venue, says the same statement
The Chess Olympics, the most prestigious national team competition in the sport, will not be held in Moscow, the International Chess Federation (FIDE, its French acronym) announced today, in reaction to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Related

War in Ukraine: Judo Grand Slam in Kazan canceled
Modalities.

The decision was taken at an extraordinary meeting of the organization, in which it was assumed that all planned official competitions would be moved from Russia to another country.
The FIDE congress, scheduled to take place in Russia, will also be scheduled for another venue, says the same statement.

"The rapid deterioration of the geopolitical situation forced the FIDE council to take this difficult decision," the statement continues.
The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) today urged international sports federations to cancel or relocate events planned for Russia or Belarus.

Lazio fans don't forget and S√©rgio Concei√ß√£o is emotional in Rome
On Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
"And
We are mobilizing the collective defense response force for the first time, to prevent transgressions on NATO territory", highlighted the secretary general of the Atlantic Alliance, Jens Stoltenberg.
The person in charge was speaking in a videoconference with the leaders of NATO members about this reaction force, in which Portugal participates.
Stoltenberg, who praised the capabilities of Ukrainian forces, stressed that "Russia launched an all-out invasion of Ukraine with the stated aim of overthrowing the government by invading Kiev."
"But the Kremlin's objectives are not limited to Ukraine. Putin demanded the withdrawal of Alliance forces from the territories of all countries that joined since 1997," he warned.
For the NATO secretary general, the response must involve "strengthening deterrence and the defense posture of allies".
"The Alliance activated its defense plans on Thursday and is mobilizing elements of its rapid reaction force," he explained.
NATO's Rapid Reaction Force has 40,000 soldiers and included a very high level of readiness joint operational force (VJTF), of 8,000 soldiers, currently commanded by France.
This includes a multinational brigade and battalions, supported by air and maritime units and special forces.
Some units could be ready to move within two to three days, according to NATO.
In Portugal, the Superior Council for National Defense gave a unanimous favorable opinion on Thursday to the Government's proposals for the possible participation of Portuguese military assets in NATO standby forces.
"The Council unanimously gave a favorable opinion to the Government's proposals for the participation of the Portuguese Armed Forces within NATO, which are as follows: 1. Activation of the 'Very high readiness Joint Task Force' (VJTF) and the 'Initial Follow-On Forces Group' (IFFG) for eventual commitment to NATO's Graduated Response plans. 2. Possible anticipation of the second to the first semester of projection of an Army company for Romania", reads a statement.
The Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, announced today that a Portuguese Army company made up of 174 soldiers will be sent to Romania "in the coming weeks", at a time of conflict between Russia and Ukraine.
"Portugal, in addition to the forces assigned to NATO's European command this year, decided to bring forward from the second semester to the first semester the mobilization and commitment of an infantry company that will operate in Romania and that will be projected in the coming weeks", said the Prime Minister.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
A
NATO announced additional reinforcement of its borders with Ukraine and Russia, in the face of what it considers to be a threat that is not limited to Ukrainian territory.
At a press conference this Friday, the alliance's secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, reiterated that "Russia destroyed peace in Europe" and argued that "the Kremlin's objectives are not limited to Ukraine."
In response to this threat, NATO announces that it will mobilize "defensive forces" for countries further east, which border Russia and Ukraine (such as Romania, Moldova and the Baltic countries).
Stoltenberg also announced that NATO would support Ukraine with anti-aircraft material and weapons, after an intense night in which Kiev's defenses shot down Russian aircraft.
"We activated NATO's defense plans to prepare to respond to a set of contingencies and secure the alliance's territory", added the secretary general.
Without specifying how the additional reinforcements would be composed, Jens Stoltenberg listed that there are "more than a hundred fighters on alert operating in more than 30 different locations" and "120 ships in the Mediterranean".
According to Stoltenberg, NATO and Europe must prepare to do so, "even if it means paying a price."
"The Russian people must know that the Kremlin's war in Ukraine will not make Russia safer, will not make it more respectable in the world, will not give its children a better future," he stressed.
The alliance leader also stressed that NATO countries will do "whatever is necessary to protect and defend all allies and every inch of NATO territory."

translated_text:
Home

NATO activates rapid reaction force for the first time that includes Portugal
Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to invade Ukraine "is a strategic error for which Russia will pay a high price", declared the NATO heads of state and government.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg
¬©¬†John Thys/AFP
DN/Lusa
25¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†19:33
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
NATO
Russia
Ukraine
International
Related

ukraine
Borrell and Santos Silva deplore Russia's "obscene" attack on Guterres
war in ukraine
Portuguese in Ukraine: "No one could be seen and only sirens could be heard in Kiev"
NATO mobilized for the first time elements of its rapid reaction force, which includes Portuguese soldiers, to "avoid transgressions on NATO territory", in the face of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Atlantic Alliance revealed this Friday.
"We are mobilizing the collective defense response force for the first time, to prevent transgressions on NATO territory", highlighted the secretary general of the Atlantic Alliance, Jens Stoltenberg.
The person in charge was speaking in a videoconference with the leaders of NATO members about this reaction force, in which Portugal participates.
Close

and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Stoltenberg, who praised the capabilities of the Ukrainian forces, stressed that "
Russia launched an all-out invasion of Ukraine with the stated aim of overthrowing the government by invading Kiev."
"But the Kremlin's objectives are not limited to Ukraine. Putin demanded the withdrawal of Alliance forces from the territories of all countries that joined since 1997," he warned.
For the NATO secretary general, the response must involve "strengthening deterrence and the defense posture of allies".
"The Alliance activated its defense plans on Thursday and is mobilizing elements of its rapid reaction force," he explained.
Portuguese Army Company with 174 soldiers will be sent to Romania "in the coming weeks"
NATO's Rapid Reaction Force has 40,000 soldiers and included a joint operational force with a very high level of readiness (VJTF), of 8,000 soldiers, currently commanded by France.
This includes a multinational brigade and battalions, supported by air and maritime units and special forces.
Some units could be ready to move within two to three days, according to NATO.
In Portugal, the Superior Council for National Defense gave a unanimous favorable opinion on Thursday to the Government's proposals for the possible participation of Portuguese military assets in NATO standby forces.
"The Council unanimously gave a favorable opinion to the Government's proposals for the participation of the Portuguese Armed Forces within NATO, which are as follows: 1. Activation of the 'Very high readiness Joint Task Force' (VJTF) and the 'Initial Follow-On Forces Group' (IFFG) for eventual commitment to NATO's Graduated Response plans. 2. Possible anticipation of the second to the first semester of projection of an Army company for Romania", reads a statement.
The Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, announced today that a Portuguese Army company made up of 174 soldiers will be sent to Romania "in the coming weeks", at a time of conflict between Russia and Ukraine.
"Portugal, in addition to the forces allocated to NATO's European command this year, decided to bring forward from the second semester to the first semester the mobilization and commitment of an infantry company that will operate in Romania
and which will be projected in the coming weeks", said the prime minister.
NATO heads of state and government declared this Friday that Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to invade Ukraine "is a strategic error for which Russia will pay a high price" economically and politically.
In a joint statement, released after today's meeting in Brussels aimed at discussing what they classified as
"the most serious threat to Euro-Atlantic security in decades",
Member States of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) condemned "in the strongest possible terms" the "large-scale invasion of Ukraine, facilitated by Belarus", which began on Thursday.
"We urge Russia to immediately cease its military aggression, to withdraw all its forces from Ukraine and to retreat from the path of violence it has chosen
", the document reads.
Peace in Europe "has been destroyed". "No one should be fooled by the Russian Government's barrage of lies"
"This long-planned attack on Ukraine, an independent, peaceful and democratic country, is brutal and completely unprovoked and unjustified. We regret the tragic loss of life, the enormous human suffering and destruction caused by Russia's actions", continued the leaders of the Member States of the Atlantic Alliance, for whom "peace on the European continent has essentially been destroyed".
Defending that "the world will hold Russia responsible, as well as Belarus, for its actions", the NATO heads of State and Government called on "all States to unreservedly condemn this inconceivable attack" and stressed that "no one should allow themselves to be fooled by the Russian Government's barrage of lies".
"Russia is solely responsible for this conflict: it rejected the path of diplomacy and dialogue repeatedly proposed by NATO and its allies; it violated the foundations of international law, including the Charter of the United Nations" and "its actions are also a flagrant rejection of the principles enshrined in the NATO-Russia Founding Act", because "it was Russia that departed from the commitment made in the Act".
"President Putin's decision to attack Ukraine is a terrible strategic error, for which Russia will pay a high price, both economically and politically, in the coming years", reads the text, which states that "massive and unprecedented sanctions have already been imposed on Russia" and that NATO "will continue to coordinate closely with relevant actors and other international organizations, including the European Union", indicating that,
At the invitation of the Secretary General, representatives from Finland, Sweden and the European Union participated in today's meeting.
NATO will continue to provide political and practical support to Kiev
NATO heads of state and government stressed that they will continue "to provide political and practical support to Ukraine.
"We stand in full solidarity with the democratically elected president, parliament and government of Ukraine and its courageous people who are now defending their homeland. Our thoughts are with all those killed, injured and displaced by Russia's aggression, and with their families,"
indicated in the statement.
Maintaining that ‚ÄúNATO remains committed to all of the founding principles that underpin European security, including that each nation has the right to choose its own security mechanisms,‚Äù its Member States declared: ‚ÄúWe will continue to provide political and practical support to Ukraine as it continues to defend itself, and we call on others to do the same. We reaffirm our unwavering support for the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine within its internationally recognized borders, including its territorial waters. This principled position will never change.‚Äù
In the statement, the heads of State and Government of the Atlantic Alliance also assured that "in view of Russia's actions", they will remove "all necessary consequences for NATO's deterrence and defense posture".
After holding consultations under Article 4 of the Washington Treaty, they assured: "We will continue to take all necessary measures and decisions to ensure the security and defense of all allies."
"We sent land and air defensive forces to the eastern part of the Alliance, and maritime assets to the entire NATO area; we activated NATO's defense plans to prepare to respond to a series of contingencies and guarantee the security of Alliance territory, including using our reaction forces; and we are now proceeding with significant additional deployments of defensive forces to the eastern part of the Alliance", they specified.
"We will deploy all necessary forces to ensure strong and credible deterrence and defense across the Alliance, now and in the future", they reiterated, stressing: "Our measures remain preventive, proportional and non-aggressive".
"Our commitment to Article 5 of the Washington Treaty is ironclad. We stand together to protect and defend all Allies. Freedom will always overcome oppression", they concluded.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
"H
hears an increase in indicators above control levels at 03:20 (01:20 in Lisbon)", said the deputy director of the Ukrainian department for safety issues at nuclear installations, Alexander Grigorach, quoted by the French news agency AFP.
"We cannot verify [what is happening], because all employees have been removed" from the facilities, explained Grigorach.
The Ukrainian parliament (Verkhovna Rada) also indicated, in its account on the Telegram messaging network, that the automatic control system issued a warning of an increase in "gamma rays", a sign of radioactivity, without specifying the level.
"Because of the occupation and hostilities, it is currently impossible to establish the causes" for these readings, he indicated.
A spokesman for the Russian army assured, in turn, that there was no need to worry about the safety of the reactor that exploded in 1986, releasing radiation to part of Europe, nor with the nuclear installations, guaranteeing, contrary to what the Ukrainians said, that the plant's employees remain on site.
"An agreement was reached with a battalion of the Ukrainian atomic energy security force for the joint security of the power blocks and shelter of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant," Russian Defense Ministry spokesman Igor Konashenkov said.
"Radiation in the nuclear plant area is within normal levels", he assured, stating that "plant employees (...) are monitoring the radioactivity situation".
Cooperation between Russian and Ukrainian soldiers to ensure the security of the plant "is a guarantee that nationalist formations or other terrorist organizations will not be able to use the country's situation to create a nuclear provocation," the spokesman added.
The worst nuclear accident in history occurred on April 26, 1986 in Ukraine - which was, at the time, one of the 15 Soviet republics - when a reactor at the Chernobyl plant, located around 100 kilometers from Kiev, exploded, contaminating around three-quarters of Europe, especially Ukraine, Russia and Belarus.
Almost 350,000 people had to be evacuated from a 30-kilometer perimeter around the nuclear plant.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Control over the Chernobyl nuclear power plant was lost to the Russians, after intense clashes in the area.
Mykhailo Podolyak, an advisor to the Ukrainian President, admitted that it is unknown, after the fighting in the area, what condition the plant's facilities are in, where there is a protective shelter and a nuclear waste storage unit.

0

Serbia, a close ally of Russia that has been negotiating membership of the European Union for years, is so far the only European country that has not condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

On Tuesday, before the invasion, the Serbian leader had defended Ukraine's territorial integrity but refused to condemn Russia for the concentration of troops around Ukraine, citing historical relations with Moscow.

Vucic acknowledged a few days ago that 80% of the Serbian media "are not objective and are on the Russian side no matter what happens", while the remaining 20% are, from the outset, opponents of the Russians.
In 2014, Serbia did not impose sanctions on Russia during the Ukraine crisis, unlike EU countries.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Feb 25, 2022
09:20
0
Comments
The European Broadcasting Union (EBU), organizer of the Eurovision Song Contest, confirmed that, as a "cultural event of a non-political nature", Russia will participate in the 2022 edition, despite the invasion of Ukraine.
The confirmation was given in a letter sent to the North American public broadcaster NPR following a petition from the Ukrainian network UA: PBC, which requested the country's expulsion from the contest because it considered it to be "a mouthpiece for the Kremlin and a fundamental tool of political propaganda financed from the Russian state budget".
"The Eurovision Song Contest [which will take place in Italy] is a non-political cultural event. However, the EBU is concerned about developments in Ukraine and will continue to closely monitor the situation", it is stated in the letter.
On Thursday, news emerged of some sporting cancellations, with the match between Georgia and Russia, in the third round of the 2022 Europe Championship in rugby, being postponed to "preserve the health and safety of all staff players", according to the tournament organization.
Poland, which should play in Russia, and Sweden and the Czech Republic, possible opponents, appealed to the International Football Federation (FIFA) so that the World Cup 2022 play-offs cannot be played in that country.
Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

Marco Baixinho wore an armband in honor of Ukraine in the meeting with Belenenses.
The captain of Pa√ßos de Ferreira, Marco Baixinho, wore an armband with the Ukrainian flag and a dove of peace, in the match of the 24th round of the Bwin League, against Belenenses.

This tribute to the Ukrainian population was approved by the Portuguese Professional Football League (LPFP), following a request from the locals, with the intention of "demonstrating all their solidarity with the most recent events" in Ukrainian territory.
Pa√ßos de Ferreira "will pay tribute to Ukraine, through the team captain, who will wear an armband with the flag of that Eastern European country, with a white dove, symbolizing peace. This request from the beavers, given the war situation between Ukraine and Russia, and in a clear tribute to Ukraine, had the approval of the LPFP", explained the entity that governs the I and II Leagues, in a statement.
On Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

The European Union (EU) "wants to cut all ties between Russia and the global financial system", the French Economy Minister said today, following the announcement of a new set of sanctions against Moscow.
Related

"We want to isolate Russia financially (...). We want to dry up the financing" of the Russian economy, Bruno Le Maire declared to the press shortly before the start of a meeting of the European Union's Economy and Finance Ministers (Ecofin), in Paris.
"Our objective is to double the Russian economy and this will take time," said Le Maire, the day after the announcement of European sanctions on Russia.
"Russia is a secondary economic partner of France," said Le Maire, after consulting several business federations, including the automotive, nuclear and aeronautical sectors.

Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

The president of the PSD, Rui Rio, considered today that the Portuguese must be prepared for "some economic sacrifice" resulting from the international economic sanctions imposed on Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
"We all have to be willing to make some sacrifice to punish Russia (...) If we imposed very heavy sanctions on Russia, we also suffer from them", he said today on RTV Lusa radio, during a visit to London as part of the campaign for the legislative elections, whose vote will be repeated in the European circle.
The former mayor of Porto predicted an increase in inflation, interest on bank loans and public debt due to the deterioration of the world economy.
"We must understand that, in view of what the Ukrainian people are going through and suffering, we make our contribution of some reduction in service and some economic difficulties for their benefit, but it is not theirs, it belongs to all of us because if Russia does not have an exemplary punishment, Russia will continue, tomorrow it will enter Georgia or whoever knows where", he explained.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.

Y
aryna Arieva and Sviatoslav Fursin got married just hours after Russia launched the military offensive against Ukraine, early yesterday morning. This Ukrainian couple's wedding was supposed to be in May, but Yaryna and Sviatoslav preferred not to wait as the future is uncertain.
And in the doubt they live in regarding what the future holds for them, they both have only one certainty: they will fight for Ukraine.
The first day of the wedding was, therefore, different from what is usual. Instead of embarking on a honeymoon, the two Ukrainians embarked on a search for weapons, specifically rifles, to defend their country.
Arieva and Fursin also signed up for the Territorial Defense Forces, a branch of Ukraine's military that is primarily made up of volunteers. After finding weapons, the couple went to the office of their political party, European Solidarity.
‚ÄúThere is a lot of work to do, but I still hope everything will be fine," Arieva said in statements to CNN, adding that some civilians who are not part of the defense force also received rifles.
On social media, Arieva shared an image of her first day of marriage with her husband.
"First family photo after the wedding. The second day of the war. The truth will prevail. Everything will be Ukraine!", he wrote in the caption of the shared photo.
Yaryna Arieva and Sviatoslav Fursin got married at St. Michael's Monastery in Kiev.
Yaryna Arieva and Sviatoslav Fursin got married under the sound of sirens in Kiev
¬© Facebook
"The situation is difficult. We will fight for our land," said Arieva. "Maybe we could die and so we just wanted to be together before all this," he admitted to CNN.
The couple, who met in October 2019 at a protest in central Kiev, decided to get married after the first Russian attacks.
