"T
We made the political decision to add an additional package of massive sanctions, which will be painful for the Russian regime", announced Charles Michel.

The Ukrainian President said this Friday that "sooner or later" Russia will have to "talk" to Ukraine to put an end to the fighting and denounced that Moscow is also targeting civilian areas.
In a televised speech addressed to the nation, Volodymyr Zelensky also praised Ukrainian "heroism" in the face of the Russian advance.
"Russia will have to talk to us, sooner or later. To talk about how to stop the fighting and stop the invasion. The sooner this conversation starts, the smaller the losses will be for Russia itself", he defended.
The official also stated that the country's defenders frustrated the operational plans of the Russian invasion on the first day.
"Our boys and girls, all the defenders of Ukraine, did not allow the enemy to execute the operational plan of the invasion on the first day," said the head of state, who stressed that in most directions the advance of Russian troops was stopped and fighting continues.
Russian forces "started bombing civilian areas. This reminds us [of the Nazi offensive in] 1941," said Zelensky, in a video posted on social media, pronouncing the phrase in Russian.
Moscow launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
PUB
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

Ukrainian coach Yuriy Vernydub, of Moldovan side Sheriff, Sporting de Braga's opponent in the Europa League, today lamented the "Russian attack" on his country and expressed "pride" in the people who defend him.
"I was born in Ukraine, I live in Ukraine, and I want to leave some words of support for the people in Ukraine who suffered an attack from Russia this morning. I am proud of the people who are defending the country", he said at the press conference at the end of the match.
Asked if he has family in Ukraine, the coach replied: "it's difficult to talk in this situation, but thank God they are all alive".
"I have a wife, two children, two grandchildren, brothers and sisters, I wish them health and that this war does not touch them. When I arrive in Moldova, I will ask to go to my family, if they need my help I will always be there", he concluded.
This morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of which are civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

NATO mobilized for the first time elements of its rapid reaction force, which includes Portuguese military personnel, to "avoid transgressions on NATO territory", in the face of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Atlantic Alliance revealed today.
"We are mobilizing the collective defense response force for the first time, to prevent transgressions on NATO territory", highlighted the secretary general of the Atlantic Alliance, Jens Stoltenberg.
The person in charge was speaking in a videoconference with the leaders of NATO members about this reaction force, in which Portugal participates.
Stoltenberg, who praised the capabilities of Ukrainian forces, stressed that "Russia launched an all-out invasion of Ukraine with the stated aim of overthrowing the government by invading Kiev."
"But the Kremlin's objectives are not limited to Ukraine. Putin demanded the withdrawal of Alliance forces from the territories of all countries that joined since 1997," he warned.
For the NATO secretary general, the response must involve "strengthening deterrence and the defense posture of allies".
"The Alliance activated its defense plans on Thursday and is mobilizing elements of its rapid reaction force," he explained.
NATO's Rapid Reaction Force has 40,000 soldiers and included a very high level of readiness joint operational force (VJTF), of 8,000 soldiers, currently commanded by France.
This includes a multinational brigade and battalions, supported by air and maritime units and special forces.
Some units could be ready to move within two to three days, according to NATO.
In Portugal, the Superior Council for National Defense gave a unanimous favorable opinion on Thursday to the Government's proposals for the possible participation of Portuguese military assets in NATO standby forces.
"The Council unanimously gave a favorable opinion to the Government's proposals for the participation of the Portuguese Armed Forces within NATO, which are as follows: 1. Activation of the 'Very high readiness Joint Task Force' (VJTF) and the 'Initial Follow-On Forces Group' (IFFG) for eventual commitment to NATO's Graduated Response plans. 2. Possible anticipation of the second to the first semester of projection of an Army company for Romania", reads a statement.
The Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, announced today that a Portuguese Army company made up of 174 soldiers will be sent to Romania "in the coming weeks", at a time of conflict between Russia and Ukraine.
"Portugal, in addition to the forces assigned to NATO's European command this year, decided to bring forward from the second semester to the first semester the mobilization and commitment of an infantry company that will operate in Romania and that will be projected in the coming weeks", said the Prime Minister.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The Water Polo World League games and the World Series of artistic swimming and diving, scheduled for Russia, have been canceled due to the military offensive in Ukraine, the International Swimming Federation (FINA) announced today.

Despite recognizing that "sport must remain politically neutral", the body that governs world swimming "condemns all acts of aggression", assuming "extreme concern" about the escalation of violence in the conflict on Ukrainian territory.
In the same statement, FINA reports on the cancellation of the games between Russia and Greece, for the Water Polo World League, scheduled for March 8, in Saint Petersburg, and the tests for the World Series of artistic swimming and diving, scheduled for between April 8 and 10, in Kazan.

The Council of Europe decided this Friday to "suspend" the participation of Russian diplomats and delegates in the main bodies of this pan-European organization "with immediate effect", in response to the "armed attack" against Ukraine.
This decision excludes the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR, in its French acronym), the judicial arm of the Council of Europe, which will continue to provide protection to Russian citizens, the international organization announced in
statement
.

The decision adopted today by the Committee of Ministers means that requests made against the Russian Federation will continue to be analyzed and decided by the Court.
The suspension of the right to representation in the Committee of Ministers and in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe "is not a final measure, but a temporary one, leaving communication channels open",
The organization also refers to the statement available on its website.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.

The attack was condemned by the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with unprecedented sanctions being approved against Russia.

The Ukrainian President said today that Ukraine is defending itself, lamented that the "most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar" and maintained that international sanctions are insufficient.

"We defend our state alone. The most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar," said Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a speech addressed to the nation, the Ukrainian head of state added: "Did yesterday's sanctions [Thursday] persuade Russia? We feel in our heavens and on our earth that this is not enough."

US President Joe Biden also announced that the United States and allies will reinforce sanctions on Russia and that the NATO device in Germany will be reinforced with US troops.
In the same speech, Zelensky also maintained that "sooner or later" Russia will have to "talk" to Ukraine to put an end to the fighting and denounced that Moscow is also targeting civilian areas.
On the other hand, he praised the Ukrainian "heroism" in the face of the Russian advance.
"Russia will have to talk to us, sooner or later. To talk about how to stop the fighting and stop the invasion. The sooner this conversation starts, the smaller the losses will be for Russia itself", he defended.
The official also stated that the country's defenders frustrated the operational plans of the Russian invasion on the first day.
Russian forces "started bombing civilian areas. This reminds us [of the Nazi offensive in] 1941," said Zelensky, in a video posted on social media, pronouncing the phrase in Russian.
Moscow launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

The War
World
More than 50,000 have left Ukraine since the start of the Russian invasion
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
17:56
0
Comments
Photo EPA
More than 50,000 Ukrainians fled their country in less than 48 hours since the start of the Russian invasion, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees revealed today, who also counted 100,000 displaced people in Ukraine.
"More than 50,000 Ukrainian refugees have fled their country in less than 48 hours -- the majority to Poland and Moldova -- and many more are heading towards the borders," Filippo Grandi wrote on the social network Twitter.
In the message, the UN High Commissioner "warmly thanked the governments and citizens of countries that keep their borders open and welcome refugees."
The Russian invasion that began in the early hours of Thursday threw tens of thousands of Ukrainians onto the roads, heading mainly to Moldova and Poland, but also to Hungary and Romania.
In another message on the same social network, Grandi thanked in particular the President of Moldova, Maia Sandu, "for allowing people fleeing Ukraine to cross the border" with the country "in safety", and assured support from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).
UNHCR, he assured, "will do everything possible to help mobilize international aid while welcoming and receiving" these refugees.
On Thursday, UNHCR reported that at least 100,000 people had already fled their homes in Ukraine due to the invasion initiated by Russia and several thousand had crossed borders into neighboring countries.
Russian President Vladimir Putin launched the invasion of Ukraine early Thursday morning, with air strikes and entry of forces across land borders, including towards the capital Kiev.
Ukrainian forces were today fighting Russian soldiers in the capital Kiev, with the Russian President ignoring Western sanctions and calls to cease military aggression and instead calling on the Ukrainian army to seize power.

The evolution of Zelensky's speeches: from optimism to disillusionment in four¬†days
Before the invasion began, Zelensky assured that the country was "ready for anything." Three days later he asked Europe not to leave him to fight alone. The 7 speeches of the Ukrainian president.
25 Feb 2022, 20:27
Zelensky's 7 speeches since Tuesday
Between Tuesday and this Friday Zelensky has already addressed the country seven times, what has the Ukrainian President's discursive evolution been like?
Notes
Rita Penela
Text
23rd, Tuesday. Russia had not yet invaded Ukrainian territory and Zelensky was meeting the presidents of Lithuania and Poland in Kiev.
"Only me and our army will know the right steps to take in relation to the defense of our State. Believe me, we are ready for anything. It's no secret to anyone that the Budapest Memorandum is not working.
We clearly realize that Ukraine is not part of any security alliance. We will protect Ukraine ourselves, with the support of our partners, but it is the Ukrainians who are dying.
That‚Äôs why Ukraine needs clear, concrete security guarantees right now.‚Äù
At the end of the meeting with his Lithuanian and Polish counterparts, Zelensky said he was certain that Ukraine would fight, in what was still a hypothesis, alone against Russia. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Ukrainians who are dying‚Äù, Zelensky said in the abstract, one of the points of the Ukrainian president‚Äôs speech that changed radically until this Friday. At this point Zelensky already says that
‚ÄúWhen missiles kill our people it is the death of all Europeans‚Äù
.
It is very important to have the support of other partners.
Considering that we currently have 150 thousand Russian troops on the borders, temporarily occupying territories, I believe that the
Russia should be among the countries that must provide us with security guarantees
. It's no secret that I have repeatedly invited the President of Russia to sit at the negotiating table and talk,
because it is a matter of dialogue and not conditions‚Äù
.
The insistence on the path of dialogue has not yet disappeared from the Ukrainian President's interventions. Zelensky appeals for European support, and before the Russian invasion he still stressed that ‚ÄúRussia should be among the countries‚Äù with an obligation to provide security guarantees to neighboring Ukraine. Hours later, the Russian military entered Ukrainian territory.
Day 24, 12:28 pm. Zelensky was speaking at a briefing in his office after an emergency meeting and the Russian invasion
‚ÄúOur soldiers need support, our main focus is the support they need from our population.
We have an army of powerful people, our population is also a powerful army, so support our military
. [‚Ä¶] The enemy has already suffered great losses and will be even greater. They came to our land, Ukraine is under attack from the north, east and south and from the air. Today, the army and national solidarity are the basis of the Ukrainian state.‚Äù
Hours after the Russian invasion, Zelensky spoke to the country for the first time, focusing essentially on Ukrainian citizens. In an attempt to mobilize the population he spoke of ‚Äúthe powerful army‚Äù that the Ukrainian population is and the need to ‚Äúsupport the military‚Äù.
The future of the Ukrainian people depends on each citizen.
Everyone who has combat experience can join the defense of Ukraine and go to the appropriate centers
. The Ministry of Internal Affairs will also call on war veterans to defend the State‚Äù
Even before declaring martial law ‚Äî and consequently preventing all men between the ages of 18 and 60 from leaving Ukrainian territory ‚Äî Zelensky appealed to all citizens ‚Äúwith combat experience‚Äù to join the country's defense. At this time, he was still a President who spoke in a suit shirt and coat, with a closed and concerned expression.
Day 24, 2:13 pm. Less than two hours after the previous declaration to the country
‚ÄúThis morning went down in history, a completely different story for our country and for Russia.
We have cut diplomatic relations with Russia. Ukraine is defending itself and will not give up its freedom, regardless of what Moscow thinks.
For Ukrainians, independence and the right to live on their land in accordance with their values ‚Äã‚Äãis their greatest good. Russia treacherously and self-destructively attacked our State in the morning,
just like Nazi Germany did during World War II.‚Äù
With the advance of the military on Ukrainian soil, Zelensky once again addressed the Ukrainians two hours after the first statement, on the first day of the invasion, to announce that the country had ‚Äúcut diplomatic relations with Russia‚Äù. Speaking about the right to live in Ukraine according to ‚Äúyour values‚Äù and the greater good this is for the population, Zelensky compared the Russian invasion with the expansion of Nazi Germany in World War II.
Day 24, 6:01 pm. In the third intervention of the day, Zelensky appears without a suit, to ask for international help
‚ÄúWhat we hear today is the sound of a new Iron Curtain lowering and closing Russia away from the civilized world. Our national task is to ensure that this curtain passes through the Russians' homes and not ours. [‚Ä¶]
I am in permanent contact with the leaders of partner countries and international organizations.
Russia has already begun to receive the first sanctions of a larger package, the most powerful in world history. [‚Ä¶] Politicians and local leaders, help the people, ensure a normal life on the ground as much as possible. Everyone must take care of their loved ones, neighbors and others in need. The duty of journalists, an important duty, is to defend democracy and freedom in Ukraine.‚Äù
As the hours pass, Zelensky addresses the country again to make it clear that he was in ‚Äúpermanent contact with the leaders of partner countries and international organizations‚Äù and appeals to Ukrainians who can help ‚Äúguarantee a normal life as much as possible‚Äù. Unlike previous interventions, Zelensky now appears without a suit, with an increasingly tired expression and a more burdened expression. Communications to the country are always allegedly made at the official residence of the Head of State, with the same background and just a country flag on the right of the image.
I spoke to many leaders today: the United Kingdom, Turkey, France, Germany, the European Union, the United States, Sweden, Romania, Poland, Austria and others.
If you, dear European and world leaders, leaders of the free world, do not help us today, tomorrow war will knock on your door.
.‚Äù
And after highlighting the most general contacts and appealing for international help, Zelensky moves on to the strategy of warning the international community: what is happening in Ukraine could spread to other countries.
Day 25, 01:10h. Zelensky speaks at the end of the first day of attacks
"I know that there is a lot of false information circulating, particularly that which states that I abandoned Kiev. I stay in the capital, I stay with my people. During the day I held dozens of international conversations, I directly managed our country.
I'm staying in the capital, my family, my children, are also in Ukraine, they are not traitors. My family isn't traitors, but I won't say where they are right now.
According to the information we have, the enemy has marked me as their number one target. My family is number two.
They want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state
.‚Äù
In the early hours of this Friday, the Ukrainian President spoke to the country to say that he knows that he is Putin's ‚Äúnumber one target‚Äù and that both he and his family are the target of the Russians. With martial law already decreed, Zelensky uses the word ‚Äútraitor‚Äù to say that he will not leave Ukraine, in a statement that also serves the purpose of reaching Ukrainians who may have chosen to leave the country and not stay to help fight the Russian military.
No matter how many conversations I had with leaders from different countries today, I heard several things. The first is that we will have support.
I am grateful to every state that will help Ukraine in concrete, not just in words. But there is another thing: we were left alone in defending our State. Who is ready to fight with us? Honestly, I don't see any.
Who is willing to guarantee Ukraine's membership in NATO? Honestly, everyone is scared.‚Äù
With the Russian invasion and the lack of military personnel from third countries on the country's territory, Zelensky chooses to highlight this in the last speech he gives in the early hours of the first day of the war.
Today I asked Europe's 27 leaders whether Ukraine will be accepted into NATO. I asked directly, everyone is afraid and doesn't respond.
We are not afraid of anything. We are not afraid to defend our State. We are not afraid of Russia, we are not afraid to talk to Russia, we are not afraid to say everything about security guarantees for our state. We are not afraid to talk about our neutral status.
We are not in NATO at the moment, but the main thing is to know what security guarantees we have. Which countries will give it to us? We need to talk about an end to this invasion, about a ceasefire
.‚Äù
Zelensky still tries to leave open the possibility of joining NATO, stressing that ‚Äúat this moment‚Äù the country is not part of the Alliance. He calls for answers to be given about this integration and the defense guarantees that Ukraine has. The leader of Ukraine says that the 27 namesakes in Europe ‚Äúare afraid‚Äù and refuse to respond, but he wants security guarantees from the countries that make up the European Union. In the last speech of the day, Zelensky put more pressure on European leaders, already looking for concrete answers, but the tone would be even more intense on the second day of the war against Russia.
Day 25, 07:27h. Zelensky speaks on the morning of the second day, visibly more haggard, tired and with swollen eyes.
‚Äú
They say that the civilian area is not a target, but that is a lie. In fact, they do not distinguish in which areas they operate. There were terrible explosions in the sky this morning over Kiev, bombers, they hit a house, there was a fire. All this reminds me of the first
attack of this type on our capital, which occurred in 1941.
This morning
we are defending our State alone, as we did yesterday. The most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar
. Did yesterday's sanctions convince Russia? We hear in our heavens and see on our earth that it is insufficient.
Foreign troops are trying to be even more active in our territory.
Only the solidarity and determination of Ukrainians can preserve our freedom and protect the state.
‚Äú
Similar to what he had done the previous day, Zelensky recovers moments from the history of humanity to try to draw parallels with the current situation. After talking about the invasion of Nazi Germany, this morning he revisited the Battle of Kiev in 1941, when Hitler attacked the Ukrainian capital. Then, the Ukrainian President emphasizes that the sanctions announced the previous day had no effect on Russian military actions and says that the troops became even more active on this second day of the invasion. The one who appears in his first address to the country of the day is a visibly more upset president.
Day 25, 1:07 pm. In the middle of the second day of the invasion, Zelensky speaks to the country again solely to put pressure on Europe
‚ÄúGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz said yesterday that Russia's invasion of Ukraine is something Europe has not seen for 75 years. And it's true, but it's not the whole truth.
This is not just Russia's invasion of Ukraine, this is the beginning of the war against Europe, against the unity of Europe, against elementary human rights in Europe and all the rules of coexistence on the continent.
Against the fact that European states refuse to divide borders by force.‚Äù
If until now the central issue was Ukraine, from this address to the nation, Zelensky starts to treat the issue as an attack on Europe as a whole. The President of Ukraine says the attack on his country is the beginning of the war against Europe and the unity of the continent, in an attempt to gain greater support from the EU.
Ukrainian cities suffer bombings for the second day. The columns of
Tanks and air attacks are similar to what Europe saw a long time ago, during World War II and said ‚Äúnever again‚Äù to such a situation. But that's it! Again, now. In 2022. 75 after the end of World War II. I believe you see, all of you, all of Europe
. But we don't see what they're going to do.
How are they going to protect themselves when they help Ukraine so slowly?
In a criticism of Europe's stance, which Zelensky says has left Ukraine isolated in the face of the Russians, the country's President accuses the 27 of being ‚Äúslow‚Äù in responding. Once again, Zelensky resorts to World War II to try to mobilize Europeans in favor of Ukraine.
I would like to highlight what has already happened.
And we are grateful for that, these are sectoral sanctions.
The United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, the European Union, Australia and New Zealand have enacted sectoral sanctions against Russia, particularly the largest banks. Against Russia's access to Western technologies. But Russian tanks are still firing at residential buildings in our cities. Armored cars are still attacking civilians, including ordinary Ukrainian citizens.
Europe has enough strength to stop this aggression. What else will European states expect?
Cancellation of visas for Russians? Hack SWIFT? Completely isolate Russia? Withdraw ambassadors? Oil embargo? Close airspace? Today, all of this should be on the table, because it is a threat to all of us, to the whole of Europe
. They can still stop the aggression, but it is necessary to act without delay.‚Äù
Aware that NATO and European Union countries would meet this Friday to decide on the sanctions package against Russia, Zelensky presented Ukraine's requests a few hours before the start of the meetings: canceling visas for Russian citizens, placing Russia out of SWIFT, embargoing oil or closing European airspace to Russian planes, for example. In a last-minute request, putting everything on the table and in front of the television cameras, Zelensky calls for ‚Äúaction without delay‚Äù.
When bombs fall on Kiev, it's Europe, not just Ukraine.
When missiles kill our people it is the death of all Europeans. Ask for more protection for Europe, more protection for Ukraine, as part of the democratic world.
While the European institutions are in no rush to impose really strong decisions, all Europeans in the various capitals can come to our embassy and offer help. Demand greater financial and military assistance from governments for Ukraine, because this aid is also help for you as it is help for the whole of Europe, you are helping yourself.‚Äù
Bluntly, Zelensky completely shifts the needle from what was centered on the Ukrainian population to the population of the European continent. He doesn't want to be alone in facing Russia and completely changes the speech he had the day before the Russian invasion. The focus now is on the European population and the damage the Russians can do at that level. Putting things on a transnational plane Zelensky intends to increase solidarity between States and the chances of receiving military reinforcement to combat Russian troops.

Home

Portuguese Swimming Federation cancels trips to Ukraine
Portuguese Swimming Federation cancels trips to Ukraine
Share
on Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Email
Share
Ant√≥nio Silva, president of the Portuguese Swimming Federation
Share
on Facebook
Writing with Lusa
25¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†15:17
Russia's invasion of Ukrainian territory is the basis of the organization's decision. "We are forced to condemn all types of violence and we will cancel all trips", said Ant√≥nio Silva
This Friday, the Portuguese Swimming Federation (FPN) expressed support and solidarity with athletes from Ukraine and announced that, for security reasons, it will cancel all initiatives that involve the movement of athletes to at-risk territory.
Related
Modalities.
IOC calls for cancellation or change of venue for sporting events in Russia
Modalities.
Beijing'2022: Two-time Swedish champion donates medal to daughter of detained Chinese dissident
In a statement, the president of the FPN says that the organization has already contacted the Ukrainian federation, "as well as with the international goalkeeper of the Portugal national team Nicolai Yanochko and the open water Olympian Arsenie Lavrentyev, in order to make all its resources available to support athletes in aquatic disciplines during this period".
Ant√≥nio Silva, who also presides over the European Swimming League (LEN), said he was "very concerned about the events taking place in Ukraine", adding: "We are developing a series of contacts and actions to alleviate the suffering of the Ukrainian population and athletes in particular. We are forced to condemn all types of violence and we will cancel all trips to territories at risk."
Nikolai Yanochko, water polo goalkeeper of Ukrainian origin and international for the Portugal national team, said he had already expressed solidarity with his Ukrainian colleagues and "availability to help with whatever they need. Including welcoming athletes in difficult situations caused by war".
Arsenie Lavrentyev, naturalized Portuguese in 2008, was born in Russia, but lived in Ukraine from the age of five to 23, also condemned the bombings and considered that "Russia has to stop what it is doing".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The War
Country
'Gold' visas attract investment of 277.8 ME from Russia and 32.5 ME from Kiev
Feb 25, 2022
09:47
0
Comments
Investment from Russia captured by the 'gold' visa program totals more than 277.8 million euros in nine years and that from Ukraine totals 32.5 million euros, according to SEF data requested by Lusa.
In total, since the Residence Permit for Investment Activity (ARI) program was launched, 431 'gold' visas have been granted to Russian citizens, which corresponds to an investment of 277,811,929.38 euros, according to the Foreigners and Borders Service (SEF).
"Ukrainian citizens were allocated 51 ARI, implying an investment of 32,547,593.49 euros", according to the same source.
This year, seven 'golden' visas have been granted to Russian citizens.
Last year, 65 ARIs were granted to Russia, totaling 33,608,503.58 euros, compared to 63 'gold' visas granted in 2020, totaling 37,730,418.17 euros.
Also in 2020, seven Ukrainian citizens obtained residence permits for investment activities, worth 3,7979,500 euros.
With regard to the job creation criterion, Ukraine was responsible for 11 jobs in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãcomputer consultancy and programming in Lisbon and Russia for 11 jobs in Set√∫bal, in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãhotels and restaurants.
Since the ARI grant program was launched in October 2012, 6,147,874,500.99 euros have been raised through this instrument. Of this amount, the majority corresponds to the purchase of real estate, which until January totaled 5,545,982,427.40 euros, with the acquisition for urban rehabilitation totaling 376,804,564.85 euros.
The investment resulting from the capital transfer is 601,892,073.59 euros.

translated_text:
The War
World
Pope publishes 'tweet' in Russian and states that 'every war is a shameful capitulation'
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
21:46
0
Comments
Pope Francis, regarding the Russian military offensive in Ukraine, said today that "any war is a shameful capitulation", in a tweet published and translated into several languages, including Russian, which is rare.
"Any war leaves the world worse off than in the state in which it found it. War is always a failure of politics and humanity, a shameful capitulation, a defeat in the face of the forces of evil", writes the pope, in a passage from his encyclical on peace "Fratelli tutti" (all brothers) published in 2020.
The tweets, also published in the account's usual languages (Italian, Portuguese, Polish, French, English, Spanish, German and Arabic), are accompanied by the hashtags #PrionsEnsemble and #Ukraine.
Pope Francis went to the Russian Embassy in the Holy See this morning to express "his concern" on the second day of the military offensive in Ukraine by Russian troops, an also exceptional gesture for the Argentine pontiff who never goes to foreign representations, but receives diplomats accredited at the Vatican.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

√≥s estamos preocupados com as m√∫ltiplas deten√ß√µes arbitr√°rias de manifestantes na R√∫ssia que, na quinta-feira, estavam a protestar", disse a porta-voz do OHCHR (siga em ingl√™s), Ravina Shamdasani, numa confer√™ncia de imprensa em Genebra.
"N√≥s sabemos que mais de 1.800 manifestantes foram detidos. N√£o ficou claro se algum deles j√° foi libertado", acrescentou.
A porta-voz sublinhou que "a deten√ß√£o de pessoas que exercem o seu direito √† liberdade de express√£o ou de reuni√£o pac√≠fica constitui uma priva√ß√£o arbitr√°ria de liberdade".
"N√≥s apelamos √†s autoridades que garantam a liberta√ß√£o imediata de todos os detidos arbitrariamente por exercerem esses direitos", disse Ravina Shamdasani.
A Alta Comiss√°ria das Na√ß√µes Unidas para os Direitos Humanos, Michelle Bachelet, disse na quinta-feira que a invas√£o russa da Ucr√¢nia foi "claramente uma viola√ß√£o da lei internacional, colocando in√∫meras vidas civis em risco".
"Esta invas√£o deve ser imediatamente interrompida", declarou Michelle Bachelet num comunicado.
O OHCHR tem, por enquanto, funcion√°rios na Ucr√¢nia que continuam a monitorar a situa√ß√£o dos direitos humanos.
A R√∫ssia lan√ßou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucr√¢nia, com for√ßas terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em v√°rias cidades, que j√° provocaram pelo menos mais de 120 mortos, incluindo civis, e centenas de feridos, em territ√≥rio ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 100.000 deslocados no primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "opera√ß√£o militar especial" na Ucr√¢nia visa "desmilitarizar e desnazificar" o seu vizinho e que era a √∫nica maneira de o pa√≠s se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durar√° o tempo necess√°rio, dependendo de seus "resultados" e "relev√¢ncia".
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuni√µes de emerg√™ncia de v√°rios governos, incluindo o portugu√™s, e da Organiza√ß√£o do Tratado do Atl√¢ntico Norte (NATO), Uni√£o Europeia (UE) e Conselho de Seguran√ßa da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas san√ß√µes em massa contra a R√∫ssia.

translated_text:
"N
We are concerned about the multiple arbitrary arrests of demonstrators in Russia who, on Thursday, were protesting," said OHCHR spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani at a press conference in Geneva.
"We know that more than 1,800 protesters have been detained. It is not clear whether any of them have been released yet," he added.
The spokesperson stressed that "the detention of people exercising their right to freedom of expression or peaceful assembly constitutes an arbitrary deprivation of liberty."
"We call on authorities to ensure the immediate release of all those arbitrarily detained for exercising these rights," said Ravina Shamdasani.
United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights Michelle Bachelet said Thursday that Russia's invasion of Ukraine was "clearly a violation of international law, putting countless civilian lives at risk."
"This invasion must be stopped immediately," said Michelle Bachelet in a statement.
OHCHR currently has staff in Ukraine who continue to monitor the human rights situation.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

"The
Russia's unprovoked attack against Ukraine, using cyber and military weapons, violates international law and the fundamental human rights of the Ukrainian people," Carter said in a statement published on the social network Twitter.

For Bill Clinton, "the world will hold Russia and Russia alone accountable, economically and politically, for this blatant violation of international law."
On Wednesday, former US President Donald Trump stated that the Russian military operation in Ukraine was "a very sad thing for the world" and during his administration, he argued in an interview with the Fox television channel, it would not have happened. A day earlier, during a radio program, Trump had praised the dismemberment of independent, democratic and sovereign Ukraine, decided by Putin, considering it a "genius act".
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and 'denazify'" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

Muitos n√£o acreditaram, quase at√© ao fim (neles me incluo), que a R√∫ssia pudesse lan√ßar um ataque em larga escala contra a Ucr√¢nia, pela especial irracionalidade da decis√£o, pelas consequ√™ncias dram√°ticas que esta decis√£o vai importar para aquele pa√≠s, para o seu povo e para a paz internacional.
Das declara√ß√µes sucessivas de Vladimir Putin resulta que, afinal, a invas√£o da Ucr√¢nia n√£o existe. Trata-se, isso sim (como ali√°s reafirmou o representante russo no Conselho de Seguran√ßa), de uma "a√ß√£o militar especial", para enfrentar a amea√ßa que a Ucr√¢nia representa para a seguran√ßa russa (!), desnazificar o
regime ucraniano (!) e, finalmente, ajudar, a t√≠tulo de leg√≠tima defesa coletiva, as "rep√∫blicas" populares de Donetsk e Lugansk, reconhecidas h√° dias.
T√≠nhamos as "fake news", e continuamos a t√™-las; mas h√° que acrescentar-lhes a "fake law". √â impressionante como a manipula√ß√£o do Direito, como poucas vezes no passado, √© realizada para
promover as mais graves viola√ß√µes desse Direito - e, reconhe√ßa-se, o l√≠der russo tem-se mostrado ex√≠mio nesse exerc√≠cio.
Desde 2014, e apenas para me referir √† Ucr√¢nia, violentou o direito de autodetermina√ß√£o dos povos (abusando-o para anexar a Crimeia), a prote√ß√£o dos direitos humanos (alegando, a ro√ßar o absurdo, genoc√≠dio contra a popula√ß√£o russa ou russ√≥fona do leste ucraniano) e a legitima√ß√£o para o uso da for√ßa (com base no pedido de "aux√≠lio" feito pelas duas entidades secessionistas de Donetsk e Lugansk), declarando estar a agir ao abrigo da Carta das Na√ß√µes Unidas.
Poder√° ser contestado este diagn√≥stico com o facto (comprov√°vel) de que nunca um agressor assumiu s√™-lo, e n√£o poucas vezes at√© se justificou das formas mais contradit√≥rias. Mas, aqui, a pr√≥pria constru√ß√£o da realidade junta "fake news" e "fake law". De facto, a pr√≥pria sequ√™ncia dos factos √© irreal, e isso √© indubit√°vel: grava√ß√µes feitas v√°rios dias antes, declara√ß√µes de um Chefe de Estado que √© poss√≠vel provar terem sido feitas antes, com absoluta premedita√ß√£o, ou a gaffe de um alto respons√°vel que, aterrorizado perante o chefe, diz defender a incorpora√ß√£o do Donbass na R√∫ssia e desnuda a verdade.
PUB
O que n√£o √© "fake", muito infelizmente, √© a realidade que temos perante n√≥s. E, nessa realidade, n√£o consigo deixar de pensar, sobretudo, nos milh√µes que fogem perante o agressor, na popula√ß√£o civil que est√° hoje obrigada a deixar o seu lar e a iniciar um caminho que sabemos onde e como come√ßa, mas n√£o como poder√° terminar em seguran√ßa.
*Professor da Faculdade de Direito da UCP Porto

jos√© alberto azeredo lopes

Share
Many did not believe, almost until the end (myself included), that Russia could launch a large-scale attack against Ukraine, due to the particular irrationality of the decision, due to the dramatic consequences that this decision will have for that country, for its people and for international peace.
It follows from Vladimir Putin's successive statements that, after all, the invasion of Ukraine does not exist. This is indeed (as the Russian representative in the Security Council reaffirmed), a "special military action", to face the threat that Ukraine poses to Russian security (!), denazifying the
Ukrainian regime (!) and, finally, help, by way of collective self-defense, the people's "republics" of Donetsk and Luhansk, recognized a few days ago.
We had "fake news", and we continue to have it; but we must add the "fake law" to them. It is impressive how the manipulation of the Law, like few times in the past, is carried out to
promote the most serious violations of this Right - and, admittedly, the Russian leader has shown himself to be excellent in this exercise.
Since 2014, and just to refer to Ukraine, it has violated the people's right to self-determination (abusing it to annex Crimea), the protection of human rights (alleging, almost absurdly, genocide against the Russian or Russophone population of eastern Ukraine) and the legitimization of the use of force (based on the request for "aid" made by the two secessionist entities of Donetsk and Luhansk), declaring that it is to act under the Charter of the United Nations.
This diagnosis can be challenged with the (provable) fact that an aggressor has never admitted to being an aggressor, and not a few times he has even justified himself in the most contradictory ways. But here, the very construction of reality brings together "fake news" and "fake law". In fact, the sequence of events itself is unreal, and this is beyond doubt: recordings made several days before, statements by a Head of State that can be proven to have been made before, with absolute premeditation, or the gaffe of a senior official who, terrified in front of his leader, claims to defend the incorporation of Donbass into Russia and exposes the truth.
PUB
What is not "fake", unfortunately, is the reality we have before us. And, in this reality, I can't help but think, above all, about the millions who flee before the aggressor, about the civilian population who are today forced to leave their home and begin a path that we know where and how it begins, but not how it can end safely.
*Professor at the Faculty of Law at UCP Porto

The United States announced today that it will impose economic sanctions on Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in retaliation for the invasion of Ukraine.
"The United States will join (the European Union) in sanctioning Putin, Foreign Minister Lavrov and the rest of the Russian security team," White House spokeswoman Jen Psaki said at her daily briefing.
Washington's sanctions come after the European Union announced today the freezing of Putin and Lavrov's financial assets on European territory.
After months of tensions, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

And
n statements following an extraordinary summit of EU heads of state and government held in Brussels to discuss the European response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Ant√≥nio Costa pointed out that "NATO will certainly give [today] the response in the sense of deterrence and guaranteeing the defense of all NATO countries, and in particular those that have a border with Ukraine or are close to the border with Ukraine".
"The EU is not a military organization and, therefore, what we approved today was the endorsement of a proposal that the European Commission presented", for a second package of sanctions, to be adopted by foreign ministers at a meeting today in Brussels, he said.
The package, Costa pointed out, contains tough sanctions "which aim to hit in particular the financial sector, the energy sector, the transport sector, limit the international financing capacity of Russian state companies and the Russian State, and also limit the granting of visas to holders of diplomatic or service passports".
Asked whether Ukraine is not being left alone in the face of Russian aggression, Costa stressed that "the response the Council gave was financial support, humanitarian support, support for Ukraine", in addition to "a set of very harsh measures in relation to Russia and a group of Russian and Belarusian personalities", and "at the same time, in NATO, measures will be adopted with a view to dissuasive action".
"Therefore, the solidarity that the EU can express translated into the extent to which the EU can act. As is known, the EU is not an organization of a military nature, therefore it naturally cannot provide military support to Ukraine", he reiterated.
NATO, he recalled, "is a defensive Alliance", which has "a duty of solidarity towards all member countries of the Alliance - Ukraine is not a member country of the Alliance -, and NATO naturally cannot act outside its own territory and without being in defense of its members", but several EU member states "have been providing bilateral support to Ukraine, including military support, with the provision of lethal and non-lethal material".

The heads of government and state of the European Union (EU) reached an agreement this morning on "massive sanctions" that will be "painful for the Russian regime", the president of the European Council announced today.

The decision was taken at an urgent summit in Brussels of EU heads of government and state, including the Portuguese Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, on which European leaders had "the opportunity to reaffirm the firm position, this hand in conjunction with our allies and friends", given the Russian invasion of several Ukrainian cities.

Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".

translated_text:
The War
World
Council of Europe suspends Russia's representation rights
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
16:35
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Council of Europe decided today to "suspend" the participation of Russian diplomats and delegates in the main bodies of this pan-European organization "with immediate effect", in response to the "armed attack" against Ukraine.
This decision excludes the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR, its French acronym), the judicial arm of the Council of Europe, which will continue to provide protection to Russian citizens, the international organization announced in a statement.
The decision adopted today by the Committee of Ministers means that requests made against the Russian Federation will continue to be analyzed and decided by the Court.
The suspension of the right to representation in the Committee of Ministers and in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe "is not a final measure, but a temporary one, leaving communication channels open", the organization also states in the statement available on its website.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
The Russian President said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on the "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with unprecedented sanctions being approved against Russia.

A
Deputy Minister of Defense of Ukraine, Hanna Malyar, this Friday, in the early afternoon, took stock of the losses that have already occurred since the start of the war.
In a post made on Facebook, the Ukrainian authority states that approximately 2,800 Russian soldiers have been killed in fighting so far.
In the same message, the deputy minister also says that Ukrainian forces destroyed around 80 Russian tanks, 516 armored combat vehicles, 10 aircraft and seven helicopters by 3 pm local time (1 pm in mainland Portugal).
"We are strong! The victory will be ours!", he concluded.
It is recalled that Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine this Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, thus starting the war in Ukraine.
The offensive has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported last night that 100,000 were displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said the "special military operation" in Ukraine aimed to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way the country could defend itself. How long this invasion will last is uncertain, with the Kremlin stating that it will depend on its "results" and "relevance", without specifying exactly what the objectives are.
The attack was vehemently condemned by most of the international community. Emergency meetings were held between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council.

mass sanctions against Russia but also specifically against Putin and Lavrov
.

1,800 protesters were detained in Russia
for speaking out against the war.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky lamented this Friday that Europe's response to the Russian invasion is being too slow and invited Europeans with combat experience to travel to Ukraine and repel the Russian army.
"How are you going to defend yourselves if you are so slow to help Ukraine?"
, asked Volodymyr Zelensky, in a communication to international journalists, in which he criticized the European response to the ongoing Russian invasion.
"Cancel visas for Russians? Disconnection from SWIFT (interbank network)? Total isolation of Russia? Call of ambassadors? Oil embargo? Today, everything must be done, because this is a threat to all of us, to the whole of Europe"
, asked Zelensky.

"Europe is strong enough to resist this aggression"
, Zelensky stressed, at a time when Russian troops continue to advance into various parts of Ukrainian territory.
Volodymyr Zelensky also asked Europeans to have combat skills to move to Ukrainian territory, taking up arms against the Russian invasion.
"If they have combat experience (...) they can come to our country, to defend Europe"
, said Zelensky.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The War
World
Ukraine regrets that it is defending itself against Russia
Zelensky considers sanctions to be insufficient
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
08:08
0
Comments
The Ukrainian President said today that Ukraine is defending itself, lamented that the "most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar" and maintained that international sanctions are insufficient.
"We defend our state alone. The most powerful forces in the world are watching from afar," said Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a speech addressed to the nation, the Ukrainian head of state added: "Did yesterday's sanctions [Thursday] persuade Russia? We feel in our heavens and on our earth that this is not enough."
The heads of Government and State of the European Union European Union agreed on sanctions that will be formally adopted today, at an extraordinary Council of Foreign Ministers, in Brussels.
US President Joe Biden also announced that the United States and allies will reinforce sanctions on Russia and that the NATO device in Germany will be reinforced with US troops.
In the same speech, Zelensky also maintained that "sooner or later" Russia will have to "talk" to Ukraine to put an end to the fighting and denounced that Moscow is also targeting civilian areas.
On the other hand, he praised the Ukrainian "heroism" in the face of the Russian advance.
"Russia will have to talk to us, sooner or later. To talk about how to stop the fighting and stop the invasion. The sooner this conversation starts, the smaller the losses will be for Russia itself", he defended.
The official also stated that the country's defenders frustrated the operational plans of the Russian invasion on the first day.
Russian forces "started bombing civilian areas. This reminds us [of the Nazi offensive in] 1941," said Zelensky, in a video posted on social media, pronouncing the phrase in Russian.
Moscow launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

"C
We consider violating the territorial integrity of any country, including Ukraine, to be very wrong. Serbia offers full support in principle for the territorial integrity of Ukraine, said Aleksandar Vucic, speaking to the press after a meeting of the National Security Council.

Vucic recalled that Russia did not impose sanctions on Serbia in the 1990s during the wars in the former Yugoslavia and that the Kremlin defends Serbian interests in international institutions.
Russia, a member of the UN Security Council, is Serbia's main ally in the position of not recognizing the independence of its former province of Kosovo.
Vucic recalled that Ukraine also does not recognize Kosovo's independence.
The President warned that the government would prohibit Serbian citizens from participating as "volunteers" in the conflict, while promising all types of humanitarian aid to the Ukrainian people.
Vucic also indicated that Serbia, as a country that maintains military neutrality, will suspend for some time all activities and exercises planned by its Army and Ministry of the Interior with foreign partners.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The Prime Minister of Poland, Mateusz Morawiecki, announced this Friday that Polish airspace will be closed to Russian planes, which will prevent them from taking off or landing in the country.
"I have ordered the preparation of a resolution by the council of ministers that will lead to the closure of Polish airspace to Russian aviation companies," Morawiecki wrote in a brief message on his Facebook account.
On Thursday, the United Kingdom banned Aeroflot planes from landing on its territory, in reaction to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and Moldova adopted a similar measure.
In retaliation, Russian civil aviation agency Rosaviation announced today that flights to or from the United Kingdom will not be able to use its airspace.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on three fronts in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused more than 120 deaths on Ukrainian territory, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Syrian President Bashar al-Assad today welcomed Russia's invasion of Ukraine in a telephone conversation with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, calling it a "correction of History".
"President Assad¬†underlined that what is currently happening is a 'correction of History' and the reestablishment of the balance of the international order after the end of the Soviet Union," the Syrian presidency said in a statement.
The Syrian head of state also said that "Syria is on Russia's side", adding that "facing NATO enlargement is Moscow's right".
Bashar¬†al-Assad considered the Atlantic Alliance to be a ‚Äúglobal threat‚Äù endowed with¬†‚Äútools that implement the irresponsible policies of Western countries aimed at destabilizing the world.‚Äù
Damascus is an ally of the Moscow regime. Russia has intervened¬†militarily in Syria since 2015, in support of the Assad government against rebels and 'jihadists'.
According to Moscow, around 63,000 Russian soldiers are fighting in Syria.
"Western nations are responsible for the chaos and bloodshed", said the president of Syria in the same telephone contact he had with Vladimir Putin today.
The war in Syria has been ongoing since 2011 and has caused nearly 500,000 deaths.
The Burmese military junta, which came to power a year ago after a coup d'√©tat, also expressed its support for Russia in the invasion of Ukraine, considering that in this way Moscow "consolidates its sovereignty" and "shows the world that it is a global power".
Speaking to Voice of America (VOA) Burma, General Zaw Min Tun, spokesman for the coup regime, stated that the military attack against Ukraine is "the right decision" and that "Russia is working to consolidate its sovereignty".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began on Thursday, the United Nations has received reports of at least 25 civilians killed following bombings and air strikes on the country. According to Sky News, figures from the same entity report 102 civilians injured following the invasion.
Even so, the same source recognizes that this number could be much higher, given that there are many casualties that may not have been accounted for so far.
For its part, Ukraine had already reported that, after the first day of clashes, the number of people who lost their lives (from soldiers to civilians) was at least 137, while 316 people had been injured.
After Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a "special operation" on Ukrainian territory, several cities in that country suffered incursions by the Russians. This is the case of Kharkiv, Mariupol, Odessa and, finally, Kiev.
However, the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, has already said that he has reason to believe that he himself is Russia's "number one target", followed by his family members.

The War
World
NATO expansionism is a threat to stability and security
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
08:09
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/IRANIAN PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE
Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi stated on Thursday night that NATO's expansionism is a threat to the stability and security of independent countries in a conversation with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin.
"The continued expansion of NATO is a serious threat to the stability and security of independent countries in various regions," Raisi said in a telephone conversation with Putin, released by the Iranian Presidency.
"I hope that what is happening will benefit the people of the region," added the Iranian leader, after Russia launched a large-scale military operation against Ukraine.
Iran has sought political and economic allies in China and Russia in recent years.
In late January, the three countries held joint naval exercises in the Indian Ocean "to reinforce security in the region."
Raisi's remarks continue the Persian country's official policy, which throughout the week blamed NATO and the United States for tensions in Ukraine.
"The crisis in Ukraine has its origins in NATO's provocations," said Iranian Foreign Minister Hosein Amir Abdolahian.
The head of Iranian diplomacy called for a ceasefire and a political and democratic resolution.
Moscow launched a military offensive on Ukrainian territory early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least fifty deaths, 10 of them civilians, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was immediately condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council.

translated_text:
World
Boris Johnson and Northern allies believe ‚Äúmore sanctions‚Äù are necessary
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
16:11
0
Comments
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Northern European allies agreed today that "more sanctions" are needed against Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, particularly the "close circle" of Russian President Vladimir Putin.
After a call between Boris Johnson and his allies from the Joint Expeditionary Force (JEF), which brings together ten states, including the Baltics, "the leaders agreed that more sanctions are necessary, focusing above all on¬†President Putin's close circle."
"Added support must be given to Ukraine with all urgency", insisted Boris Johnson, quoted by France-Presse (AFP), adding that "President Putin's harmful acts can never be normalized and his aggression against Ukraine taken as a fait accompli".
Founded in 2012, the JEF brings together NATO member countries (Denmark, Estonia, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Norway and the United Kingdom) and non-member countries (Sweden and Finland), focusing on security in the "great North" around the Arctic, the North Atlantic and the Baltic Sea.
At a meeting of its defense ministers on Wednesday, the JEF announced future maneuvers in the Baltic Sea to demonstrate "freedom of movement" in that strategic zone.
Previously, Boris Johnson held a call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and promised to reinforce support for Ukraine.
London excludes any sending of British soldiers to fight Russian soldiers, but says it is ready to supply defensive weapons.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on three fronts in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused more than 120 deaths on Ukrainian territory, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
President Zelensky regrets that European response is "slow"
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
13:34
0
Comments
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today lamented that Europe's response to the Russian invasion is being too slow and invited Europeans with combat experience to travel to Ukraine and repel the Russian army.
‚ÄúHow are you going to defend yourselves if you are so slow to help Ukraine?‚Äù asked Volodymyr Zelensky, in a speech to international journalists, in which he criticized the European response to the ongoing Russian invasion.
"Cancel visas for Russians? Disconnection from SWIFT (interbank network)? Total isolation of Russia? Call of ambassadors? Oil embargo? Today, everything must be done, because this is a threat to all of us, to the whole of Europe", asked Zelensky.
"Europe is strong enough to resist this aggression", stressed Zelensky, at a time when Russian troops continue to advance into several parts of Ukrainian territory.
Volodymyr Zelensky also asked Europeans to have combat skills to move to Ukrainian territory, taking up arms against the Russian invasion.
"If they have combat experience (...) they can come to our country, to defend Europe," said Zelensky.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
EU diplomacy chiefs with agreement to sanction Putin and minister Lavrov
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
17:40
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The heads of European Union (EU) diplomacy today reached an agreement to sanction Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, with a freeze on financial assets, following the invasion of Ukraine.
The information was announced today by the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, at a press conference in Brussels, at the end of an extraordinary meeting with his EU counterparts.
Santos Silva indicated that "this package expands the list of Russian personalities, natural persons and entities subject to sanctions, extending it to the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, as well as the Prime Minister, of Defense which was already included, the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of the Interior".
According to the head of Portuguese diplomacy, in the case of Putin and Lavrov, the "freezing of their respective financial assets" is at stake.
This is a second package of massive sanctions, decided by the 27 in the face of the invasion of Ukraine, after a first one formally adopted on Wednesday. This first package contained the name of the Russian Defense Minister, Sergei Shoigu.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The Prime Minister of Poland, Mateusz Morawiecki, announced today that Polish airspace will be closed to Russian planes, which will prevent them from taking off or landing in the country.
"I have ordered the preparation of a resolution by the council of ministers that will lead to the closure of Polish airspace to Russian aviation companies," Morawiecki wrote in a brief message on his Facebook account.
On Thursday, the United Kingdom banned Aeroflot planes from landing on its territory, in reaction to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and Moldova adopted a similar measure.
In retaliation, Russian civil aviation agency Rosaviation announced today that flights to or from the United Kingdom will not be able to use its airspace.
On Thursday morning, Russia launched a military offensive on three fronts in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused more than 120 deaths on Ukrainian territory, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Home

Borrell and Santos Silva deplore Russia's "obscene" attack on Guterres
The head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, and the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, deplored in Brussels Russia's recent verbal attacks on the UN Secretary General, with Portugal showing solidarity with Ant√≥nio Guterres
Ant√≥nio Guterres, UN Secretary-General

.In statements to the press at the end of an extraordinary meeting of EU heads of diplomacy, at which a second package of sanctions was adopted against Moscow for the military aggression against Ukraine,
Santos Silva made a point of "expressing Portugal's solidarity with the United Nations and the Secretary-General of the United Nations, who has been the victim in recent hours of an absolutely unfounded and obscene personal attack by disinformation campaigns orchestrated from Russia."
The EU High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy, who presides over the Council of Foreign Affairs Ministers of the 27, also addressed the issue at the final press conference, after announcing the inclusion of Russian President Vladimir Putin himself and the head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov, on the EU sanctions list.
"Putin launched a war against a neighbor during an emergency session of the United Nations Security Council on Ukraine. It shows the respect that Russia has for this institution. And now they are even verbally attacking the secretary general!"
Borrell exclaimed.
