The head of European diplomacy, in an indignant tone, reinforced that "the Secretary General of the United Nations is being attacked by Russia for speaking in favor of peace and respect for international rules".
Last Wednesday, Lavrov accused Ant√≥nio Guterres of having succumbed to pressure from the West by making statements about the situation in Ukraine that "are not in accordance with his status" as secretary-general of the United Nations.
Santos Silva also welcomed "the decision taken today at the Council of Europe to immediately suspend Russia from all activities of the Council of Europe, because it is the body created in Europe to promote democracy, human rights and the rule of law, and therefore an aggressor Russia, a Russia that so blatantly ignores the minimum rules of civilized behavior between nations has no place in the Council of Europe".
The Portuguese minister commented that the ongoing political effort to isolate Russia internationally, particularly at the level of the United Nations general assembly, is "very, very important", but added that "the economic sanctions that hurt", like those adopted today by the 27, "are also very important, because, clearly, President Putin only seems to understand the language of force".
Tensions between the West and Russia intensified after, last Thursday in the early hours of the morning, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, in Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Hungary, which borders Ukraine to the west, has in the past taken a firm stance against all forms of immigration and has refused to accept refugees and asylum seekers from the Middle East, Africa and Asia.
However, the Government published, on Thursday night, a decree that opens the country's doors to Ukrainians and citizens of third countries legally residing in Ukraine, which allows, for example, Belarusian refugees living in Ukraine to receive protection in the European Union.
Prime Minister, ultranationalist Viktor Orban, said that Hungary will not participate in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but that it will accept refugees who arrive at its borders.
Several European countries, especially those closest to Ukraine, are already receiving or are preparing to receive thousands of refugees, following the Russian attack that began in the early hours of Thursday on three fronts in that country.
In Hungary, which has a 136-kilometer land border with Ukraine, warnings about the possible arrival of thousands of refugees in the country in the event of war have been going on for several days and, on Thursday, public television reported that many young people were already on their way.
Viktor Orb√°n considered that the wave of refugees from this war will be worse than that caused by the wars of the 1990s in the former Yugoslavia.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
"Russia's military incursion into Ukraine will have a high human and economic price", defended Dietmar Hornung, in a written response to Lusa.
The head of Moody's also highlighted that the additional and more severe sanctions on Russia "will weigh even more" on the already low economic growth potential of the country led by Vladimir Putin.
On Thursday, Moody's Analytics promoted a webinar on the Russia-Ukraine conflict and its impact on the global economy, where it envisaged two possible scenarios: one in which the conflict has a quick resolution (probability of 55%) and another in which it continues over time (probability of 30%).
In both cases, Moody's Analytics predicts pressure on prices in European gas markets, which will drive the rise in inflation in the euro zone. However, the longer the conflict lasts, the later its stabilization will begin, which, with reservations, it estimates could begin to decline at the end of this year.
In the case of a long conflict scenario, Moody's Analytics predicts that inflation in the euro zone will only begin to decline in 2023, with the fall in energy prices.
Regarding Russia, Moody's Analytics economist Olga Kuranova pointed out that, "given the divergent scenarios of war and increasing sanctions from the West, the nation is facing impressive economic volatility."
The economist highlighted that Russia is the third largest oil producing country and the second largest natural gas producer and, taking into account that the prices of those raw materials have soared, the increase in revenue could partially compensate for an embargo on exports.
"However, the tide is turning towards Europe's dependence on Russian energy, and this could have long-term consequences for the nation," added Olga Kuranova.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Manchester United has terminated the sponsorship contract linking it to Russian airline Aeroflot in response to the invasion of Ukraine ordered by Vladimir Putin, the English Football League club announced today.
Aeroflot has been Manchester United's official airline since 2013 and is the one the English club usually uses for European games.
However, this week, for the trip to Spain, to face Atl√©tico de Madrid (1-1), in the Champions League on Wednesday, the English delegation flew with a different airline.
This decision comes after the British government banned Aeroflot planes from flying over UK airspace and the country's aviation authorities withdrew its flying license.
"Due to the events in Ukraine, we have ended our sponsorship with Aeroflot. We understand the concerns of fans around the world, which we extend to those affected by this situation," Manchester United said in a statement.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

"That's what moves us", highlighted Vasco Ribeiro.
The colors of the Ukrainian flag will be projected this evening on Porto City Hall and should remain throughout the weekend.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
UK freezes assets of Vladimir Putin and minister Sergei Lavrov
Lusa Agency
Feb 25, 2022
21:18
0
Comments
The United Kingdom froze the assets of the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, and his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the British government revealed today.
The British Treasury announced that it had added the two Russian figures to its list of entities and individuals targeted for sanctions, due to their role in "destabilizing Ukraine" or "threatening its territorial integrity".
UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson informed his allies today, during an emergency NATO meeting, that he had "imminent" plans to sanction the Russian head of state and the person responsible for diplomacy.
These sanctions follow a series of measures applied this week to Russian oligarchs and banks, among other entities.
Putin and Lavrov now have their assets frozen on British soil.
Boris Johnson described, to his NATO allies, the Russian offensive in Ukraine as a "disaster" and considered that Vladimir Putin is developing a "revenge mission to overthrow the post-Cold War order".
The British government leader also urged Atlantic Alliance allies to "act immediately" to exclude Russia from the Swift banking system in order to "inflict maximum pain" on the Kremlin, Downing Street revealed.
Johnson conveyed that the United Kingdom is ready, if necessary, to increase its military support within the framework of NATO, after warning allies that Putin's ambitions "may not stop here", added the British Prime Minister's office.
The United Kingdom, in addition to sanctioning five banks and three oligarchs on Tuesday, imposed a new package of sanctions against Russia on Thursday, banning the airline Aeroflot from operating on British soil and also targeting the banking sector, technology exports and five businesspeople.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and denazify" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.
